sense.def: a taxi
dictionaryExamples: We took a cab to the theater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I packed my things and I took a cab home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: a large round vegetable with green, white or purple leaves, which can be eaten cooked or raw
dictionaryExamples: a savoy cabbage
red/white cabbage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sarma is made [with] meat and cabbage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: the area where passengers sit on an aircraft
dictionaryExamples: cabin crew
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is [a] cabin attendant now, and she had a flight to London from Japan. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a small, simple house made of wood
dictionaryExamples: a log cabin
We stayed in a cabin and  went hiking every day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Near the cabin there was a creek. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a small room to sleep in on a ship
dictionaryExamples: We had a cabin on the top deck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to my cabin to have a little nap. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a piece of furniture with shelves or drawers to store or show things in
dictionaryExamples: a medicine cabinet
kitchen cabinets
a china cabinet
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bed is on your left, and a big cabinet is on your right. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the system of sending signals carrying information for  television, telephone, or Internet along wires
dictionaryExamples: cable TV/television
This channel is only available on cable.
a cable modem
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rooms are big and [have] cable TV and air conditioning. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a set of wires, covered by plastic, that carries electricity, telephone signals, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The road had been dug up in order to lay cables.
overhead power cables
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A mouse had eaten the cable so that there was no contact any more. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a small restaurant where you can buy drinks and light meals
dictionaryExamples: There's a little café on the corner that serves very good coffee.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a new café near my home. Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese

sense.def: a restaurant where people choose foods from a serving area and carry them to their tables, often in a school, factory, office, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the school cafeteria
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jo, the information is on the wall next to the cafeteria but I have some information [too]. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a container made of wire or metal bars used for keeping birds or animals
dictionaryExamples: It took about 10 minutes to get the mouse into her cage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a wonderful garden, in which you can find a lot of flowers and parrots in [a] cage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a sweet food made from flour, butter, sugar and eggs, mixed together and baked
dictionaryExamples: chocolate cake
a birthday cake
Would you like a piece of/a slice of cake?
He made/baked a delicious cake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your chocolate cake is great too. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: to be very easy
dictionaryExamples: The exam itself was a piece of cake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The article was a piece of cake though I didn't expect to win. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to discover an amount or number using mathematics
dictionaryExamples: Have you calculated the cost of the project?
He's calculated that it would take him two years to save up enough for a car.
At some stage we need to calculate when the project will be finished.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To end with, the police calculated that there were over 5000 people [at] the Festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be intended to have a particular effect
dictionaryExamples: His comments were calculated to embarrass the president.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Had he known that his Majesty would be vexed, he would have never written such comical r[hy]mes, hardly calculated to [e]ndear himself to the King. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when you use mathematics to discover an amount or number
dictionaryExamples: I did some quick calculations to see if we could afford it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just a simple calculation: the living space an elephant has got in a zoo is about 500m2. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: an electronic device that you use to do mathematical calculations
dictionaryExamples: a pocket calculator
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I use the calculator and the computer every day, so modern technology has become a big part of my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a list that shows all the days, weeks and months of the year
dictionaryExamples: a calendar for the year 2022
I think my birthday is on a Saturday - I'll check the calendar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a calendar from Jul[ie], a candle from Peter, a book from Robert and a birthday cake from my parents. Key English Test; A2; Slovak

sense.def: a book or other list with spaces for each day of the year in which to write down appointments, meetings, etc.
dictionaryExamples: OK, I put that in my calendar - dinner at seven on the twenty-third.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have looked in my calendar to see what time would be the best for you to come here. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a young cow
dictionaryExamples: There were some calves in the field.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That reminded me [of] the time when I milked the cows and fe[d] the ewes and the calves. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the back of your leg below your knee
dictionaryExamples: I pulled a muscle in my calf.

sense.def: relaxed and not worried, frightened, or excited
dictionaryExamples: Try to stay calm - the doctor will be here soon.
Now keep calm everyone, the police are on their way.
He has a very calm manner/voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is calm, friendly and helpful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: describes weather which is not windy, or the sea or a lake when it is still and has no waves
dictionaryExamples: calm seas
The weather was calmer the next morning so we set sail.
There was no rain that day and the  sea was calm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sea is calm with almost no waves, so we could relax in the water. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop feeling upset, angry, or excited, or to stop someone from feeling this way
dictionaryExamples: Calm down, Lily, and tell me what's wrong.
She was angry at first but we managed to calm her down.
She sat down and took a few deep breaths to calm herself down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I got in my car, I told myself to calm down and take a deep breath. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in a quiet or relaxed way
dictionaryExamples: She reacted surprisingly calmly to the news of his death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very calmly, I closed my book and put it on the table which was on my left. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a large animal that lives in the desert and has one or two raised parts on its back
dictionaryExamples: Have you ever ridden a camel?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can enjoy watching camels and goats passing, once in the morning and [again] in the evening. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: a device for taking photographs or making films or television programs
dictionaryExamples: I forgot to take my camera with me to Portugal, so I couldn't take any photos.
Television camera crews broadcast the event all round the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it, because my camera has broken. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a place where people stay in tents or other temporary structures
dictionaryExamples: We set up camp near the lake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The camp was a peaceful place with flowers, trees, and a [bike path]. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a place in the countryside where you go for a vacation and that has cabins or tents and offers a program of things to do
dictionaryExamples: The kids go away to summer camp for two weeks every August.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was a friend I have not seen for four years. We met in summer camp and had great time together, but I lost her phone number. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: an area containing temporary buildings or tents used for soldiers/prisoners/refugees
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This year I think I'd rather go to a refugee camp to organi[z]e a program for children. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: to stay in a tent or temporary shelter
dictionaryExamples: We camped near the beach for two nights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We camped near a group of lions the first night. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a series of organized activities or events intended to achieve a result
dictionaryExamples: an advertising/election campaign
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order to solve problems caused by traffic congestion, perhaps the City Co[u]ncil should consider launching a publicity campaign to show people in Baden the alternative means of transport and the advantages of using them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a series of military attacks
dictionaryExamples: a bombing campaign
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another example is the campaign of Alexander the Great. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to organize a series of activities to try to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: to campaign against/for something
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of campaigning against tourism, people should [look for] ways of making it better and safer. International English Language Testing System; C1; Bengali

sense.def: when you stay in a tent on vacation
dictionaryExamples: We used to go camping in Vermont when I was a child.
camping equipment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobb[ies are] singing, reading and going camping. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: an space where a person can put a tent and other equipment and stay on vacation
dictionaryExamples: The campsite was near the beach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really enjoyed the scenery because near our tent there was a tiny waterfall; in front of our campsite there was a forest. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the buildings of a college or university and the land that surrounds them
dictionaryExamples: There's housing for about five hundred students on campus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [should] visit Kamakura City, which is 30 minutes from our campus by train. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a closed, metal container for food or liquids
dictionaryExamples: a can of beans/soup
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have already bought two cans of blue paint. Key English Test; A2; Marathi

sense.def: to be able to
dictionaryExamples: Can you drive?
She can speak four languages.
I can't read that sign over there - what does it say?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was difficult to join two words of English correct[l]y. Now I can speak. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: used to request something
dictionaryExamples: If you see Adrian, can you tell him I'll be in London next weekend?
Can I have a glass of water?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So please, can you make me a big sala[d]? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: used in polite offers of help
dictionaryExamples: Can I help you with those bags?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can I help you? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lithuanian

sense.def: used to talk about what is possible
dictionaryExamples: You can get stamps at the post office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: to be allowed to
dictionaryExamples: Can I go now?
You can't park here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And if you want, you can bring pencils or pens. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: used to show surprise or lack of belief
dictionaryExamples: You can't possibly be hungry already!
Can you believe it?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, the highest tree there is almost 30 met[er]s tall! Can you believe that? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to talk about how someone often behaves or what something is often like
dictionaryExamples: She can be really rude at times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you choose to travel by car there can be a lot of traffic. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: used to say that something sometimes happens or is true
dictionaryExamples: Smoking can cause cancer.
The nights can be very cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But overworking is also bad. It has lots of disadvantages, and can cause lots of problems, including health problems. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: an artificial river built for boats to travel along or to  take water from one area to another
dictionaryExamples: The Panama Canal provides a crucial shipping link between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And if you don't like jazz, you could visit Tivoli or take a canal tour. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to decide that an organized event will not now happen, or to stop an order for goods or services that you no longer want
dictionaryExamples: They had to cancel tonight's game because of the bad weather.
The concert was cancelled.
I've cancelled the order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had nothing to do because my previous plans had been cancelled. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when someone decides that an event will not now happen or stops an order for something
dictionaryExamples: a last-minute cancellation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To begin with, there was a general disappointment due to the cancellation of the opening speech. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a serious disease that is caused when cells in the body grow in a way that is uncontrolled and not normal
dictionaryExamples: breast/lung cancer
He died of liver cancer.
cancer of the stomach
a cancer patient
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doctors told my parents that my aunt was suffering from cancer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a person who is competing to get a job or elected position
dictionaryExamples: There are three candidates running for mayor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am the appropriate candidate for this job. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a stick of wax with string going through it which produces light as it burns
dictionaryExamples: Shall I light a candle?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like shopping for clothes but also for other things like candles and so on. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a sweet food made from sugar or chocolate, or a piece of this
dictionaryExamples: a candy bar
a box of candy
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like a box of candy. Key English Test; A2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: used to describe food or drink that has been put into metal containers in a factory
dictionaryExamples: canned tomatoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A new way of of eating has sprung [up] - fast food and canned vegetables are all around us. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the negative form of "can"
dictionaryExamples: I cannot predict what will happen next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cannot sp[ea]k English. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Czech

sense.def: a hat with a curved part at the front
dictionaryExamples: He wears a baseball cap.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to buy sho[es], [a] pull-over, tee-shirt, cap and sun glasses. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to put a limit on an amount of money that can be borrowed, charged, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The interest rate has been capped at 5%.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Balance sheets reveal a need of further income. Since the fee needs to be capped to be suitable for students, we cannot raise it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the ability or power to do something
dictionaryExamples: Both players have the capability to win this match.
With the new machines we finally have the capability to do the job properly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important part of this job is to be able to work as a member of a team and manage to use everyone's skills and capabilities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: able to do things effectively  and achieve results
dictionaryExamples: She's a very capable young woman.
He's very capable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a little farm when I was in Italy so I think I'm quite capable and have more experience than others. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: having the ability, power or qualities to be able to do something
dictionaryExamples: She is certainly capable of running the business.
She was capable of great cruelty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And although I've never had to cook [for] myself, I suppose I would be capable of cooking if needed. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the largest amount or number that a container, building, etc. can hold
dictionaryExamples: a restaurant with a capacity of 200
The new stadium has a seating capacity of 50,000.
The stadium was filled to capacity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would recommend the use of the state stadium next year for the concerts, in order to support the capacity of the crowd. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the ability to do, experience, or understand something
dictionaryExamples: She has a great capacity for hard work.
What impresses me is his capacity to absorb information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, I think [films] reduce your capacity [for] imagination. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a position or job
dictionaryExamples: She attended over 100 events last year in her capacity as mayor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm writing in my capacity as secretary of the Social Club of the language school to complain about the services provided to us during our visit to the Science and Technology museum. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a city which is the center of government of a country, state or region
dictionaryExamples: The capital of France is Paris.
Australia's capital city is Canberra.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll go to Hue province, it's the old capital of Vietnam; you can take [a] train, car or plane from Hanoi to Hue. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a political and economic system in which industry is owned privately for profit and not by the state
dictionaryExamples: Modern capitalism has shaped the global economy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although living in the former DDR was almost like living in prison, the film shows the problem of unemployment and the negative results of capitalism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: relating to capitalism
dictionaryExamples: a capitalist society
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There will be important insights to have in exam[in]ing the ways Japan maintains its social solidarity while prospering as a capitalist society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a large letter of the alphabet used at the beginning of sentences and names
dictionaryExamples: Write your answers in capital letters on the answer sheet.

sense.def: the leader of a sports team
dictionaryExamples: It's unusual to have a goalkeeper as the team captain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I am the captain of the football team. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the person in charge of a ship or an aircraft
dictionaryExamples: This is your captain speaking. We expect to be landing at London Heathrow in an hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest you leave at 8 a.m., because it tends to less crowded then, according to the captain of the ship. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to catch someone and make them your prisoner, or to take something into your possession, especially by force
dictionaryExamples: Two of the soldiers were killed and the rest were captured.
Rebel forces captured the city after a week-long battle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joe, the serial killer, was captured. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to show or describe something successfully using words or pictures
dictionaryExamples: His book really captures the spirit of the place.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, let me tell you that your report is really good. I think you capture in a few lines the whole expression of a Mexic[an] town['s] life. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to record someone or something on camera/film, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He was captured on film swearing at the referee.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another event that should absolutely be captured on film is the preparation of the meals in the canteen. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to make someone interested in or excited about something
dictionaryExamples: The Moon landing captured the attention of the whole world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure this program would capture the interest of other students in this college, as those who participated would be telling their friends all about their adventurous trip. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when a person or animal is caught and made a prisoner
dictionaryExamples: He shot himself to avoid capture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best example is Operation Takedown w[h]ich is based on the capture of Kevin Mitnick, who illegally hacked in to computers and stole information, but in the movie he is presented [as] a hero. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a road vehicle with an engine, four wheels, and seats for a small number of people
dictionaryExamples: They don't have a car.
Where did you park your car?
It's quicker by car.
a car crash
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are coming by car. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: one of the separate parts of a train where the passengers sit
dictionaryExamples: a dining/café/sleeping car
freight/passenger cars
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a dining car in the train so you can eat duri[n]g the tr[ip]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a chemical element present in all animals and plants and in coal and oil
dictionaryExamples: Diamonds are formed from  carbon.

sense.def: the gas formed when carbon is burned, or when people or animals breathe out
dictionaryExamples: carbon dioxide emissions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we use up carbon dioxide with balloon clothes there will be less carbon dioxide on Earth, so there is no worry about [the] Ozone. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the amount of energy that a person or organization uses in order to exist or operate
dictionaryExamples: Many of us could reduce our carbon footprint by taking fewer flights and insulating our homes better.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also included some possible precautions to reduce our carbon footprints. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a poisonous gas that is produced by burning some types of fuel, especially petrol
dictionaryExamples: The cause of death was given as carbon monoxide poisoning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cars also emit carbon monoxide and make the air unfit to breath. First Certificate in English; B2; Amharic

sense.def: a folded piece of stiff paper with a picture on the front and a message inside, that you send to someone on a special occasion
dictionaryExamples: birthday/get-well cards
It's Steve's birthday on Thursday - I should send him a card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a pretty hat and a birthday card from them. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: one of a set of 52 small rectangular pieces of stiff paper, each with a number and one of four signs printed on it, used in games
dictionaryExamples: After dinner, Ted got out a pack of cards
They play a lot of card games.
Do you want to play cards?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joe, Marie, Martin and Alison came so we played cards. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a small piece of stiff paper or plastic that has information printed on it
dictionaryExamples: a library card
He gave me his business card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important because my student card is in there. Key English Test; A2; Burmese

sense.def: a part inside a computer which controls how the computer operates
dictionaryExamples: a graphics/sound card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Obviously, I complete[d] the configuration with a sound card and the connection by modem to [the] internet, creating a powerful multimedia work station. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to be likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: Do you think marriage is in the cards?

sense.def: material like very thick stiff paper, usually pale brown in color, which is used especially for making boxes
dictionaryExamples: a cardboard box

sense.def: a piece of clothing often made from wool, that covers the upper part of the body and fastens at the front
dictionaryExamples: My worst present ever was an orange and green knit cardigan from my aunt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope it will be warm enough that I only need a cardigan. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the job or series of jobs that you do during your working life, especially if you continue to get better jobs and earn more money
dictionaryExamples: He hasn't yet chosen a career.
a successful career in marketing
What are the career prospects?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's important to learn English for my career in the future. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the time that you spend doing a particular job
dictionaryExamples: She began her acting career in TV commercials.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His tennis career was only a small introduction to his business career. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: without any worries or problems
dictionaryExamples: a carefree childhood
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It reminded her of their far-away, carefree youth when they were energetic, healthy and full of hope. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: giving a lot of attention to what you are doing so that you do not have an accident, make a mistake, or damage something
dictionaryExamples: Be careful with that knife.
Be careful where you put that hot pan.
Be careful what/how much you say to him - he can't keep any secrets!
Be careful to look both ways when you cross the road.
Michael is a very careful worker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you must be more careful. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: with great attention
dictionaryExamples: She carefully folded the letter and put it in her pocket.
Drive carefully on those icy roads.
It was a carefully prepared speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Look at it carefully. Key English Test; A2; Korean

sense.def: not giving enough attention to what you are doing
dictionaryExamples: careless driving/drivers
My son's teacher says that his work is often careless and sloppy.
He made a careless remark about her appearance that really upset her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Car accidents happen every day, because many drivers are careless. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a careless way
dictionaryExamples: He told me off for driving carelessly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I broke your beautiful vase carelessly while I ran to answer the door. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the state of being careless
dictionaryExamples: It's the carelessness with which he just throws stuff on the floor that annoys me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please forgive my carelessness. I'd like to bring a new one like yours when I come to you next time. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: goods that are carried in a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: a cargo of oil
a cargo ship/plane
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ships that pass through the Schelde usually carry cargo such as oil, and different vitally important foods from abroad. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: describes someone who is kind and gives emotional support to others
dictionaryExamples: I've always thought of Jo as a very caring person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course I enjoyed staying with you. It was really a remarkable experience being able to live with a caring family like yours. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a public celebration where people wear special clothes and dance and play music in the streets
dictionaryExamples: I took the kids to the local carnival.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course it is not as good as the carnival [in] Rio! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an entertainment event outdoors where there is food, machines you can ride on, and games that can be played for prizes
dictionaryExamples: The annual carnival will be held at Harbor Island park next weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to your letter, you have decided to turn up the first week of July.  This is great, because on the 5th and 6th of July there is a carnival. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: thick material for covering floors, often made of wool
dictionaryExamples: We've got carpets in all the bedrooms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do we care about a new carpet or fashionable furniture? No, I do not think so. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a vehicle with wheels that is pulled by a horse
dictionaryExamples: a horse and carriage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bride arrived in a open carriage pulled by horses surrounded by flowers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a long, thin orange vegetable that grows in the ground
dictionaryExamples: raw carrot
Finely chop the carrots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can just bring vegetables - tomato[es], carrots, cucumber and potatoes. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: something that is offered to someone in order to encourage them to do something
dictionaryExamples: The carrot is the extra payment they will get if they finish the work on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Weiss['s] policy of dangling the carrot proved useful - he managed, literally, to hit two birds with one stone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to hold something or someone with your hands, arms, or on your back and take them from one place to another
dictionaryExamples: Let me carry your bag for you.
She was carrying a small child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To help you I can carry some drinks and food. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: to have something with you all the time
dictionaryExamples: She still carries his photo in her purse.
Police officers in Britain do not usually carry guns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my lucky T-shirt which I used to carry with me anywhere I would go. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to move someone or something from one place to another
dictionaryExamples: The plane was carrying 300 passengers.
The bus was carrying children to school.
Underground cables carry electricity to all parts of the city.
Police think that the body was carried down the river.
Trash left on the beach during the day is carried away at night by the tide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jay's swimming trunks got carried away by that huge wave. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to have a disease that you might give to someone else
dictionaryExamples: Mosquitoes carry malaria and other infectious diseases.

sense.def: to have something as a part, quality, or result of something
dictionaryExamples: All cigarette advertising must carry a government health warning.
Murder still carries the death penalty there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not something flashy or expensive but to me it is an object that carries great sentimental value. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to support the weight of something
dictionaryExamples: Is the ice thick enough to carry my weight?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My legs hardly managed to carry my weight as we began to enter. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to be considered important and effective in influencing someone
dictionaryExamples: His opinions carry a lot of weight with the scientific community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has become increasingly important to strive for near perfection in every move they make, the pursuit of excellence therefore carrying more weight than ever and leading to strenuous tr[ai]ning programs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: to be so excited about something that you do not control what you say or do
dictionaryExamples: There's far too much food - I'm afraid I got a bit carried away!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was so very tired but the book was so interesting that I got carried away. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue
dictionaryExamples: Let's carry on this discussion at some other time.
Carry on with your work while I'm gone.
Just carry on as if nothing happened.
Steve just carried on talking even after the orchestra started to play.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I promise that when I come back I'll carry on studying. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

blocks.phrasalVerb: carry out sth or carry sth out

sense.def: to do or complete something, especially something that you have said you would do or that you have been told to do
dictionaryExamples: Nigel is carrying out research on early Christian art.
The hospital is carrying out tests to find out what's wrong with her.
It is hoped that the kidnappers will not carry out their threat to kill the hostages.
Don't blame me, I'm only carrying out my orders/instructions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will try to carry out my duties to the best of my ability. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a vehicle with two or four wheels that is pushed or pulled to carry large or heavy objects on
dictionaryExamples: a shopping/grocery/luggage cart
His first job was delivering fruits and vegetables by horse-drawn cart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to put my suitcase on my cart. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a film made using characters that are drawn and not real
dictionaryExamples: Mickey Mouse and other famous cartoon characters
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to paint my room with cartoon characters. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: a funny drawing, especially in a newspaper or magazine
dictionaryExamples: He likes the cartoons that you get on the back page.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [My] present is a pack of cartoon books. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to make an object, a shape, or a pattern by cutting wood, stone, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The statue was carved out of stone.
They had carved their initials into the tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Odd symbols have been carved on both sides of its square handle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a container for storing or protecting something
dictionaryExamples: a pencil case
an eyeglass case
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring with you your pencil case, your books and your notebooks. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a particular situation or example of something
dictionaryExamples: Over fifty people were injured, in several cases seriously.
I wouldn't normally agree but I'll make an exception in this case.
The number of new cases of flu has risen.
We have lots of applications from people who want to study here and in each case we consider the candidate very carefully.
She was suffering from an extreme case of sunburn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this case, I suggest that you need to gather your friends and go to ask for it together. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: when something happens, or in preparation for when something happens
dictionaryExamples: We keep a bucket of water backstage, in case of fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is about how to rescue people in case of an accident or a natural disaster. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: because of a possibility of something happening, being needed, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I don't think I'll need any money but I'll bring some just in case.
Bring a map in case you get lost.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't forget to bring comfortable shoes in case you have to walk long distances while you are sightseeing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be true
dictionaryExamples: Bad diet can cause tiredness, but I don't think that's the case here.
I take it that  the price includes breakfast - if that isn't the case, please let us know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could you also please let me know if you're coming back in time for dinner because if that's the case I'll make a spe[cial] dinner for us. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to give another reason for something you are saying, or that you have done
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to go, and in any case I haven't been invited.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest that you should in any case leave your car at home and take buses or other public means of transport. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: because of the mentioned situation
dictionaryExamples: There's no coffee left? In that case I'll have tea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could try [k]ayaking. In that case, of course, you need to pay for the equipment. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a crime that police are trying to solve
dictionaryExamples: a murder case
Police in the town have investigated 50 cases of burglary in the past month.
The detective on the case has been suspended from duty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They succeeded in solving a case too difficult even for the police. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a matter to be decided by a judge in a court of law
dictionaryExamples: The case will go before the European Court next month.
She accused her employer of unlawful dismissal and won/lost her case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To summarize, we lost the case on the ground that he had [a] criminal background and that the girl's testimony wasn't reliable because she was in love with the man, as she confessed herself in court. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: an illness, or somebody with an illness
dictionaryExamples: 4,000 new cases of the disease are diagnosed every year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two years ago, Mr Slovac contacted us and told us that John had died of a severe case of malaria. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: arguments, facts, or reasons that prove a particular opinion
dictionaryExamples: There is a strong case for/against passing the new legislation.
He put the case for more funding very convincingly.
She was given the opportunity to state her case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But there are other reasons which help make a case for tourism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: money in the form of notes and coins
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any cash on you?
Will you pay by credit card or in cash?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I went to your house last night, I left my red bag - in there I have some cash and my glasses. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: money in any form
dictionaryExamples: I'm a bit short of cash at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a lot of hotels, but if you don't want to spend [any] cash you can stay at my place. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a machine, usually at a bank or store, that you can get  money from using a plastic card
dictionaryExamples: I got some money out from the cash machine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Are] there any cash machines nea[r] where we [are] staying? First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: a mixture of meat, vegetables, or other foods cooked with liquid for a long time in the oven
dictionaryExamples: a beef casserole
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The "Quaint and Co[z]y," which faces our town's main square, is a classy place with a hint of irony: the atmosphere, quiet and relaxing, is what you need to taste a very special salmon [e]n croute, and a pork and orange casserole that eventually became the restaurant's second name. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a large, heavy container with a lid, that is used for cooking casseroles
dictionaryExamples: Bake the mixture in a casserole.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember going around the kitchen, looking for old used pans, casseroles and all kind of utensils which could call the attention of the people passing by. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: all the actors in a film, play or show
dictionaryExamples: After the final performance, the director threw a party for the cast.
Part of the film's success lies in the strength of the supporting cast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We saw a romantic film with a famous cast. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to choose an actor for a particular part in a movie or play
dictionaryExamples: Why is he always cast as a criminal?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And this "universal force" of this book made [it] possible to already have two cinematographic versions; the first, really similar to the book, casts Colin Firth as the main character, the second, an American version of the book, changed the football passion [to] a baseball madness, showing well how universal this story could be. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to vote
dictionaryExamples: More than 30,000 citizens cast their votes in the last city election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every several years, in every country people have to make their choices during general elections. Often a great number of political parties encourage them to cast their votes according to the unemployment policy the candidates are supposed to introduce once they are appointed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to try to remember
dictionaryExamples: If you cast your mind back, you might recall that I never promised to go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, when I pick one of these stones, I cast my mind back to the specific place where I found it, the person I was, the particular moment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to seem to use magic to attract someone
dictionaryExamples: The city had cast a spell on me and I never wanted to leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even objects that came indirectly into our possession may cast an emotional spell on us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to use magic to make something happen to someone
dictionaryExamples: The witch cast a spell on her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The good fairy, taking pity upon Laura, prevented her from going on living without her prince - which would have been too painful for her - by casting a spell upon the castle that put every one of its inhabitants [in]to a deep, dreamless sleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to make people feel uncertain about someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Witnesses have cast doubt on the suspect's innocence.
A leading scientist has cast doubts on government claims that the medication is safe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wars lead to suffering, tears and [the] death of many people. They cast doubt on our humanity and values, especially in countries where the right to live is the princip[al] one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to send light or shadow in a particular direction
dictionaryExamples: The moon cast a white light into the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first blush of the morning was casting a yellow soft light over the landscape. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a large strong building with towers and high walls that was built in the past to protect the people inside from being attacked
dictionaryExamples: Warwick Castle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could visit a really famous castle which is near my town. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: Casual clothes are comfortable clothes worn when there is no reason to dress in a formal way.
dictionaryExamples: casual clothes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I mostly wear casual things, jumpers and jeans for example. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: not planned, or without particular meaning or importance
dictionaryExamples: a casual meeting/remark
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was last summer, when I had a casual meeting with someone. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: in a casual way
dictionaryExamples: She was dressed casually in shorts and a T-shirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest that you and your group go dressed casually. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who is injured or killed in an accident or war
dictionaryExamples: Both sides in the conflict have promised to try to avoid civilian casualties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As films, books and documentaries show, it was a real disaster, not only because the ship sank, but also due to the high number of casualties. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a small animal with fur, four legs and a tail that is kept as a pet
dictionaryExamples: I saw that orange cat today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have two dogs, [a] cat and lots of birds. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a book with a list of items, such as goods that you can buy from a business or pictures displayed in a museum
dictionaryExamples: a mail-order catalog
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't need to bring me back a gift, but, just in case you have planned to visit the MOMA, then I'd like their last exhibition catalog (you know, the one about fashion in the [Twentieth] Century). First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: an extremely bad event that causes a lot of suffering or destruction
dictionaryExamples: After the drought, the country is facing environmental catastrophe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Asian and African societies, where time is seen as a circle, rather than a straight line with [a] definite beginning and end, the legacy of past generations is regarded with due respect as the main source of wisdom and deliverance from natural catastrophes as well as everyday difficulties. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to take hold of something, especially something that is moving through the air
dictionaryExamples: Try to catch the ball.
She fell backwards but he caught her in his arms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like the competition, because it's interesting to see who can catch the ball and who can't. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to get on a bus, train, etc. in order to travel somewhere
dictionaryExamples: He catches the 8:30 train into the city every morning.
I got there too late to catch the last bus home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can catch the bus to Cheltenham. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to get an illness, especially one caused by bacteria or a virus
dictionaryExamples: He's caught a cold.
He caught the flu while we were on vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard you caught a cold. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to find and stop a person or animal that is trying to escape
dictionaryExamples: Did they ever catch the terrorists?
They caught a lot of fish that day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave me some good tips on how to catch some really large fish. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to start burning
dictionaryExamples: The factory caught fire late yesterday evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the new machines that I had brought from Germany had caught fire. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to make someone notice something and feel interested
dictionaryExamples: A ship out at sea caught his attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the museums have very interesting objects displayed, but they don't know how to catch the visitor's attention. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to discover someone who is doing something wrong or something secret
dictionaryExamples: He caught her reading his old love letters.
She was caught cheating on the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [learned] a good lesson when I was caught cheating on a test at school last year. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If the police catch a criminal, they find them and take them away.
dictionaryExamples: These terrorists must be caught.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The issue had been forgotten and the burglar was never caught. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to rest for a short time until you can breathe regularly again
dictionaryExamples: Let's stop here and catch our breath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, the rooms we stayed in were on the 4th floor. The older people couldn't catch their breath when they finally arrived there! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to be unable to avoid something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: I got caught in the rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must apologi[z]e for my lateness as I was caught in the bad weather. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to stick somewhere, or to make something stick somewhere
dictionaryExamples: My dress caught on the door handle as I was leaving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No sooner did I start bicycling before my slacks got caught in the chain and with a curse coming from my lips I fell right into the neighbor's well trimmed shrubbery. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to see something suddenly, often only for a short time
dictionaryExamples: He caught sight of himself in the mirror.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All we could see were people bursting into tears when they caught sight of his coffin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to get someone's attention by looking at them
dictionaryExamples: I tried to catch her eye, but she had already turned away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All of a sudden she caught my eye and smiled in a sad way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to be attractive or different enough to be noticed by people
dictionaryExamples: It was the color of his jacket that caught my eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir, I am writing regarding your newly published article about nutrition, which immediately caught my eye as I was reading your magazine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: to surprise someone by doing something when they are not ready to deal with it
dictionaryExamples: The journalist caught him off guard and he admitted to lying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It caught me off guard. This grotesque image shattered the comfort of a languid Sunday afternoon and for a few seconds hurled me into a world of pain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to become popular
dictionaryExamples: I wonder if the game will catch on with young people?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The commercial succes[s] of "Super agent" has resulted in introducing "Super agent II", the game which is sup[p]osed to present further adventures of the agent. Unfortunately, I don't think that it will catch on. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to understand something, especially after a long time
dictionaryExamples: It took him a while to catch on to what we meant.

sense.def: to reach someone in front of you by going faster than them
dictionaryExamples: I ran after her and managed to catch up with her.
You go on ahead - I'll catch up later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to catch up with the guide and the other tourists. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to reach the same level or quality as someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: She's doing extra work to catch up with the rest of the class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her father did not really seem to hate her, after all, and if she was always left in the shadow, that happened because she did not do her best to catch up with her brothers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to learn and discuss the newest facts about something
dictionaryExamples: I'll call you tonight to catch up on all the gossip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could catch up on each other's news. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to become involved in a situation, often without wanting to
dictionaryExamples: How did the paper get caught up in a legal dispute?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order not to get caught up in a vicious circle, it's sensible just to study well and then be able to for[e]see the results of [your] actions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to meet someone you know after not seeing them for a period of time and talk about what you have been doing
dictionaryExamples: I caught up with him in Singapore a few years later.
I'll catch up with you later!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should catch up with me in Sicily, where you will be able to walk on the best beaches you have ever seen. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If something bad that you have done or that has been happening to you catches up with you, it begins to cause problems for you.
dictionaryExamples: I can feel the stress of the last few weeks beginning to catch up with me.

sense.def: to do something that you did not have time to do earlier
dictionaryExamples: I'm hoping to catch up on some sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It gave me time to catch up with my reading and sleeping. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a group of people or things of the same type
dictionaryExamples: There are three categories - standard, executive and deluxe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I belong to the category of people who think that society needs zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to provide and often serve food and drinks for a particular event
dictionaryExamples: We hired a local chef to cater our parents' anniversary party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can understand why you shortlisted these three proposals as all of them seem good enough to cater for our canteen. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to provide what is wanted or needed by a particular group of people
dictionaryExamples: Our magazines cater to professionals such as lawyers and physicians.
This legislation simply caters to a small minority and shouldn't be passed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Retail establishments have enhanced and multiplied [their] product offerings to cater to a wider market. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: providing food and drinks for people
dictionaryExamples: Who did the catering for the party?
a high-class catering company
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All food, appetizers and refreshments will be provided by a catering company. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the largest and most important church in a particular area
dictionaryExamples: Salisbury Cathedral
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's an interesting place because there is an important cathedral called Lujan Cathedral. Key English Test; A2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: male and female cows kept on a farm for their milk or meat
dictionaryExamples: beef/dairy cattle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was born in Australia, where his father has a big cattle station. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the reason why something, especially something bad, happens
dictionaryExamples: The police are still trying to establish the cause of the fire.
She had died of natural causes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Overworking can be a cause of many problems. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a principle or aim that a group of people support or fight for
dictionaryExamples: The money will all go to a good cause.
The war will not end as long as people believe they are fighting for the right cause.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be a shame if people got the wrong impression, that it is not worth working and making an effort for charity and good causes and I would certainly not like to beli[e]ve that your paper contributed to giving that impression?? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a reason to feel something or to behave in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: He's never given me any cause for concern.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, the world is filled with fast food restaurants, making diseases like obesity a cause for concern everywhere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make something happen, especially something bad
dictionaryExamples: The difficult driving conditions caused several accidents.
Most heart attacks are caused by blood clots.
The bright light caused her to look away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is troubling that young people are eating a less healthy diet nowadays than their grandparents did. This is caused mainly by changes in food and eating habits. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: great care and attention not to take risks or get into danger
dictionaryExamples: Travelers have been advised to exercise great caution when passing through the region.
I would treat anything he says with extreme caution.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Extreme caution has to be taken during push-back and engine start. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to take a risk
dictionaryExamples: I decided to throw caution to the wind and book a ticket to India.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They just threw caution to the wind, and did what they wanted. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: to warn someone of something
dictionaryExamples: They were cautioned against traveling alone through the desert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is a totally unnecessary situation to be in and if possible, people should be cautioned about getting into such a habit. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tagalog

sense.def: taking care to avoid risks or danger
dictionaryExamples: He's a very cautious driver.
We take a more cautious approach.
She is cautious about lending money to anyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should be cautious and sensible. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a large hole in the side of a hill, cliff or mountain, or one that is underground
dictionaryExamples: The area is also home to one of the largest underground cave and lake systems in Latin America.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The next day I went to see a cave with a blue lake inside it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: compact disc: a small disc on which music or information is recorded
dictionaryExamples: His CD collection is huge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Martin gave me a CD, Valeria gave me some make-up, and Juliana gave me a pink belt. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a machine that is used for playing music CDs
dictionaryExamples: She has a CD player in her bedroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My cousin bought me a CD player and I got a box of chocolate[s] from my friends. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: compact disc read-only memory: a disc that holds large amounts of information that can be read by a computer but cannot be changed
dictionaryExamples: Cambridge dictionaries are available on CD-ROM.

sense.def: to stop
dictionaryExamples: He ordered his men to cease firing.
The company has decided to cease all UK operations after this year.
She never ceases to amaze me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I thought the ring was just inside my head, in the dream.  But it didn't cease, making me realize it was something else, from outside the room. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the surface of a room which you can see when you look above you
dictionaryExamples: Look at all those lights hanging from the ceiling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to use lilac for the walls and violet for the ceiling. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a limit on the amount that can be paid for something
dictionaryExamples: They have set a ceiling on pay raises.

sense.def: to do something enjoyable because it is a special day, or because something good has happened
dictionaryExamples: We always celebrate our wedding anniversary by going out to dinner.
We'd just finished our exams so we were having a party to celebrate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to celebrate my husband's birthday at home with some friends, so I'm preparing everything for the party. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a special social event, such as a party, when you celebrate something, or the act of celebrating something
dictionaryExamples: There were New Year's celebrations all over town.
Such good news calls for a celebration!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that he decided to marry and he invited me [to] the celebration in Paris in November. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: someone who is famous, especially in the entertainment business
dictionaryExamples: It's a celebrity gossip magazine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was in London, I went to the Cosmopolitan Show and I [entered] a game to win one week with a fashion celebrity. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the smallest basic unit of a plant or animal
dictionaryExamples: brain/blood cells
cancer cells
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [...] such as, us[ing] gamma rays to damage the cancer cell or to treat people's short sight and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a small room in a prison or police station where a prisoner is kept
dictionaryExamples: He was kept in a prison cell for four months.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's why six years after this I'm writing the story in my cold wet cell. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a room under the ground floor of a building, usually used for storage
dictionaryExamples: He keeps his wine in the cellar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were in the cellar of the old castle without a candle or even matches. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a large, wooden musical instrument with four strings that you hold between your knees to play
dictionaryExamples: She plays the cello.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was Beethoven, the 9th symphony. The cellos [and] violins, followed by the timpani... First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a telephone that you can carry everywhere with you
dictionaryExamples: Rory is always on his cell phone, either talking or texting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I left my cell phone at your house. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a place where dead people are buried
dictionaryExamples: She went to the cemetery where her grandfather was buried.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was Halloween night and almost midnight, and Steve had the idea of going out to the nearest cemetery to catch some ghosts or vampires. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a unit of money worth 0.01 of the US dollar and of the main monetary unit of many countries, or a coin with this value
dictionaryExamples: He spent eighty cents on a chocolate bar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last weekend I went with a few friends to the shopping center of my town, but I [did]n't spend a cent. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the middle point or part of something
dictionaryExamples: There was a large table in the center of the room.
She stood in the center of the stage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My new house is in the center of Rome. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a place or a building used for a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: a fitness/medical/community center
a garden/shopping center
a center for the arts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can go to see the film tomorrow at 6:00 o'clock an then we can go to the shopping center. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to receive more attention than anyone or anything else
dictionaryExamples: He loves to be the center of attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He would have so much fun being the center of attention. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a political position with opinions that are not extreme
dictionaryExamples: His political views are left of center.

sense.def: a measurement of temperature in which water freezes at 0° and boils at 100°
dictionaryExamples: Water boils at 100° centigrade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last few days I prefer[red] to go swimming, because the temperature was above thirty degrees centigrade. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a unit of length equal to 0.01 of a meter
dictionaryExamples: The picture measures fifty by thirty centimeters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher told us to bring with us some pencils, colo[r] pencils and a rule[r] (about 30 centimeters). Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: in or near the center of a place or object
dictionaryExamples: central Europe/London
Of course, you pay more for a hotel in a  central location.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could go for a walk to the park in the central area of my town. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in the main part of a town or city
dictionaryExamples: Our offices are very central.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The house location is very central, it is in South Kensington and it is [with]in walking distance [of] Gloucester Road Underground station. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: controlled or organized in one main place
dictionaryExamples: central authorities/government
the US central bank
central control/planning
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The contribution of the central government seems to be inevitable to complete the project. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: main or most important
dictionaryExamples: a central character/figure
the central argument of the book
Her role is central to the movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a central character, Piggy works both as a real boy and a symbol. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a system of heating a building by warming air or water in one place and carrying it to different rooms in pipes
dictionaryExamples: The house had no central heating so in winter it was freezing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this restaurant because it's cheap, big and tidy, [and] at the same time it has central heating and air condition[ing]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: a period of 100 years, especially used in giving dates
dictionaryExamples: the 21st century
The town has changed hardly at all in over a century.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love it, because for me "The Beatles" is the best band of the century. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the start of a new century
dictionaryExamples: He was born at the turn of the century.

sense.def: a food that is made from grain and usually eaten with milk, especially in the morning
dictionaryExamples: a bowl of cereal
breakfast cereals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually, we have a good breakfast with toast, cereals, milk and juice, but it depends [on] each person. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a plant that is grown to produce grain for food
dictionaryExamples: cereal crops
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During this part you can see cereal crops, mainly wheat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a formal event that is performed on important social or religious occasions
dictionaryExamples: a wedding/graduation ceremony
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In July I'm going to [get] married to my girl friend, and the wedding ceremony is on 7th of July. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: completely sure of something, or knowing without doubt that something is true
dictionaryExamples: I feel certain (that) you're doing the right thing.
Are you absolutely certain (that) you gave them the right number?
I'm not certain how much it will cost.
He was quite certain about/of his attacker's identity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm certain that in your country weddings are as wonderful as in Brazil. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: sure to happen, to do something, or to be true
dictionaryExamples: It now looks certain that she will resign.
One thing is certain: she's not coming to my party.
How can we make certain that she sees the note?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I were you I'd choose the large school because it's certain that you'll find people [there] that think like you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a particular person or thing without naming or describing them
dictionaryExamples: The museum is only open at certain times of the day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last one I saw was called 'Spelling' and it was a kind of quiz where the competitors had to spell difficult words fast and finish at a certain time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used before a noun when it is difficult to describe something exactly or give its exact amount
dictionaryExamples: He's got a certain charm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was still that gleam and a certain kind of pride which let me assume once she must have been a strong lady. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to know something without doubt
dictionaryExamples: We don't know for certain whether she's coming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rules may be considered a bit too strict, the teaching methods too "old-fashioned", but I know for certain that this course gives very good preparation in [Busi]ness English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: used to emphasize something and show that there is no doubt about it
dictionaryExamples: I'll certainly be there.
They certainly deserved to win.
She certainly knew him but I don't know how close they were.
"Do you think more money should be given to education?" "Certainly!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't wear new clothes, you will certainly get dirty. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to agree politely to a request
dictionaryExamples: "Could you pass the salt, please?" "Certainly."

sense.def: used to strongly say “no,” or to emphasize that you know that something is not true or will not happen
dictionaryExamples: "Will you be taking her there?" "Certainly not!"
It’s certainly not surprising that he was upset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last, but certainly not least, is the malfunction that several exhibits experienced. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when you are completely sure about something
dictionaryExamples: I'm unable to answer that question with any certainty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can say with certainty that this town is just a treasure of Polish culture. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: something that is very likely to happen or cannot be doubted
dictionaryExamples: There are no absolute certainties in life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Book is a Hitchcockian sequence of chases, shaken certainties, mistaken identities, masquerades and escapes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an official document that gives details to show that something is true
dictionaryExamples: a birth/marriage/death certificate
a doctor's/medical certificate
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must have the PET certificate and you should speak another language. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a line of metal rings connected together
dictionaryExamples: a bicycle chain
She wore a gold chain around her neck.
The hostages were kept in chains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My best friend, Clara, gave me a silver chain. I like [it] a lot!!! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a number of similar stores, restaurants, etc. owned by the same company
dictionaryExamples: a chain of hotels/stores/supermarkets
a fast-food chain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These days children [have] grown up with McDonalds and other fast-food chains. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a series of things that happen one after the other
dictionaryExamples: a chain reaction
His arrival set off a surprising chain of events.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem began to increase because all her friends knew her secret. It was like a "chain reaction." First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a seat for one person, that has a back, usually four legs, and sometimes two arms
dictionaryExamples: He sat back in his chair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can sit on the chair outside and look [at the] bridge. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: something that is difficult and that tests someone's ability or determination
dictionaryExamples: Finding a solution to this problem is one of the greatest challenges faced by scientists today.
You know me - I like a challenge.
It's going to be a difficult job but I'm sure she'll rise to the challenge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went with two friends from school, we had a big adventure there and we had to face many challenges. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: an expression of disagreement with ideas, rules, or someone's authority
dictionaryExamples: a challenge to the authority of the President
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The one occasion in which Jack seems childish is when his challenge to Ralph's leadership fails and he weeps with humil[i]ation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to express disagreement with ideas, rules, or someone's authority
dictionaryExamples: Children challenge their parents' authority far more nowadays than they did in the past.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His daughter had just challenged him and he was struggling for a decision. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: difficult, in a way that tests your ability or determination
dictionaryExamples: This has been a challenging time for us all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like cavaliers we ride across the country looking for adventures and challenging activities. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: French white wine with lots of bubbles in it which people often drink to celebrate something
dictionaryExamples: We always celebrate our wedding anniversary with a bottle of champagne.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are listening [to] music, dancing, drinking champagne. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a person, animal, or team that wins a competition
dictionaryExamples: an Olympic champion
the division/league/World champions
She is the world champion for the third year in a row.
The defending champion plays his first match of this tournament tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week I played with a person who was the world chess champion! Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: someone who supports, defends, or fights for a person, belief, or principle
dictionaryExamples: a champion of human rights
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What this argument attempts to show is that too much emphasis on them, perhaps accelerated by commercial interests, has let them act as if they were the champions of personal virtues. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a competition to find the best team or player in a particular game or sport
dictionaryExamples: the national/world championships
He played professional golf and won both the British Open and the PGA  Championship.
He has been playing championship tennis for three years now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a sailing championship, in which I must participate. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the possibility that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: There's a chance (that) he'll still be there.
Does she have any chance of winning?
You'd have a better chance of passing your exams if you worked a bit harder.
There's a good chance (that) I'll have this essay finished by tomorrow.
