sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Is [there] any chance [of] borrow[ing] your bicycle? Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: the opportunity to do something
dictionaryExamples: I didn't get/have a chance to speak to her.
If you give me a chance to speak, I'll explain.
This trip is the chance  of a lifetime.
He left and I missed my chance to say goodbye to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you get a chance to learn to dance, you must do this because it [is] fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: when something happens because of luck, or without being planned
dictionaryExamples: I ran into  her by chance in the supermarket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By chance it was my camera. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a risk
dictionaryExamples: I'm delivering my work by hand. I'm not taking any chances.
There's a chance of injury in almost any sport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The chances of [having] an accident [on a] bicycle are bigger than [in a] car. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: it is likely
dictionaryExamples: Chances are that he'll refuse.
If we plan a picnic, the chances are that it'll rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was the case in London this summer, and with England's failing electricity system, chances are that this winter we will experience a similar situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to have a chance of success or of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t stand much of a chance in the election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only those who are open-minded and really intelligent stand a chance of survival as the disaster is of world-wide extent and there can be no aid for the victims. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to ask in a polite way whether something is possible or true
dictionaryExamples: You're not Spanish by any chance, are you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I pick up the phone "Hello, Nick have you by any chance got, or seen, my diary? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: used to emphasize that there is no possibility of something happening
dictionaryExamples: "Do you think she'd go out with me?" "No chance!"

sense.def: an equal and honest opportunity
dictionaryExamples: All he asks is a fair chance to prove his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then again, I think you have to give every job a fair chance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If you blow it or blow your chance, you lose an opportunity to do something by doing or saying the wrong thing.
dictionaryExamples: I blew it when I criticized the way she ran the office.
Tom blew his chances of getting the job by arriving late for the interview.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm giving you one last chance. If you blow it, you'll be sent to an Institution which treats people like you. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the leader of the government in some countries
dictionaryExamples: the German chancellor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides the point that our current government has become very much immovable during the last decade, Chancellor Kohl ought to know very well about Germany's historical development since he had passed his exam in history. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a person with a high rank in a government or university
dictionaryExamples: He became chancellor in 2010.
University faculty met with the chancellor to discuss their  concerns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [He] soon rose to be the First Secretary in the Department of Finance, directly under the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to stop having or using one thing, and start having or using another
dictionaryExamples: She's just changed jobs.
I hope they can change the time of my interview.
The doctor has recommended changing my diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I changed job last month, and now I'm working in [a] nursery. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: to become different, or to make someone or something become different
dictionaryExamples: The course changed my life.
I almost didn't recognize her - she'd changed so much.
That was twenty years ago and things have changed since then.
Nothing changes, does it - I've been away two years and the office still looks exactly the same.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My room doesn't change. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to take off your clothes and put on different ones
dictionaryExamples: You don't need to change - you look great as you are.
I'll just change into something a little fancier.
Give me five minutes to change out of my work clothes and I'll come out with you.
How often do you think he changes his shirt?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can change your clothes here. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to get off a train, bus, etc. and catch another in order to continue a journey
dictionaryExamples: I had to change planes twice to get here.
Take the express downtown and change to the L at Fourteenth Street.
You have to change trains in Albany for Boston.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the return flight from Los Angeles, I had to change plane[s] in Paris. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to get or give someone money in exchange for money of a different type
dictionaryExamples: Could you change a twenty for two tens?
I need to change my dollars for/into pounds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can I change money for US dollars there? First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to take something you have bought back to a store and exchange it for something else
dictionaryExamples: I had to change the shirt I bought for a bigger size.

sense.def: to form a new opinion or make a new decision that is different from your old one about something
dictionaryExamples: If you change your mind about coming tonight, just give me a call.
When I first met him I didn't like him but I've changed my mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the first lesson, I changed my mind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to start talking about a different subject
dictionaryExamples: I tried to explain, but he just changed the subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, changing the subject, I accidentally broke your beautiful vase. I'm really sorry, I'll try to find [another] vase that looks similar. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when something becomes different, or the result of something becoming different
dictionaryExamples: Let me know if there's any change in the situation.
We're living in a time of great change.
They've made a lot of changes to the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Really, this bedroom needs a big change. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you stop having or using one thing and start having or using another
dictionaryExamples: I've told the school about our change of address.
This country is ready for a change.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason for the change of class was mainly the teacher. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a set of clean clothes you can put on if you need to take off the ones you are wearing
dictionaryExamples: Make sure you bring a change of clothes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want you can bring an extra change of clothes so we can get wet. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the money which is returned to someone who has paid for something which costs less than the amount that they gave
dictionaryExamples: I think you've given me the wrong change.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I helped selling tickets and drinks and there I realized how bad my math is - I took such a long time to give back the change! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: money which is coins rather than notes
dictionaryExamples: She gave me $2 in change.
My dad always used to carry a lot of loose/small change  in his pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He asked me if I had any change. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something which is pleasant or interesting because it is unusual or new
dictionaryExamples: It's nice to see her smile for a change.
"Should we eat in the garden?" "Why not - it'll make a nice change."
We've always had a red car - it's time we had a change!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am planning to paint my room yellow now for a change! Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: If you have a change of heart, you change your opinion or feelings about something.
dictionaryExamples: At first he said he wouldn't help us, but he seems to have had a change of heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The narrator didn't tell her big secret to Inder Lal and after a change of heart she decides to keep the baby. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: often changing, or likely to change
dictionaryExamples: The weather was very changeable last summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must say that summers here are a bit mild and changeable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a television station
dictionaryExamples: a cable/broadcast channel
a music/movie/news/shopping/sports channel
the news on channel 4
She switched/turned to another channel to watch football.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Recently, I'm enjoying that Simpsons c[a]rtoon. I really love it and n[o]w it's on channel fifteen. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a way of communicating with people or getting something done
dictionaryExamples: a channel of communication
Please make your request through the proper channels.

sense.def: to use money or energy for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: We've channelled all our resources into this project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the same way that it shouldn't take the place of more important matters, there shouldn't be so much money channelled into it, especially when we want to see it as sport rather than business, and when there are so many other much fairer ends for that money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a state of total confusion with no order
dictionaryExamples: Snow and ice have caused chaos on the roads.
Ever since our secretary walked out, the office has been in a state of total chaos.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was chaos at the school. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: in a state of chaos
dictionaryExamples: a chaotic situation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Lawson House Hotel is situated 3km from Craniston village therefore you can expect a peaceful enviro[n]ment separated from the chaotic atmosphere of cities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: a small church, or a room used as a church in a building
dictionaryExamples: There is a small chapel on the grounds of the estate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On [one] occasion we were taken to a small chapel that was in such a state of dilapidation that it was not worth climb[ing] the stairs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: one of the parts that a book is divided into
dictionaryExamples: Read Chapter 3 before class tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I promise you that I will read chapter 10 of the book, and I will make a resume for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a person represented in a film, play or story
dictionaryExamples: The story revolves around three main characters.
She had Mickey Mouse or some other cartoon/Disney character on her sweater.
He made his name as a character actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is an action film w[h]ich [i]s full of fights. Its name is "Thai Chi."The main charactor is "Jet Lee." Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: the combination of qualities and personality that makes a person different from others
dictionaryExamples: Politeness is traditionally part of the British character.
It would be very out of character of her to lie.
One of the joys of being a parent is watching your child's character develop.
It's not in his character to be jealous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mary had a strong character and faced her uncle with great courage. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: qualities that are interesting or unusual
dictionaryExamples: a hotel with character
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There [are] many very old house[s] with a lot of character and charm, [which are] just perfect for a photographer. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an interesting or funny person whose behavior is different from most people's
dictionaryExamples: Your grandmother is a real character.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mr Brown is a great character. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a letter, sign, or number that you use when you are writing or printing
dictionaryExamples: Chinese characters
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, [the] poems are written in old Japanese characters which are difficult to understand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a particular kind of person
dictionaryExamples: an unpleasant character
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John was a gentle character, [rather] shy, but full of joy and happiness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a typical or noticeable quality of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Unfortunately a big nose is a family characteristic.
Sentimentality seems a characteristic of all the writers of that period.
The male bird displays several characteristics which distinguish him from the female.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Orwell gives the animals human characteristics and we can identify with them. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: typical of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Gray stone is characteristic of the buildings in that area.
With characteristic generosity, she offered to pay for us all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But to be honest, food is the only feature which will stay as a characteristic aspect of a country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to ask an amount of money for something, especially a service or activity
dictionaryExamples: How much/What do you charge for delivery?
The bank charged a commission to change my traveler's checks.
They charge you $20 just to get into the nightclub.
The local museum doesn't charge for admission.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Be careful while you are in Brazil because sometimes people charge really high prices for everything just because you are a tourist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If the police charge someone, they accuse them officially of a crime.
dictionaryExamples: She's been charged with murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While Jem is accused of [a] minor crime, Joss is charged with smuggling. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to attack someone or something by moving forward quickly
dictionaryExamples: The bull lowered its horns and charged.
The violence began when the police charged at a crowd of demonstrators.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had water bombs and water pistols at the ready. They started charging down the field towards the fire and once in range everyone th[r]ew their balloon as far as they could. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to put electricity into something
dictionaryExamples: I need to charge my cell phone - the battery is low.

sense.def: the amount of money that you have to pay for something, especially for an activity or service
dictionaryExamples: There's no charge for children under ten.
There's an admission charge.
They fixed my watch free of charge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is free of charge and will give me a idea of this sport. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be the person who has control of or is responsible for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She's in charge of a team of 20 people.
Who's in charge of organizing the music for the party?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I talk[ed] to the man who was in charge and [he] convince[d] me that it was safe, so I did it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to take control of or make yourself responsible for something
dictionaryExamples: I was happy to let her take charge of the travel arrangements.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am 21 years old which means that I can take charge of school children. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a formal police statement saying that someone is accused of a crime
dictionaryExamples: The 19-year-old will be appearing in court on Thursday where she will face criminal charges.
He has been arrested on a charge  of murder.
The district attorney brought charges against him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He decided on the spot that if Paul was to return all the money he wouldn't press charges so he called his parents and asked them to find out where he was. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a natural power which some people have to influence or attract people
dictionaryExamples: He is a respected politician but he lacks charisma.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I admire peop[l]e with heart and soul, with that real charisma which can only blossom in highly intelligent and spiritual people - this is what we call "intense personality." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: having a natural power to influence and attract people
dictionaryExamples: Her mother was a very charismatic woman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some charismatic people have a great influence on others, and they are highly respected or praised. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an official  organization that gives money, food, or help to people who need it, or money, food, or help that is given to people who need it
dictionaryExamples: UNICEF is an international charity.
She does a lot of work for charity.
She does a lot of charity work.
People tend to give to charity at Christmas time.
Money from the sale of these cards will go to local charities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the club, we do some charity work, helping people. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: kindness towards other people
dictionaryExamples: an act of charity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is undeniable that nowadays the whole world is suffering [from] the lack of good personalit[y] models to follow.  Models that [ar]e able to show the importance of charity, humility and other qualities so old-fashioned in our age. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a quality which makes you like or feel attracted to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a woman of great charm
The building has a certain charm.
I had to use all my charms to get them to lend us the hall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's an extremely severe and rugged sort of landscape with its own very special charm. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an object that you keep or wear because you believe that it is lucky
dictionaryExamples: a lucky charm
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently, "the treasures" I took there were nothing but all the little gifts and lucky charms I had received from my boyfriend and friends. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to attract someone or persuade someone to do something because of your charm
dictionaryExamples: We were charmed by his boyish manner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She arrived in time for the ball held that night, and everybody was charmed by her looks and manners. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: pleasant and attractive
dictionaryExamples: He's very charming.
It's a charming little village.

sense.def: a drawing which shows information in a simple way, often using lines and curves to show amounts

sense.def: an official list of the most popular songs each week

sense.def: to run after someone or something in order to catch them

sense.def: to try very hard to get something

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to have a conversation with someone who is online at the same time as you are by typing messages

blocks.phrasalVerb: chat sb up or chat up sb

sense.def: a friendly, informal conversation
dictionaryExamples: Give me a call and we'll have a chat sometime.

sense.def: liking to talk
dictionaryExamples: My sister is very chatty.

sense.def: costing little money or less than is usual or expected
dictionaryExamples: I got a cheap flight at the last minute.

sense.def: low in price and quality

sense.def: to put a mark  by something written to show it is correct or has been done

sense.def: to examine something to make sure it is correct or the way it should be

We checked out of our hotel at 5 a.m. to catch a 7
                             a.m. flight.

blocks.phrasalVerb: check sth out or check out sth

sense.def: to go to a place in order to see what it is like

sense.def: a mark (✓) put by something written to show it is correct or has been done

 Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: shaped like a circle
dictionaryExamples: a circular rug
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who congratulate the marrying [couple] take a circular sweet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: used to describe an argument which keeps returning to the same points and is not effective
dictionaryExamples: a circular argument/theory

sense.def: the movement of blood around your body
dictionaryExamples: Exercise improves your circulation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This [is] a very unhealthy habit, because we could have some problems with our circulation and also we could suffer from pains in the joints. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the number of copies of a newspaper or magazine that are sold each day, week, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The paper's circulation has fallen recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being on top of the media world is something that has required hard work and compet[e]nce and in a business where newspaper circulation depend[s] on the political profile of the paper, he is not afraid of making a comment [on] current affairs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a fact or event that makes a situation the way it is
dictionaryExamples: I think she coped very well under the circumstances.
The circumstances surrounding her death were suspicious.
We oppose capital punishment in all/under any circumstances.
Under no circumstances should you  approach the man.
The meeting has been cancelled due to circumstances beyond our control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will never forget the circumstances which brought us together. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a show in which a group of people and animals perform in a large tent
dictionaryExamples: a circus ring
The children loved being taken to the circus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the afternoon you can just go walking if you are not in a mood to do something exciting, but if are, you can go to the circus. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: someone who lives in a particular town or city
dictionaryExamples: The citizens of Moscow woke up this morning to find they had a new government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that it is a really good idea to make a film about our town and its citizens. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: someone who has a legal right to live in a particular country
dictionaryExamples: He applied to become an American citizen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm an American citizen because my mother comes from Queens, New York. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a large town
dictionaryExamples: the city of Boston
There's a huge park right in the center of the city.
Wellington is the capital city of New Zealand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I visit this city every year in June. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to the ordinary people or things in a country and not to military or religious organizations
dictionaryExamples: They married in a civil ceremony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The wedding will occur first in the church, and then in front of the Mayor, who will personally come [to] the castle for the civil wedding. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: someone who is not a member of a military organization or the police
dictionaryExamples: Several civilians were killed in the attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Twenty peple were killed in an ambush on a UN convoy transfer[r]ing injured civilians to the country's central hospital. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: human society with its well-developed social organizations, or the culture and way of life of a society or country at a particular period in time
dictionaryExamples: Some people think that nuclear war would mean the end of civilization.
Cuzco was the center of one of the world's most famous civilizations, that of the Incas.
ancient civilizations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since the beginning of civilization, man has been looking for co[m]fort and better ways to do things. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when people have an advanced and comfortable way of life
dictionaryExamples: modern civilization
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if this idea is idealistic, some think that they will take advantage of all the benefits of modern civilization. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: to say that something is true or is a fact, although you cannot prove it and other people might not believe it
dictionaryExamples: The company claims (that) it is not responsible for pollution of the river.
He claims to have met the President, but I don't believe him.
An unknown terrorist group has claimed responsibility for this morning's bomb attack.
All parties have claimed success in yesterday's elections.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people claim that keeping animals in zoos is cruel and unnecessary. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to ask for something because it belongs to you or  you think you have the right to have it
dictionaryExamples: She claimed $1,200 on her expense account.
Don't forget to claim your traveling expenses after the interview.
The number of people claiming unemployment benefits has risen sharply this month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also would like to claim [a] refund for the evening. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to say that you have done or achieved something
dictionaryExamples: No one has claimed responsibility for yesterday's bomb attack.

sense.def: a written request asking an organization to pay you a sum of money which you believe they owe you
dictionaryExamples: an insurance claim
a claim for compensation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This wasn't "my perfect evening out",  and I [would like to] make a claim for half the money back. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a statement that something is true or is a fact, although other people might not believe it
dictionaryExamples: She rejected claims that she had lied.
Can you give any evidence to support your claim?
He made wild claims about being able to cure cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To correct your claims about our target figure and the result of the day, I enclose a sheet displaying an income pie [chart]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to hit your hands together, often repeatedly, especially in order to show you enjoyed a performance
dictionaryExamples: The audience clapped and cheered for more.
"When I clap my hands, you must stand still," said the teacher.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every[thing] was nice till I clapped my hands to call the waiter to [get] the bill. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a sudden, loud sound that is made by thunder
dictionaryExamples: We heard a clap of thunder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, I heard a loud clap of thunder. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an explanation which makes something clearer or easier to understand
dictionaryExamples: Please contact this office again if you require further clarification.
Our lawyer has advised us to seek clarification on the matter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If any tricky questions come up you simply stay calm and ask for a clarification. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to make something easier to understand by explaining it
dictionaryExamples: The law aims to clarify building regulations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could you clarify this situation for me, please? International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: the quality of being clear and easy to understand
dictionaryExamples: She described the process with great clarity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jonathon, the eldest, is like his mother (and for that matter, like his father too!) a verbally very gifted person who already expresses himself with great clarity and a lot of understanding and afterthought as well as creativity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to fight or argue
dictionaryExamples: Government troops clashed with rebel soldiers.
Many young people clash with their parents over what time they must be home at night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the very beginning their two characters clashed and the relationship had only been deteriorating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If colors or styles clash, they do not look good together.
dictionaryExamples: You can't wear pink lipstick - it clashes with your dress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She wore lemon green trousers and a pink top and she didn't seem to mind that those colors clashed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: If two events clash, they happen at the same time so that you cannot go to them both.
dictionaryExamples: Emma's party clashes with my brother's wedding.

sense.def: a fight or argument
dictionaryExamples: There were violent clashes between the police and demonstrators.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, it has to be considered that Things fall apart is set in [the] 1890s and it portrays the clash between white colonialists and the indigenous Igbo people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: when ideas or qualities are very different, and this causes problems
dictionaryExamples: a clash of personalities
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since people's material interests are similar, having competitiveness as the only measurement for personal virtue only creates an endless competition that eventually will lead to a clash of interests. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a group of students who have lessons together
dictionaryExamples: Which class are you in this year?
She gave the whole class extra homework for a week.
My class was really noisy this morning.
Okay, class, settle down and open your books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have some friend[s] in the class. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Chinese

sense.def: a period of time in which students are taught something
dictionaryExamples: My last class ends at 4 o'clock.
I got in trouble for talking in class.
Who takes/teaches your environmental studies class?
I missed my aerobics class yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have one class a week w[ith] Miss Liz, she is my teacher. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: a group into which goods, services or people are put according to their standard
dictionaryExamples: first- class mail
a business/economy class ticket

sense.def: a group of people within society who have the same economic and social position
dictionaryExamples: The tax reforms are aimed at providing relief for the middle class.
upper-/middle-/lower- class people
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second film is called "Upper class first" and it describes how rich people live. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to put someone or something in a particular group according to their qualities
dictionaryExamples: The tower is classed as a historic monument.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All things considered, the [d]ay could be classed as a success. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: A classic book, film, etc. is one that has been popular for a long time and is considered to be of a high quality.
dictionaryExamples: a  classic film/novel/story
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am fond of reading different books, especially classic literature. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a piece of writing, a musical recording or a film which has been popular for a long time and is considered to be of a high quality
dictionaryExamples: Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is a classic of English literature.
Many of the Rolling Stones' records have become rock classics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wuthering Heights [is] a classic, which everybody knows about. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the process of putting people or things into groups by their type, size, etc., or one of these groups
dictionaryExamples: the classification of plants
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cinema attendance between 1990 and the present, with projections to 2010, is reported with the classification of four age groups: (i) 14-24 years old (ii) 25-34 years old (iii) 35-49 years old (iv) over 50 years old respectively. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to put people or things into groups by their type, size, etc.
dictionaryExamples: A third of the population has been classified as poor.
The books are classified by subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The paintings will be classified according to their subject and our guests will have the chance to see them and talk with the creators. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone who is in your class at school
dictionaryExamples: He went on a school trip with his classmates.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our classmates, Christine, Alice, Michael [and] Peter w[ere] there. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a room in a school or college where groups of students are taught
dictionaryExamples: The classrooms are large and have big windows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like my classroom [o]n the 2nd floor. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish

sense.def: a group of words containing a subject and a verb, that is usually only part of a sentence
dictionaryExamples: In the sentence "I can't cook very well but I can make a good omelette," both "I can't cook very well" and "I can make a good omelette" are main clauses.
In the sentence "I'll get you some stamps if I go to town," "if I go to town" is a subordinate clause.

sense.def: not dirty
dictionaryExamples: a clean white shirt
clean air/water
Make sure your hands are clean before you sit down to dinner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this place, because I have got a beautiful room. It is very clean and nice. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: showing that you have not done anything illegal
dictionaryExamples: a clean driving record
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, it is a strain to portray a clean image and avoid scandals. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to remove dirt from something
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to clean the windows this morning.
You should clean that scrape so it doesn't get infected.
He asked her to help him clean out the cupboards.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She clean[s] the house every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

blocks.phrasalVerb: clean sth out or clean out sth

sense.def: to take everything out of a room, car, container, etc. and clean the inside of it
dictionaryExamples: I cleaned out the fridge this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The owner, an almost illiterate woman, claimed to have come across the diary as she was cleaning out the attic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make something clean and neat
dictionaryExamples: You need  to clean up your room.
We'll clean this mess up before we leave.
I have to clean up before the guests arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I usually clean up my room once a week myself, and [the] cleaner does it on every Tuesday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to remove pollution from somewhere
dictionaryExamples: They are developing processes to clean up polluted rivers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can also help by distributing leaflets which contain information on how to start cleaning up the environment. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: someone whose job is to clean houses, offices, public places, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Our cleaner comes on Wednesdays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [am] working in Romford Abbey bank [as a] cleaner. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lithuanian

sense.def: a store where clothes are cleaned with chemicals
dictionaryExamples: I took my dress to the cleaner's.

sense.def: easy to understand, hear, read or see
dictionaryExamples: clear instructions/directions
Can we make the sound any clearer?
These photos are very clear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's clear and easy to use. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: If something is clear, you can see through it.
dictionaryExamples: clear glass
The water in the lake is so clear that you can see the bottom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I go to there every year, because the water of the lake is very clear and I like swimming in this lake. Key English Test; A2; Hungarian

sense.def: A clear sky does not have any clouds.
dictionaryExamples: clear blue skies
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we went to San Martin de los Andes, we could see seven lakes and different kinds of trees and the sky [was] always clear. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: certain or obvious
dictionaryExamples: Are you clear about how to get there?
It's clear that she's not interested.
I'm still not clear on what I'm supposed to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are you clear about the questions? Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: not covered or blocked by anything
dictionaryExamples: a clear road
a clear desk
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While banning the private cars brings with it less congestion, less air pollution and clear roads, it also carries major concerns [for] people's traveling needs. Should there not be a proper transport infrastructure in place in the city? International English Language Testing System; C2; Tamil

sense.def: extremely clear
dictionaryExamples: crystal clear water
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will be amazed by the crystal clear water of the shallow sea and the multitude of colourful fish which you will see as you [ar]e exploring the bottom of the sea. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: very easy to understand
dictionaryExamples: She made it crystal clear that she was in charge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They do learn something of course, but it is crystal clear that they need some help from you to develop their ability, creativity, sensitivity and so on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to remove all the objects or people from a place
dictionaryExamples: It took several hours to clear the road after the accident.
I'll make the coffee if you'll clear the table.
I cleared the snow off the path.
Could you clear your things from the couch?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cleared the stage before the concert, but you [ca]n't imagine how it looked after it?!!! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to get rid of bad feelings between two people or groups less
dictionaryExamples: It was an unpleasant argument, but at least it cleared the air.
The meeting Friday will help clear the air and clarify some issues that need to be addressed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I rushed into the room [to] cheer them up and clear the air, although I knew it was too late. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

blocks.phrasalVerb: clear sth away or clear away sth

sense.def: to make a place neat by removing things from it, or putting them where they should be
dictionaryExamples: We need to clear away  these tree branches that were knocked down in the storm
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After clearing away the worst mess, she opened the left drawer, and there it was! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrasalVerb: clear up sth or clear sth up

sense.def: to give an explanation for something, or to deal with a problem or argument
dictionaryExamples: Before we sign the contract, there are a few points we should clear up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope this will clear up your problem. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If the weather clears up, it improves and becomes sunny.
dictionaryExamples: I hope the weather clears up before this afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the first two days the weather was so bad that we couldn't reach the beach but finally the sky cleared up. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not in a difficult situation or having problems any more
dictionaryExamples: We had some large debts, but we should be in the clear by next year.
His lawyers say that Wilson is in the clear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "You're in the clear, you don't have to be afraid any more," it said. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to avoid someone or something because they are unpleasant or dangerous
dictionaryExamples: Steer clear of Tony this morning - he's in a bad mood.
Davis steered clear of politics because of all the problems his father had had as governor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eating healthy doesn't mean starving, eating plants or steering clear of meat. International English Language Testing System; C1; Latvian

sense.def: If you remain clear of something you stay away from or avoid it.
dictionaryExamples: Stand clear of the doors, please.
His parents warned him to keep clear of trouble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Especially young readers kept clear of the town library with its reputation of being a place for old people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: in a way that is easy to see, hear, read or understand
dictionaryExamples: He spoke very clearly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't see clearly without them. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: in a way that is not confused
dictionaryExamples: I'd had two hours' sleep and wasn't thinking clearly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I don't remember clearly. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show that you think something is obvious or certain
dictionaryExamples: The accident was clearly the truck driver's fault.
Clearly, he's very talented.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was clearly not for me, because it came from a girl called Carol who wanted to talk to some guy named John. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: effective and showing intelligence
dictionaryExamples: a clever idea
I've got a clever little gadget for opening jars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend told me that he saw [a] really nice loft bed. I think it's [a] clever idea. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: something that is said or done too often, so that it becomes boring or without meaning
dictionaryExamples: Her writing is full of clichés.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Prejudices and clichés are part of our state of mind, they travel with us [and] we won't avoid them by going abroad. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: said or done too often and therefore boring or without real meaning
dictionaryExamples: He made some clichéd remark about the birth of his first child completely changing his life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I do agree with this clichéd wording. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: to press on part of a computer mouse to make the computer do something
dictionaryExamples: If you want to open a file, click twice on the icon for it.
When you have selected the file you want, click "Open."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did click to e-mail and then the monitor color changed to black. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to suddenly understand something
dictionaryExamples: Suddenly everything clicked and I realized where I'd met him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now it all clicked into place... Those flimsy excuses he gave her: "No, this Saturday I can't make it." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to make a short, sharp sound, or to use something to make this sound
dictionaryExamples: The door clicked shut behind him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The back-door key clicked when I unlocked the door. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: If two people click, they like each other immediately.
dictionaryExamples: We met in college and we just clicked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She went to a house party and they met there. They clicked immediately and the next day they were calling each other. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a press on part of a computer mouse
dictionaryExamples: You can get the information with a single click.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could have written a letter in a bottle but waiting for the answer would take a decade, now it's just a click of a button. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: someone who pays someone else for services or advice
dictionaryExamples: We're losing a lot of our clients.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The mot[t]o of the staff there is: "the client is always right." First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a high area of rock with a very steep side, often on a coast
dictionaryExamples: Keep well away from the edge of the cliff.
the cliff edge
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This hotel is [on] a cliff, and has good [views]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the weather conditions that an area usually has
dictionaryExamples: a hot/dry/cold/wet climate
The Mediterranean climate is good for growing citrus fruits and grapes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The climate of Brazil is typically tropical so the weather is gorgeous. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the situation, feelings, and opinions that exist at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: the political/social climate
Terrorism creates a climate of fear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hence the Narrator lives in a more peaceful period than Olivia's and only in this context could Olivia's experiences be regarded as more stimulating because they are inevitably involved with the unstable political climate. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the way the Earth's weather is changing
dictionaryExamples: Climate change is the greatest environmental challenge facing the world today.

sense.def: to use your legs, or your legs and hands, to go up or onto the top of something
dictionaryExamples: climb a ladder/mountain/tree
He slowly climbed the stairs.
She climbed up on a chair to change the light bulb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is better if you can wear [a] T-shirt and short pants so it is easier to climb. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to move into or out of a small space, often with difficulty or effort
dictionaryExamples: The baby had managed to climb out of his crib.
They climbed into the truck and drove away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to my car, climbed into it and wanted to drive, but nothing happened. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to go up, or to go toward the top of something
dictionaryExamples: The plane climbed quickly to a height of 30,000 feet.
As it leaves the village, the road climbs steeply up the mountain.
The sun climbed higher in the sky.

sense.def: the sport of climbing mountains, hills or rocks
dictionaryExamples: rock/mountain climbing
We're going climbing in Scotland next weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are climbing and jogging. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: to hold someone or something tightly, especially because you are frightened
dictionaryExamples: She was found clinging to the ledge.
I clung on to his hand in the dark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [had] clung to my father ever since I was born. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to try very hard to keep something
dictionaryExamples: He clung to power for ten more years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thankfully, there are those who still cling to such age-old values as personal contentment and growth regarding them as the anchors which hold happiness fast. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a building, often part of a hospital, where people go for medical treatment or advice
dictionaryExamples: a health/medical clinic
Bring your baby to the clinic and we'll take a look at her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ahmed [was] traveling to attend a fair of medical equipment to get what he wants for his clinic. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: relating to medical treatment and tests
dictionaryExamples: clinical trials/research
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Doctors, for example, travel to get better qualifications, new medical skills and clinical experience. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: only considering facts and not influenced by feelings or emotions
dictionaryExamples: a clinical approach/attitude
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays in Sweden nurser[ie]s ("dagis") are common, but in the 1950s they were a new invention."Kindergarten" was the somewhat clinical name. And clinical they were. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a piece of equipment that shows you what time it is, usually in  a house  or on a building and not worn by a person
dictionaryExamples: I could hear the clock ticking.
The town hall clock says 9 o'clock.
I think the kitchen clock is fast/slow.
The clock began to strike twelve.
Did you set the alarm clock?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell a clock that is ten years old. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: all day and all night
dictionaryExamples: Rescue teams are working around the clock to search for survivors of the earthquake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is undeniable that people are working around the clock in order to earn a living. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If something closes, it moves so that it is not open, and if you close something, you make it move so that it is not open.
dictionaryExamples: Could you close the door/window please?
Close your eyes - I've got a surprise for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's [a] phone.  It's pink and you can open and close it. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: When a store, restaurant or public place closes, people cannot go into it.
dictionaryExamples: The banks had already closed.
The museum closes at 5:30.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well you have to be here in my house at 1pm, because the sports cent[e]r opens at 1:30pm and closes at 4pm. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: If a business or organization closes, or if someone or something closes it, it stops operating.
dictionaryExamples: The factory closed over ten years ago.
A lot of restaurants/stores are closing because they can't afford the rent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, I would like you to know that the Hotel Astrid closed last year. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to end, or to end something
dictionaryExamples: She closed the meeting with a short speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's how you should close the exhibition: with a question. How much further can Arnold go?  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a business or organization closes down or someone closes it down, it stops operating.
dictionaryExamples: All the mines in this area were closed down in the 80s.
Our local butcher is closing down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must tell you that unfortunately "Hotel Astrid" closed down last year. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to  gradually get nearer to someone, usually in order to attack them or stop them from escaping
dictionaryExamples: Police closed in on the demonstrators.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the [high]way so close by and all the industrial areas closing in on us, where are we to go? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

blocks.phrasalVerb: close off sth or close sth off

sense.def: to put something across the entrance to a place in order to keep people from entering it
dictionaryExamples: Police quickly closed off the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And while it is being buil[t], it will temporar[il]y cause even more problems for traffic, as some streets will be closed off. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: near in distance, position or time
dictionaryExamples: His house is close to the sea.
Don't get too close to the dog, Rosie.
It was close to lunchtime when we arrived.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's close to my house. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: describes people who know each other very well and like each other a lot, or who see and talk to each other a lot
dictionaryExamples: Mira is one of my closest friends.
Her relationship isn't good with her father, but she's very close to her mother.
My brother and I have become much closer over the years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That night, we had just my family and some of my close friends. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: A close relative is someone who is directly related to you, for example, your mother, father or brother.
dictionaryExamples: There weren't many people at the funeral - just close family/relatives.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tomson has [a] close family, his son lives with them, [and] his company makes a good profit. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: seeing or communicating with someone a lot
dictionaryExamples: I'm still in close contact with my school friends.
Our school has close links with a school in China.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being in close touch with me for such a long time, you should have known everything about the band. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: having only a small difference
dictionaryExamples: The election results were so close they had to vote again.
He came second in the race, but it was very close.
The youngest boys are so close in age they look like twins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The over-grazing, the deforestation and the over-cultivation [seem] to be the main causes of the degradation of the agricultural land, the percentages being quite close in value. International English Language Testing System; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to almost achieve or do something
dictionaryExamples: We are close to reaching an agreement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were very close to reaching our objective. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: If someone or something is close to a particular state, they are almost in that state.
dictionaryExamples: She was close to tears.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Do you love me?" "Of course I do. I've always loved you." Adrian answered. He was close to tears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: looking at or listening to someone or something very carefully
dictionaryExamples: On close inspection, you could see that the painting was a fake.
Keep a close watch on the children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the parents keep a close watch on their children's activities and friends and advi[s]e them what is right or wrong, this will prevent them from indulging in bad activities. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: near in distance
dictionaryExamples: Come a bit closer.
He stayed close to his mother.
There's a great beach close by.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Aunty told me that there is a Hindu temple close by. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: not open
dictionaryExamples: The door was closed.
Her eyes were closed so I thought she was asleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We arrived home very tired but the door was closed and my parents weren't there. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not open for business
dictionaryExamples: All the stores were closed, so we couldn't buy any food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He went to the school for his suitcase, but it was closed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not wanting to accept new ideas, people, customs, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a closed mind
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But if we travel with a closed mind, we will be contrasting everything, always having in mind that our things are the best. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: privately and not in public
dictionaryExamples: Most of the deals were done behind closed doors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: in a way that is directly connected or has a strong relationship
dictionaryExamples: English and German are closely related.
Both politicians have been closely associated with the movement for some time.
We are working closely with the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main reason I am applying for this job is that this job would be very rewarding on [a] personal level and would give me useful experience closely related to my field of study. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is very near in distance, time, or position
dictionaryExamples: Elke came into the room, closely followed by her children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to statistical figures, Germany is better off as compared to [the] USA and closely followed by Spain in the management of Government spending. International English Language Testing System; C1; Marathi

sense.def: carefully and paying attention to details
dictionaryExamples: Pollution levels are closely monitored.
If you look closely, you can see where he painted over his signature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that working for High Travel as its inte[r]preter would be a great experience if the company decides to look closely at the co[n]ditions of its employees and of its travelers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the state of being close in distance, time, or position
dictionaryExamples: We bought the house because of its closeness to my office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To resize and relocat[e] the coffee bar and the sauna are excellent [ideas] - a larger coffee bar provides us with a better relaxing area and the closeness of the sauna to the swimming pool saves us from walking a long way from the pool when we are all wet and cold. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the quality of knowing someone very well and liking them a lot
dictionaryExamples: A special closeness is said to exist between twins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fred resented the closeness of the sisters, he wanted Susan for himself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a usually small space with a door for storing clothes or other items
dictionaryExamples: a clothes/linen closet
I hung your jacket in the closet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bedroom has a walk-in closet, bi[g] enough to be a bedroom itself. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when a business, organization, etc. stops operating
dictionaryExamples: The bad weather caused many school closures in the area.
The company announced the closure of its Paris office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really hope that the closure of the art galler[y] is temporary and that every proper action will be taken so as to reopen it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: material made from cotton, wool, etc. and used, for example, to make clothes or curtains
dictionaryExamples: a piece of cloth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [will] probably be wearing dresses made of synthetic  cloth in 2100. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a small piece of material used for cleaning or drying things
dictionaryExamples: a wash/face cloth
a dish cloth

sense.def: items such as shirts, dresses and trousers that you wear on  your body
dictionaryExamples: She wears smart/casual clothes.
I'm just putting my clothes on.
Take your clothes off and get in the bath, Holly.
a clothes shop
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And she likes to wear new clothes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: clothes, especially of a particular type
dictionaryExamples: Protective clothing must be worn at all times.
You can only take three articles/items of clothing into the changing room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays the aim in clothing is not just for covering and protecting ourselves. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a white or gray mass in the sky, made of very small drops of water
dictionaryExamples: Do you think those are rain clouds on the horizon?
The sky was a perfect blue - not a cloud in sight.
Dark clouds gathered overhead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Except for the first day, the sun was with us all the time, with absolutely no cloud in the sky. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a mass of something such as dust or smoke that looks like a cloud
dictionaryExamples: A huge cloud of smoke from burning oil tanks stretched across the sky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them leave behind a large cloud of smoke and it damage[s] our health. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionaryExamples: When I heard I got the job, I was on cloud nine!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes," she was on cloud nine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to make someone confused, or make something harder to understand
dictionaryExamples: to cloud someone's judgment/vision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having their judgment somewhat clouded by hormones should not take precedence over all other concerns. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hebrew

sense.def: When it is cloudy, there are clouds in the sky.
dictionaryExamples: This morning was lovely but it's really cloudy out there now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is cold and the sky is always cloudy. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a performer who has special clothes and a painted face and makes people laugh
dictionaryExamples: a circus clown
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My dad hired a clown and a magician. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: an organization for people who want to take part in a sport or social activity together, or the building they use for this
dictionaryExamples: I've just joined the local golf/squash/tennis club.
a health and fitness club
Visitors must be accompanied by club members.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to visit the sport[s] club near your house. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a team of sports players
dictionaryExamples: the Washington soccer club D.C. United
the Rangers baseball club
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The club is Juventus and as you know, [it] is my favorite [soccer] team. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a place open late at night where people can dance
dictionaryExamples: After the show, we went to a club.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As regards the food, you can ask for any kind of food and after midnight it turns into a club where you can dance [to] any kind of music. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a sign or some information that helps you to solve a problem or answer a question
dictionaryExamples: Police are searching the area for clues to the murder.
Police are still looking for clues in their search for the missing girl.
I'm never going to guess the answer if you don't give me a clue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They found it and they started looking for more clues. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be completely unable to guess, understand, or deal with something
dictionaryExamples: I don't have a clue what you're talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I haven't a clue about it. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the quality of being clumsy
dictionaryExamples: The accident was caused by her clumsiness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I wanted to skip with her and the girls but my clumsiness made me [b]lush and I left the rope and returned to my boys' games. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: Clumsy people move in a way that is not controlled or careful enough, and often knock over or damage things.
dictionaryExamples: That's the third glass you've broken this week - you're so clumsy!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was cleaning the house, and as you know, I'm very clumsy, so I was dusting the table, and, accidentally, I dropped the vase. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to hold something tightly
dictionaryExamples: She clutched a coin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It doesn't matter if you want to be an author, an actress clutching an Oscar or a farmer with a lot of chickens. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the part of a car or truck that you press with your foot when you change gear
dictionaryExamples: I put my foot on the clutch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can remember very well when my father explained to me how to release the clutch and to press the accelerator very slowly and carefully: easy to say but... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: If you are in someone  or something's clutches, they control you, often in an evil way.
dictionaryExamples: Keep your children out of his clutches.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However one must admit that living longer and evading the clutches of death has always been one of man's dreams. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: someone whose job is to teach people to improve at a sport, skill, or school subject
dictionaryExamples: a tennis/math coach
The third-base coach waved the runner home and the Yankees won the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then the coach wanted to know some facts about me. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to teach someone so they improve at a sport, skill,  or a school subject
dictionaryExamples: She coaches students in French, usually for exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have also been coaching a girls team for 3 years. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: additional teaching of a sport, a skill or a school subject
dictionaryExamples: She has extra coaching in math.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Poland basketball is getting more and more popular and we feel the lack of coaching. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a hard, black substance that is dug from under the ground and burned as fuel
dictionaryExamples: a lump of coal
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mining for gold, coal or oil is an option [for] our economy. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: the land next to or close to the sea
dictionaryExamples: Rimini is a thriving holiday resort on the east coast of Italy.
The accident happened three miles off the coast.
The rail line runs along/down the California coast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's best to spend your time visiting our coast in the North East of Brazil. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: situated on, or relating to the coast
dictionaryExamples: a coastal town
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love to spend time at the beach and that is the reason why I live in a coastal area. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the part of the land along the edge of the sea
dictionaryExamples: a rocky coastline
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These buildings, which haven't been looked after and maintained for many years, give the coastline around Land's End an almost ghostlike atmosphere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: an outer piece of clothing with sleeves that is worn over other clothes, usually for warmth
dictionaryExamples: a warm winter coat
Button up your coat, Joe, or you'll freeze.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mary, I've left my new coat in your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a very large nut with a hard, hairy shell, a white part that you eat, and liquid in the center
dictionaryExamples: Thai food uses a lot of coconut.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I forgot to tell you that they have a special dessert with coconut and ice cream. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a large sea fish that can be eaten
dictionaryExamples: I think I'll have the cod.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest 'batatas com bacalhau', which is cooked cod served with boiled potatoes. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a system of words, letters or signs that is used to represent a message in secret form
dictionaryExamples: The message was written in code.
She managed to break/crack the code.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The purpose was to discover secret codes of the e[n]emy thanks to electronic intelligence. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a set of rules on how to behave or how to do things
dictionaryExamples: a code of conduct
The club has a strict dress code.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of their manners, dress code, personal conduct and their general well-being is taught at school. International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans

sense.def: a popular hot drink with a strong smell that is made from dark beans, or the beans or crushed beans from which this drink is made
dictionaryExamples: fresh/instant coffee
a cup of coffee
decaffeinated coffee
Would you like some coffee?
I'd like a black/regular coffee, please.
Do you take/like milk in your coffee?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like drinking coffee. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai

sense.def: a small restaurant where you can buy drinks and light meals, or a store that sells coffee drinks and snacks
dictionaryExamples: I'm just going to grab a sandwich at the coffee shop.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my free time I like to [go to the] Library or to the coffee shop with my friends. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: the state of being clear and easy to understand
dictionaryExamples: Her argument lacks any coherence.

sense.def: the feeling that you share the beliefs or purpose of others in a group
dictionaryExamples: There is no sense of coherence within the group.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Family gatherings can offer the individual a sense of warmth, of belonging and of coherence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: A coherent argument, plan, etc. is clear, and each part of it has been carefully considered.
dictionaryExamples: We need to put forward a coherent plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition to the achievement of high academic status and [a] coherent identity, young people have to make friends, have love affairs and abide by social rules. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If someone is coherent, you can understand what they say.
dictionaryExamples: She was so upset, she was barely coherent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once she was fairly calm, Anne tried to get a coherent story out of Louise, but Louise simply burst into tears afresh. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a small, flat, usually round piece of metal used as money
dictionaryExamples: a 10p/ten pence coin
a Canadian ten-cent coin
gold coins
The one dollar coin has never become popular.
He collects old coins.
I asked for ten dollars in coins.
The machine takes dollar coins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was an old coin that my granny gave me three years ago. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to be the first person who uses a new word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: The Czech playwright, Capek, coined the word "robot."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: S. Czernick coined a term for such type of poetry - authenticism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to happen at the same time as something else
dictionaryExamples: The band's American tour coincided with the release of their second album.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This moment is of great significance for both characters and it coincides with the event which happens in the house. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: When people's opinions or ideas coincide, they are the same.
dictionaryExamples: Luckily, our views coincided.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have become curious to know more about different cultures, I have learn[ed] to respect opinions which may not coincide with mine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: when two very similar things happen at the same time but there is no reason for it
dictionaryExamples: You chose exactly the same wallpaper as us - what a coincidence!
Just by coincidence I met my old friend and classmate again fifty years later.
It was pure coincidence that we met.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What a coincidence, don't you think so? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a sweet, dark-brown drink with a lot of bubbles
dictionaryExamples: We had a cola with lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can bring some cola. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: having a low temperature
dictionaryExamples: cold weather
a cold day
cold food/water
cold hands
My feet are so cold.

It's 
                      freezing cold today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like England because it is cold. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai

sense.def: unfriendly or showing no emotion
dictionaryExamples: She became cold and distant with me.
a cold stare/voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, I heard the same, cold voice behind me again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: in a cruel way, without showing any emotion
dictionaryExamples: He shot three policemen in cold blood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Returning to the story, when I arrived, I went directly to Hillton Avenue where I should have met 005, but when I arrived at the meeting point I found him lying on the floor with two shots in his back; he had been murdered in cold blood. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a common illness which makes you sneeze and makes your nose produce liquid
dictionaryExamples: I have/caught a cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard you caught a cold. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: cold weather or temperatures
dictionaryExamples: Don't stand out there in the cold - come in!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because of the cold, some days I had to use gloves. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If something makes your blood run cold, it frightens you very much.
dictionaryExamples: I heard a tapping on the window which made my blood run cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This thought scared me and made my blood run cold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: the state of having a low temperature
dictionaryExamples: I was distracted by the coldness of my feet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, there was an atmosphere of calm and happiness [a]round: the ground was covered with snow, so that it made your steps quiet and the whole town seemed asleep under its white coat; besides it was so cold that you could actually smell the coldness in the air and it made you feel strong... Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone is unfriendly or does not show their feelings
dictionaryExamples: I was shocked by his father's coldness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Contrary to this experience, I had experienced my mother's coldness through the other episode. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: When two or more people collaborate, they work together to create or achieve the same thing.
dictionaryExamples: Didn't you collaborate with him on one of your books?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if the staff they collaborated with were quite friendly and cheerful, all of them would prefer the jobs related with computers and new technolog[y]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: when two or more people work together to create or achieve the same thing, or a product of this
dictionaryExamples: The show was a result of collaboration between several museums.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, we encourage competition on the basis of team collaboration, to optimize the HR resources in the group, and maximize [the] individual's potential. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese
