sense.def: to fall down suddenly because of pressure or having no strength or support
dictionaryExamples: Thousands of buildings collapsed in the earthquake.
The chair collapsed under her weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then a sudden wave of fire made their heads explode and many buildings collapsed instantly. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If someone collapses, they fall down, usually because they are ill or weak.
dictionaryExamples: He collapsed and died of a heart attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He desperately tried to keep the stalking sharks at bay, but he couldn't succeed, for the long fight exhausted him and he collapsed. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to fail to work or succeed
dictionaryExamples: The peace talks have collapsed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, in the long run, the whole social system may collapse due to people's longer life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the sudden failure of a system, organization, business, etc.
dictionaryExamples: A poor economy has caused the collapse of thousands of small businesses.
Negotiations between the two countries are on the brink/verge of collapse.
He suffered a mental collapse after ten years' teaching.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After your nervous collapse last year I really worry about you. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the part of a shirt, coat, etc. that is usually folded over and goes round your neck
dictionaryExamples: a shirt collar
a fur collar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a new, fashionable one with [a] high collar and short sleeves. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a strap made of leather or other strong material which is put around the neck of an animal, especially a dog or cat
dictionaryExamples: a dog collar
I grabbed the dog by its collar and dragged it out of the room.

sense.def: someone who you work with
dictionaryExamples: We're having some colleagues of Ben's over tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need it for work and so that my colleagues can reach me. Key English Test; A2; Kannada

sense.def: to get and keep things of one type such as stamps or coins as a hobby
dictionaryExamples: She collects dolls.
So when did you start collecting antique glass?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to collect dolls, you know that already. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to get things from different places and bring them together
dictionaryExamples: Police collected a lot of information during the investigation.
I collected twenty bottles to be recycled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suzie will collect all the sheets, so I can do them at home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to ask people to give you money for something, for example a charity
dictionaryExamples: I'm collecting on behalf of Oxfam.
We're collecting (money) for the homeless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I think it's a perfect way to collect money for our poor people. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to get control over your feelings and thoughts
dictionaryExamples: I'll give you a moment to collect your thoughts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had [...] about 20 minutes so it would be plenty of time to collect my thoughts and calm down. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a group of objects of one type that have been collected by one person or in one place
dictionaryExamples: a private art collection
a valuable stamp collection
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to buy the DVD named "Lord of the Rings" because I like it very much and want to have it in my DVD collection.Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: a group of things or people
dictionaryExamples: There's quite a collection of toothbrushes in the bathroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [wear] long t-shirts and I have a collection of sweaters. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when something is taken away from a place
dictionaryExamples: garbage collection
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We need a different organi[z]ation for the waste collection. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: someone who collects objects because they are interesting or beautiful
dictionaryExamples: a collector of modern art
a stamp collector
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anne has been a collector for many years and she knows almost everything about Swedish stamps. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a place where students study at a high level to get a degree
dictionaryExamples: Where did you go to college?
She graduated from Oberlin College and is now working toward her PhD.
the College of Arts and Sciences at Columbia University
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was accepted at Brown University, a very prestigious college from the Ivy league. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: a word or phrase that sounds natural or correct when it is used with another word or phrase, or the combination formed when two or more words are frequently used together in a way that sounds natural
dictionaryExamples: "Heavy traffic" is a collocation.

sense.def: a mark (:) used before a list, an example, an explanation, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There's a colon missing in that sentence.

sense.def: red, blue, green, yellow, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She likes to wear bright colors.
What color are your eyes?
Does the shirt come in any other color?
Are the photos in color or black and white?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thin[k] the best color is light pink. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: with a very high score or with great success
dictionaryExamples: He passed the exam with flying colors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thr[o]u[gh] this, he was able to get his college degree and graduated with flying colors. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: interesting or exciting qualities or parts
dictionaryExamples: We'd like to include your story in the magazine this week for a bit of local color.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His brief contact with books gave his life a touch of intellectual color, but made it all the more unbearable when it was taken away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the color of a person's skin, when thought of as their race
dictionaryExamples: I don't care what color her friend is.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A group of slaves lead by Spartacus, dared to challenge the Roman empire, an empire that had conquered much of the known world, taking slaves from wherever they were or whatever their color. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make something a particular color
dictionaryExamples: He drew a heart and colored it red
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Robbie, I want to color my bedroom white. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to influence something or affect  what someone does, says, or feels
dictionaryExamples: The report is colored by the fiscal crises of the last four years.

sense.def: having bright colors
dictionaryExamples: a colorful painting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my country, people wear colorful clothes when they are getting married. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: interesting and unusual
dictionaryExamples: a colorful character
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, some flowerpots at the entrance would make this place more colorful. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: one of the blocks of print into which a page of a newspaper, magazine, or dictionary is divided
dictionaryExamples: I didn't have time to read the whole article - just the first column.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To the editor, I am puzzled by the report which appeared on yesterday's page 2, second column, concerning the Westfield Music Festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a tall, solid, usually stone post which is often used to support a roof or as decoration in a building
dictionaryExamples: The roof of the temple was held up by a row of thick stone columns.
Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a lot [of] columns outside and inside the restaurant, in Doric [style]. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: any block of numbers or words written one under the other
dictionaryExamples: the left-hand/right-hand column
Choose an adjective from Column A to use with a noun in Column B.
Put your expenditure in column B.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last column showed a total of 5523 individuals who lived for 100 or more years. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: a flat piece of plastic, wood or metal with a thin row of long narrow parts along one side, which you use to arrange your hair and make it neat
dictionaryExamples: Has anyone seen my black comb?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my comb in your house. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to use a comb to make your hair neat
dictionaryExamples: She combed her hair and put on some lipstick.
I've been trying to comb out the knots in her hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to buy [a] mirror for my room because I need to see myself while I'm combing my hair. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: a fight, especially during a war
dictionaryExamples: The aircraft was shot down in combat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Gaza is accessible only by car and because of the terrorists setting ambushes against any car, it is very difficult to supply the villages [a]round the combat zone with food and medication. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to try to stop something unpleasant or harmful from happening or increasing
dictionaryExamples: new measures to combat the rise in crime
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another way of combating the problem is to create recreational cent[e]rs in which unemployed people can spend their time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the mixture you get  when two or more things are combined
dictionaryExamples: Strawberries and cream - a perfect combination.
A combination of tiredness and boredom caused me to fall asleep.
This drug can be safely used in combination with other medicines.
Her experience and energy are a winning combination in business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is good combination of exercise and meditation. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to become mixed or joined, or to mix or join things together
dictionaryExamples: My wages combined with your savings should just about pay for it.
The band combines jazz rhythms and romantic lyrics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Boys wear jeans or longer shorts than girls, combined with patterned, cotton shirts. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to move or travel toward a person who is speaking or the place that they are speaking about
dictionaryExamples: Come here!
She's coming this afternoon.
Look out - there's a car coming!
Can you come to my party?
If you're ever in Chicago, come and visit us.
I came straight from the airport.
We have friends coming to stay this weekend.
The door opened and a nurse came into the room.
John  will come and pick you up at 4 o'clock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can come to dinner tomorrow at 7 o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to go somewhere with the person who is speaking
dictionaryExamples: Come with me.
Come for a walk with us.
Would you like to come with Sarah and me?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you come with me [to] my Friend's house [to] play game[s] tomorrow? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: to arrive somewhere
dictionaryExamples: Has she come yet?
When does the mail come?
Hasn't his train come in yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came [to] Dorchester, th[e] town was very pretty. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: to be available to buy in a particular color, size, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Do these slacks come in any other color?
This cuddly baby doll comes with her own blanket and bottle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's the latest digitalized model that comes with a remote control. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: to have or achieve a particular position in a race, competition, list, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She came second in the 100m race.
Z comes after Y in the alphabet.
Which president came after Jefferson?
April comes before May.

sense.def: If a dream or hope comes true, it really happens.
dictionaryExamples: I'd always dreamed of owning my own house, but I never thought it would come true.
After all the problems I'd had, Oliver's birth was a dream come true.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My dream of going to Spain came true. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to happen
dictionaryExamples: Spring has come early.
The worst problems are still/yet to come.
The announcement came at a bad time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But worse was yet to come! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to reach a state, or change to a different state
dictionaryExamples: I was sad when the evening came to an end.
I came to the conclusion that the relationship wasn't working.
That was when this administration came to power.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's why I came to the conclusion that the motorb[i]ke, together with anti-smog equipment, is the [only way] to get to work, unless you want [to] spend hours in a traffic jam. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to be very easy for someone
dictionaryExamples: Singing came naturally to Louise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a while, it came naturally: I could use words I had never seen written, just because I had picked them up in a conversation or watching a video program. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to be the most important person or thing
dictionaryExamples: Her career always comes first.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They do not take the time to sit down and enjoy being with their family. The work comes first, and the family next. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: If an idea comes to mind, you think of it.
dictionaryExamples: I was thinking about who might be suitable for this job, and your name came to mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main problem that comes to mind concerning transportation within the city is the city road network. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: when it comes to sth/doing sth

sense.def: used to introduce a new idea that you want to say something about
dictionaryExamples: When it comes to baking cakes, she's an expert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when it comes to computers, they just impose some knowledge on students, without any interaction. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: used to ask why or how something has happened
dictionaryExamples: How come you didn't go to the party?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Off the record: How come your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: used to say that you have just thought of something
dictionaryExamples: Come to think of it, I've got two batteries that you can have upstairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Come to think of it, it really is quite difficult to say. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to start to do something or to reach a state after a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I have come to rely on acupuncture.
This place has come to be known as 'Pheasant Corner.'
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the things she had been believing in until then had come to mean [no]thing, as gold turns into coal. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to become separated or removed from something
dictionaryExamples: The book came apart in my hands.
The handle came off.
My shoelaces have come undone.

sense.def: to start to exist
dictionaryExamples: When a volcano erupts underwater, a new island may come into being.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only with knowledge of the written word were villages able to organi[z]e themselves in larger forms of government, leading from local to regional to national levels, [and] finally leading to transnational structures as they came into being mostly during the last 100 years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If information about something bad comes to light, it is learned or discovered.
dictionaryExamples: She knew that the fraud would eventually come to light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, during the time they are in the forest, it comes to light that Edward is the weaker character. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be criticized
dictionaryExamples: The government has come under fire for closing the hospital.

sense.def: to help someone who is in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I forgot my purse but Anna came to the rescue and lent me some money.

sense.def: to deal with something as it happens, without planning for it
dictionaryExamples: With an illness like this you just have to take every day as it comes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should, for once, put our [jea]lousy aside, start to appr[e]ciate what we have and take life as it comes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to accept a sad situation
dictionaryExamples: He still hasn't come to terms with his brother's death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had, at last, come to terms with her loss and although she still, deep in her heart, grieved for Michael she now knew that she could move on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to understand and deal with a problem or situation
dictionaryExamples: It's a difficult subject to come to grips with.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, they are daily faced with tight schedules and they have to come to grips with the demanding work they have to prepare for school. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be useful at some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: Don't throw those jars away - they might come in handy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a washer and a dryer in the basement. I'm sure they'll come in handy with your new bundle of joy and the rest of your lovely bunch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something comes from the heart it is something you strongly feel or believe
dictionaryExamples: Her speech came from the heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is much more than that, it is something you feel proud of, which comes from the heart. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be developing or making progress
dictionaryExamples: Hassan's English is coming along well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To my delight she is coming along all right. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to be useful at some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: Don't throw those jars away - they might come in handy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a washer and a dryer in the basement. I'm sure they'll come in handy with your new bundle of joy and the rest of your lovely bunch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to happen or start to happen
dictionaryExamples: How did the idea for an arts festival come about?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Speaking of the past and its importance in our present, one cannot fail to observe that the very cumulative experience of a nation erects the foundation for our future.  How does that come about? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to seem to be a particular type of person or thing
dictionaryExamples: He came across as shy.
Her confident manner can sometimes come across as arrogance.
All these promises just come across as a meaningless political stunt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tom comes across as a lively as well as a reliable person. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: If an idea or emotion comes across, it is expressed clearly and people understand it.
dictionaryExamples: His bitterness comes across in his poetry.

sense.def: to meet someone or find something by chance
dictionaryExamples: He came across some of his old love letters in his wife's drawer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luckily, I've come across an advertisement of a well-known computer trader. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to go somewhere with someone
dictionaryExamples: We're going to the movies. Do you want to come along?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm really expecting you guys to come along. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to arrive or appear at a place
dictionaryExamples: A taxi never comes along when you need one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did not know what to do with it, and that moment my friend John came along. I told him what I had done and he told me that I could trust him with the ticket and that there was no need for me to take it home. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to start to exist
dictionaryExamples: I gave up mountain climbing when my first child came along.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A few years went past before the second child came along, by this time the family had just moved into a new house, so the mother decided to be a h[ouse]wife and a kind of "day-mother" for the neighbors' children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to change your opinion about something, or agree to an idea or a plan that you were against
dictionaryExamples: I know Maria doesn't like you borrowing her car but she'll soon come around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately, my parents finally came [a]round to my way of thinking and I am glad to say they are most supportive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to become conscious again after an accident or medical operation
dictionaryExamples: When he came around, he couldn't remember what had happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When he came [a]round, he was lying in a bed, surrounded by smiling women. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to return to a place
dictionaryExamples: I'll come back and pick you up in half an hour.
We've just come back from Mexico.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I['ll be] wait[ing] for your call, when you come back. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to harm the relationship between two or more people
dictionaryExamples: I won't let anything come between me and my children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, there was the problem of religion that came between us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to get something, especially something that is unusual or difficult to find
dictionaryExamples: Cheap organic food is still difficult to come by.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the world we live in today, jobs have become much more difficult to come by. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to drop to the ground or floor
dictionaryExamples: A lot of trees came down in the storm.
Our plane came down in a field.
We watched the building come down in a controlled explosion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luckily, the curtain came down and the play was postponed. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If a price or a level comes down, it becomes lower.
dictionaryExamples: House prices have come down recently.
Inflation is coming down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The GDP (Gross Domestic Product) has come down from 0.3% to 0.2%. International English Language Testing System; B2; Romanian

sense.def: If a situation, problem, decision, etc. comes down to something, then that is the thing that will influence it most.
dictionaryExamples: The success of the venture comes down to the commitment of those involved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the end, it all comes down to the question of job satisfaction. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: to become ill
dictionaryExamples: I feel like I'm coming down with a cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must apologize for writing so late, but my sister came down with [the] flu and I had to visit her. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to be born, gotten from, or made in a particular place
dictionaryExamples: She comes from Italy.
Where do you come from?
Some of the best wines come from France.
Does that quote come from Shakespeare?
She could hear banging coming from the room upstairs.
Where will the money for the project come from?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend's name is Niloo. She comes from Iran. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Farsi

sense.def: to enter a room or building
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to come in for a cup of tea?
Hi, come in - nice to see you!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He asked me if he could come in, and I said yes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to describe how someone is involved in a situation, story, or plan
dictionaryExamples: We need people to help clean up, and that's where you come in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another measure is to encourage people to do some forms of exercise and this is where health care practitioners come in. International English Language Testing System; C2; Yapese

sense.def: If someone comes in for criticism, praise, etc., they are criticized, praised, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He came in for a lot of criticism for his remarks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important part of this process, and one of extremely great importance for the exhibition, is that he had to endure prejudice and often came in for heavy criticism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to get money from someone who has died
dictionaryExamples: Just after I finished college, I came into a little money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even though one might jump to the conclusion that he probably came into a fortune when his father passed away after setting up a successful business, this is not the case. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to happen successfully
dictionaryExamples: His attempt to impress us all didn't quite come off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were some points in the schedule which frankly speaking didn't come off and the organization failed [in] some points as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to start to happen or work
dictionaryExamples: The heat comes on at six in the morning.
I feel like I've got a cold coming on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can now also do you[r] shopping on the internet, get in contact with your bank and talk to doctors if you feel an illness coming on. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: said to encourage someone to do something, especially to hurry or try harder
dictionaryExamples: Come on or we'll be late!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Come on, help me to find it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If a book, record, movie, etc. comes out, it becomes available for people to buy or see.
dictionaryExamples: When does their new album come out?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We're going to se[e] "Blade". It came out just yesterday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: When the sun, the moon, or a star comes out, it appears in the sky.
dictionaryExamples: It's really warm when the sun comes out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we were coming back, the sun came out. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If dirt or a mark comes out of something, it disappears when you clean it.
dictionaryExamples: Will this red wine stain come out?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the same time the sparkling, living and red-as-hell blood stain came out. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If results or information come out, they are given to people.
dictionaryExamples: Information about class placement will come out in August.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The results finally came out at the beginning of October. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to tell people that you are homosexual
dictionaryExamples: He hasn't come out to his family.

sense.def: If something that you say comes out in a particular way, you say it in that way.
dictionaryExamples: I wanted to tell her that I loved her, but it came out all wrong.

sense.def: to become known
dictionaryExamples: The truth about him will come out in the end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Murder thrillers are supposed to keep the reader in suspense right up to the last page when the truth unexpectedly comes out. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If something comes out of a process or event, it is one of the results.
dictionaryExamples: I hope something good can come out of this mess.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I ended up with something practically unnecessary to me.  But something positive came out of it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to come to a place, move from one place to another, or move towards someone
dictionaryExamples: Come over here and I'll do your hair for you.
Are your family coming over from Greece for the wedding?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recently moved to a new house, because my wife came over from Sri Lanka. International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese

sense.def: to seem to be a particular type of person
dictionaryExamples: Henry came over as a real enthusiast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He always comes over as very honest, and even though he is ambitious the way he promotes himself is much more subtle than usually seen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: If a feeling comes over you, you suddenly experience it.
dictionaryExamples: I don't usually get so angry. I don't know what came over me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is sometimes enough just to see a photograph of yourself shot 3 years ago and it comes to your mind, "What on earth came over me?!" Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If information, a result, or a document comes through, you receive it.
dictionaryExamples: Have the results of the tests come through yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the divorce had come through, they would have spent whole weekends together. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to manage to get to the end of a difficult or dangerous situation
dictionaryExamples: We've had some hard times, but we've come through them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those who have managed to come through all these hard years and got the desired medals expect now to be paid back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be a particular total when numbers or amounts are added together
dictionaryExamples: That comes to $50, please.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [If] a bill c[ame] to $1000, you would be shocked and regret what you had done. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to reach a state, or change to a different state
dictionaryExamples: I was sad when the evening came to an end.
I came to the conclusion that the relationship wasn't working.
That was when this administration came to power.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's why I came to the conclusion that the motorb[i]ke, together with anti-smog equipment, is the [only way] to get to work, unless you want [to] spend hours in a traffic jam. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to be in a particular part of a book, list, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Hairdressers come under "beauty salons" in the Yellow Pages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Qui[te] a few, it seems, opted to go for places where they had previously worked. 17% from Education, 5% from Arts and [S]cience and 3% from the Science Stream, come under this category. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: to experience something, often something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: We came under a lot of pressure to leave the area.
They have come under criticism from local campaigners.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This opinion is true in a sense but it also depends on how kids are brought up and what influences they came under. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to move toward someone
dictionaryExamples: A young girl came up to me and asked for money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A tall slim Soc came up and said:- "I will, Daryl old bud." It was James, Daryl's old school friend. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be mentioned or talked about in conversation
dictionaryExamples: What points came up at the meeting?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From time to time the discussion about keeping animals in zoos comes up. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: When the sun or moon comes up, it rises.
dictionaryExamples: We watched the sun come up over the ocean.

sense.def: If a job or opportunity comes up, it becomes available.
dictionaryExamples: If some work comes up, you should take it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am delighted to help and advise you about the three proposals that have just come up. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to be happening soon
dictionaryExamples: Final exams are coming up next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A holiday is coming up next month so it would be great if you could come sometime between Wednesday 27th to Saturday 30th. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If a problem or difficult situation comes up, it happens.
dictionaryExamples: Sorry I'm late - a problem came up with my schedule.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found it very useful that I did not have to write or read, and if a problem came up I just called the qualified teacher. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If information comes up on a computer screen, it appears there.
dictionaryExamples: The images came up on the screen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The photo instantly comes up on the screen of the computer and you can enjoy the game with the photo. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to have to deal with a problem or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: She came up against a lot of sexism in her first engineering job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is essential to get along well with your partners, otherwise you may come up against many problems, such as a loss of motivation, or even the risk of being fired. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to suggest or think of an idea or plan
dictionaryExamples: She's come up with some amazing scheme to double her income.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Together with my teacher we came up with the idea of asking you to come to the college in order to give a talk about your latest book and about the experiences you have had as a novelist. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a successful attempt to become powerful, important, or famous again
dictionaryExamples: She's made a comeback with her first new album in twenty years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He made a comeback and what a comeback! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who entertains people by telling jokes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, he went to London to become a comedian and now he is one of the [most] famous stars [in] that field. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: entertainment such as a film, play, etc. which is funny
dictionaryExamples: His latest film is described as a romantic comedy.
I prefer Shakespeare's comedies to his tragedies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody agreed to see that comedy with Jim Carrey and I know that you would like it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: a pleasant feeling of being relaxed and free from pain
dictionaryExamples: She evidently dresses for comfort.
It's a little too hot for comfort.
Now you can watch the latest movies in the comfort of your own room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the weather is bad, I need the comfort of my car. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something that makes your life easy and pleasant
dictionaryExamples: the  comforts of home
Good chocolate is one of life's little comforts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Have you ever thought how our grandparents lived [in] their villages without extra home comforts? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when you have a pleasant life with enough money for everything that you need
dictionaryExamples: He can afford to retire and live in comfort for the rest of his life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even when people sympathi[z]e with them, they always bear in mind that they are often rich children, who live in comfort. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when you feel better after being worried or sad
dictionaryExamples: What she said brought me great comfort.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I had been a "bad boy" and rec[ei]ved a spanking I would seek comfort in my brothers or sister and they would do the same. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to make someone feel better when they are anxious or sad
dictionaryExamples: The family of the dead are being comforted by friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He kept close to Sandra and comforted her, saying this was the only choice they had and that things would be fine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: describes furniture,  clothes, etc. that provide a pleasant feeling and that do not give you any pain
dictionaryExamples: a comfortable bed/sofa
comfortable shoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should wear a T-shirt because it's comfortable to paint [in]. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: relaxed and free from pain
dictionaryExamples: Are you comfortable perched on that seat?
I don't feel comfortable in high heels.
Please sit down and make yourself comfortable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when she started the lesson, everybody was comfortable and relaxed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: If you are comfortable in a situation, you do not have any worries about it.
dictionaryExamples: I don't feel comfortable about leaving the children here alone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those children maybe they don't feel comfortable away from home. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: having enough money for everything that you need
dictionaryExamples: a comfortable retirement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Certainly, there are part-time jobs, but they are mostly not [so] well-paid that it would be enough for somebody to lead a comfortable life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: in a comfortable way
dictionaryExamples: We slept very comfortably that night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was sitting comfortably on the couch watching TV when suddenly all the lights went out, [and] everything became silent. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: making you feel better when you are anxious or sad
dictionaryExamples: He said a few comforting words.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, it is always very comforting to know that someone has the same or even worse problems than we do. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a magazine with stories told in pictures
dictionaryExamples: As a boy I used to love reading comics.
a comic book
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are play[ing] basketball and read[ing] comics. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: funny
dictionaryExamples: a comic actor/performance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's a bit long for a comic film (3 hours!!) but it's very [funny]: you must see it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a mark (,) used to separate parts of a sentence, or to separate the items in a list
dictionaryExamples: Put a comma before his name.

sense.def: an order to do something, especially one given by a soldier
dictionaryExamples: He hated being in the army because he had to obey commands.
When I give the command, fire!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Under the red lights of his command room, the first question that the captain wanted to a[sk] was to know if the boat was safe. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: knowledge of a subject, especially a language
dictionaryExamples: She had a good command of Italian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, I have a good command of French and I speak English fluently, which might be useful during the voyage around the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an instruction to a computer
dictionaryExamples: It's worth learning the shortcuts for some of these commands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Program list. 1. System commands  MAIN console programs. 2. Review of LINUX Sys. console  3. Server commands. 4. ADD ONs for LINUX OS. 5. LINUX INTERFACE. 6. USER PROFILE. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: control over someone or something and responsibility for them
dictionaryExamples: The soldiers were under the command of a tough sergeant-major.
Jones was in command.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, [there] comes an insurrection of armed militia with generals in command. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an officer who is in charge of a military operation, or an officer of middle rank in the navy
dictionaryExamples: He was a naval commander.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best part is when the commander forces the troops to kill themselves to prove their loyalty. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to do something to show you remember an important person or event in the past with respect
dictionaryExamples: a ceremony to commemorate the battle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  As requested I am submitting the following proposal in order to recommend Melina Merkouri as a famous person whose achievements should be commemorated. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to begin something
dictionaryExamples: Building work will commence in the fall.
Shall we let the meeting commence?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Equip[p]ed with their cheap DV cameras, collaborating with young enthusiast[s] they strive to show what is worrying Poles and manage to commence a national discussion Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: something that you say or write that expresses your opinion
dictionaryExamples: I don't want any comments about my new haircut!
Tell us what you think - go to our web page and post/leave/add a comment.
He made negative comments to the press.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Write me a comment. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to say that you do not want to answer someone's question
dictionaryExamples: "Will you be running for Congress?" "No comment."

sense.def: to make a comment
dictionaryExamples: My mom always comments on what I'm wearing.
He commented that the two essays were very similar.
The official refused to comment on the matter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will only comment on some points, the others may be viewed as agreed upon. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the activities involved in buying and selling things
dictionaryExamples: the world of commerce and industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the old days, when the only mean[s] of transport were horses, there were many difficulties in communication between people, in commerce, [and] in life generally. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an advertisement on the radio, on television, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I turn the sound  off during the commercials.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't watch tv because of the commercials. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: related to buying and selling things
dictionaryExamples: a commercial organization/success
The commercial future of the company looks very promising.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, as long as their private life is interesting for ordinary people and it brings commercial gain to publishers, journalists and photographers, famous people will just have to get use[d] to this living "under a microscope". First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: making money from advertising
dictionaryExamples: commercial television
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These days, in all commercial television, they show advertisement[s] in every hour of the day. International English Language Testing System; C2; Bengali

sense.def: to do something that is considered wrong, or that is illegal
dictionaryExamples: He was sent to prison for a crime that he didn't commit.
to commit suicide
to commit a crime/an offense/murder
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is willing to be [a] witness for the prosecution and states that her husband [was] not with her at the time the crime was committed. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to make a firm decision that you will do something
dictionaryExamples: He committed himself to helping others.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Doctor Gregorio Alvarez was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina in the early 1910s and graduated as a doctor at an early age. [...] He worked his entire life [in] the public hospital in Neuquen, which was the most developed city at that time, but he committed himself to exploration on a permanent basis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when you are willing to give your time and energy to something that you believe in, or a promise or firm decision to do something
dictionaryExamples: She is known primarily for her commitment to human rights.
I'd like to thank the staff for having shown such commitment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really admire your stamina, your commitment and your eagerness to pursue a career as one of the youngest vice presidents ever in the company (and the only female I guess), but is it really worth it? First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: something that you must do or deal with that takes your time
dictionaryExamples: family/work commitments
I've got too many commitments right now to take an evening class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please tell me also the terms of [the] possible job so I can plan my future work commitments. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: loyal and willing to give your time and energy to something that you believe in
dictionaryExamples: a committed marathon runner
She's committed to the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, Mr. Schmidt is a very committed and hard-working person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a small group of people chosen to represent a larger organization and either make decisions or collect information for it
dictionaryExamples: She's on the school's development committee.
The city council just set up a committee to study recycling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm pleased to help and to present these films to the club committee. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a product that you can buy or sell
dictionaryExamples: The country's most valuable commodities include tin and diamonds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not just that, it will have a domino effect on prime commodities as well. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: happening often or existing in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: It's quite common to see couples who dress alike.
Is "Smith" really a common name?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The city is so noisy and it's possible that you [will] get lost, it's very common. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: belonging to or shared by two or more people or things
dictionaryExamples: a common goal/interest
English has some features common to many languages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I invited her to dinner for all her trouble and we found out that we have a lot of common interests. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: something that a lot of people know
dictionaryExamples: It's common knowledge that he spent time in jail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is common knowledge that such attention [in the mass-media] inevitably tells on relationships in the family. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to share, interests, experiences, or other characteristics with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Sue and I don't have much in common.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We both like to read fantasy books so we have a lot in common. Preliminary English Test; B1; Albanian

sense.def: often or usually
dictionaryExamples: These caterpillars are commonly found on bean plants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, fast food and microwave food are commonly eaten by the British. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the natural ability to be practical and to make good decisions
dictionaryExamples: The children shouldn't be in any danger as long as they use their common sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact she is very nice, funny, [and] full of common sense. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to share information with others by speaking, writing, moving your body or using other signals
dictionaryExamples: We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.
Has the news been communicated to the staff yet?
Unable to speak a word of the language, he communicated with his hands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I decided to join a new English class in order to improve my English because [a] few weeks ago I met someone who is really interesting, so I would like to be able to communicate properly with him. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to be understood by someone when you tell them about your feelings and thoughts
dictionaryExamples: He can't communicate with his parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I can communicate with children and make them happy. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the act of communicating with people
dictionaryExamples: Television is an increasingly important means of communication.
We are in direct communication with Moscow.
With an hour's walk to the nearest telephone, communication is difficult.
There's very little communication between mother and daughter.
a course on communication skills
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Communication [by] e-mail is very fast and very cheap. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: open and willing to talk to people
dictionaryExamples: She's never very communicative in the morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I would like to say I am a very communicative person and I enjoy being surrounded by many people. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: the people living in one particular area
dictionaryExamples: a rural/small community
He's well-known in the local community.
Drug trafficking is a matter of considerable concern for the entire international community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He supported some projects in our community. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a group of people with the same interests, way of life, nationality, job, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the black/white/Chinese/Jewish community
the business community
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a member of our academic community, and a representative of [the] student's senate, I'm very glad to hear that our college will have a surplus in its annual budget. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to regularly travel between work and home
dictionaryExamples: He commutes to Boston every day.
My aunt commutes into the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who work in the [city] cent[e]r will have to commute from the suburbs which will be a waste of time for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: someone you spend a lot of time with or go somewhere with
dictionaryExamples: a traveling companion
Dan has been her constant companion these past ten years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jane and her companion felt absolutely foolish and muttered something about a wrong address. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an organization that sells goods or services in order to make money
dictionaryExamples: He works for a software company/a company that makes software.
I work for Duggan and Company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nokia is a famous company as you know. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: when you are with a person or people, or the person or people you are with
dictionaryExamples: I just enjoy his company.
Do you want company or would you rather go by yourself?
I didn't realize you had company.
Margot came to stay for a week as company for my mother while I was away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately a friend of mine came with me for company. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to stay with someone so that they are not alone
dictionaryExamples: Come and keep me company, Isabel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually I went with him to keep him company and because I liked it. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to be a pleasant or interesting person to spend time with
dictionaryExamples: Ann and Charles are always good company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a bit narrow-minded and at first he'll drive you crazy, but once you get to know him he'll be good company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: similar in size, amount, or quality to something else
dictionaryExamples: Our prices are comparable to those in other stores.
The two experiences are not comparable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Recent surveys revealed that the gap in salary between men and women doing comparable jobs increased within the last years. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses a difference in amount, in number, in degree or quality
dictionaryExamples: "Fatter" is the comparative of "fat."
"More difficult" is the comparative of "difficult."

sense.def: comparing similar things
dictionaryExamples: a comparative study of two poems
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a comparative study we see [the] work force is increasing in Japan, whereas it is declining in U.S. International English Language Testing System; C1; Bihari

sense.def: a situation which is comfortable/free/silent, etc. when compared to another situation or to what is usual
dictionaryExamples: I enjoyed the comparative calm of his apartment after the busy office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Uruguay has exploited its comparative advantages orienting its economy towards tourism, whereas Argentina has made use of the river to promote the export of domestic products.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to examine the ways in which two people or things are different
dictionaryExamples: If you compare house prices in the two areas, it's surprising how different they are.
That seems expensive - have you compared prices in other stores?
Compare some recent work with your older stuff and you'll see how much you've improved.
Teachers always used to compare me with my sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our lives are so different, it's interesting to compare. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used when saying how one person or thing is different from another
dictionaryExamples: This street is very busy compared to ours.
Children seem to learn more interesting things compared with when we were in school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To my surprise it was very cheap compared with other restaurants. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: If two people compare notes, they tell each other what they think about something that they have both done.
dictionaryExamples: We compared notes about our experiences in China.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, regular meetings between parents and school teachers [...] help both parties to compare notes, acting in the best interest[s] of the children. International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese

sense.def: when two or more people or things are compared
dictionaryExamples: They made a comparison of different countries' eating habits.
By/In comparison with the French, the British eat far less fish.
I always drink fresh coffee, not instant.  There's no comparison.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays we can see a very different world from the one our grandparents were living in. Whereas they used to talk about how their daily life had changed in comparison with previous generations', we remain astonished [at]  how our li[v]es are changing frenetically. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: compatible equipment can be used together
dictionaryExamples: This keyboard is compatible with all of our computers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually it is compatible with the newest 3DFX technology, which gives [an] extremely realistic [look] and the possibility to interact with the game. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If people are compatible, they like each other and are happy to spend time together.
dictionaryExamples: After they got married, they soon found out that they weren't compatible.
My new job's going well, and my colleagues seem to be compatible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The personalities of my parents were very different but at the same time they were a very compatible couple. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: compatible ideas or situations can exist together
dictionaryExamples: Such policies are not compatible with democratic government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My aim here is not to criticize this point of view but to show it is hardly compatible with the idea of giving work less importance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to pay someone money because you are responsible for injuring them or damaging something
dictionaryExamples: Victims of the crash will be compensated for their injuries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to be compensated for the extra work I have done to please the guests from the last stay. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to reduce the bad effect of something, or make something bad become something good
dictionaryExamples: Nothing will ever compensate for his lost childhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yet, it seems obvious that money cannot compensate for [a] lack of affection. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to take part in a race or competition
dictionaryExamples: She's competing for a spot on next year's Olympic team.
Are you competing in the 100 metres?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's gonna be a competition and I want to compete, but you know that my bicycle is a mess and very old. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to try to be more successful than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: It's difficult for a small grocery store to compete against/with the big supermarkets.
The girls compete for their father's attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had to compete with twelve other writers. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the ability to do something well
dictionaryExamples: Her competence as a teacher is unquestionable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This report aims to outline the present state of our library's archives as well as to recommend another book or newspaper for those interested in improving their competence in Greek. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: able to do something well
dictionaryExamples: a competent teacher/swimmer
I wouldn't say he was particularly special, but he is competent at his job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the game develops, the creatures and tasks get more and more complicated and by the end of the game, you will be expected to become a competent shooter. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: an organized event in which people try to win a prize by being the best, fastest, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a swimming/chess competition
She's entered a crossword competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm in Australia. I have [just] seen a surf competition that was very exciting. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: when someone, or a company, is trying to win something or be more successful than someone else
dictionaryExamples: Competition for jobs is intense.
There's a lot of competition between computer companies.
The two companies are in competition with each other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Different opening times mean[s] competition between the shops. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: involving competition
dictionaryExamples: competitive sports
a highly competitive industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays people live in [a] very competitive society. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: wanting very much to win or be more successful than other people
dictionaryExamples: She's very competitive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I am a very competitive player. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: as good as or better than other prices, services, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They offer high quality merchandise at competitive prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stayed at Riverside Hotel w[h]ich [is] great value because of the food and the competitive prices they offer. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a person, team or company that is competing against others
dictionaryExamples: How many competitors took part in the race?
Their prices are better than any of their competitors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last one I saw was called 'Spelling' and it was a kind of quiz where the competitors had to spell difficult words fast and finish at a certain time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to collect information and arrange it in a book, report, list, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We're compiling some facts and figures for a documentary on climate change.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this report is to compile the findings and thereby outline the main reasons why our branch did not get the contract, in order to prevent future failures. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to say that something is wrong or that you are annoyed about something
dictionaryExamples: Lots of people have complained about the noise.
He's always complaining!
He complained that she never listened to him.
If the service was so bad why didn't you complain to the manager?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we are bad, they complain to our manager or they tell the head office. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to tell other people that something is making you feel ill
dictionaryExamples: She's been complaining of a headache all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I asked her if he [had] complained of any pains or aches? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when someone says that something is wrong or not satisfactory
dictionaryExamples: We've received a complaint from one of our listeners about offensive language.
I've made a complaint to the police about the noise.
We've had complaints that you've been playing your radio too loud.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you give my complaint serious consideration and I would be very pleased if you would print a correction in the next issue of your magazine. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: something that makes you complain
dictionaryExamples: My only complaint was the lack of refreshments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of their complaints is the absence of variety of options for vegetarians. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to provide the last part needed to make something whole
dictionaryExamples: Complete the sentence with one of the adjectives provided.
He only needs two more cards to complete the set.
All she needed to complete her happiness was a baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will buy episode III [as] it is the only one that I need to complete my collection. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to write all the details asked for on a form or other document
dictionaryExamples: Have you completed your application form yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes we complete the forms and talk. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Others

sense.def: to finish doing or making something
dictionaryExamples: The palace took over twenty years to complete.
She will complete her studies in France.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need this paper to complete my grade. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: very great or to the largest degree possible
dictionaryExamples: It was a complete waste of time.
He's a complete idiot!
I made a complete and utter mess of it!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a complete disaster! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: with all the parts
dictionaryExamples: the complete works of Oscar Wilde
The report comes complete with diagrams and color photographs.
Sun, sand and romance - her vacation was complete.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can send you [a] complete map.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in every way or as much as possible
dictionaryExamples: I completely forgot I'd said I would call him.
He'd completely changed and I didn't recognize him.
I agree with you completely.
She's completely insane!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the middle of the journey there was one of [those] summer rain [showers] and we got completely wet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: when something that you are doing or making is finished
dictionaryExamples: The stadium is due for completion in 2016.
They will be paid on completion of the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the completion of the work at the newly-built part of the airport and its opening for service, the formerly quiet part of the town has become a victim of the above mentioned kind of noise, even more than the parts which have had this problem for [a] long [time]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: involving a lot of different but connected parts in a way that is difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: a complex network of roads
a complex procedure
The movie's plot was so complex that I couldn't follow it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It took us two weeks to modify the results in a very complex operation. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a group of buildings or rooms that are used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a sports/housing/apartment complex
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A visit to any local shopping complex suggest[s] people between 14 to 35 years of age are the [most] frequent shoppers. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malay

sense.def: a mental problem which makes someone anxious or frightened about something
dictionaryExamples: an inferiority complex
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He began to feel like that character in "Psycho", afraid that the hotel manager would turn out to be some kind of maniac with an Oedipus complex. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the color and appearance of the skin on someone's face
dictionaryExamples: a clear complexion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had a fair complexion framed with red hair which reminded me of a witch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: when something is complex
dictionaryExamples: a problem of great complexity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will this system of planting and exploiting new values, styles and icons actually collapse under its own weight and complexity? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to make something more difficult to deal with or understand
dictionaryExamples: These new regulations just complicate matters further.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend, I hope I didn't complicate things for you with my appraisal of the situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: involving a lot of different parts, in a way that is difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: complicated instructions
I had to fill in this really complicated form.
The rules are rather complicated to follow.
The relationship is a bit complicated. He's my mother's cousin's daughter's child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Life is getting easier but more complicated - I could have written a letter in a bottle but waiting for the answer would take a decade, now it's just a click of a button. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: something which makes a situation more difficult
dictionaryExamples: We want to sign the contract, but there are several complications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you have already correctly mentioned in your memorandum, we indeed face some complications in our resort. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: a new medical problem that develops when you are already ill
dictionaryExamples: Eye problems can be a complication of diabetes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Disregarding recommendations given by nutrition experts can pose a great threat to our longevity, namely because of cardio-vascular complications. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something that you say or do to show praise or admiration for someone
dictionaryExamples: Thank you for the  compliment, but many people helped me along the way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I take that as a compliment, giving me hope to excel as well as he did. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to tell someone that you admire something about them
dictionaryExamples: He paid her several compliments about her painting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His companions always pay him compliments on his [piano] playing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
dictionaryExamples: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh ras[p]berries before finishing his/her meal with a rose lique[u]r - with the compliments of the house (and the bill). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to praise or express admiration for someone
dictionaryExamples: He complimented me on my writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, I must compliment you on lowering your prices and adding new destinations to choose from. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: praising or expressing admiration for someone
dictionaryExamples: a complimentary report

sense.def: given free, especially by a business
dictionaryExamples: a complimentary glass of wine
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It may be easy to obtain complimentary copies from publishers without any cost to the library. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to obey an order, rule, or request
dictionaryExamples: The pilot complied with instructions to descend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To comply with even the highest security standards, WEB-DMS features cutting-edge encryption and access control technologies. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: one of the parts of a machine or piece of equipment
dictionaryExamples: Our company makes components for aircraft engines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since both the hardware and software components used by the employees of this department are not in a good state, there is a need of brand new and more powerful computers and of updated software. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: one of the parts or characteristics of something or someone
dictionaryExamples: The course has four distinct components.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These components are present in everyone, whether you are rich or poor, thus it is wrong to be biased with one kind of people purely based on beliefs not support[ed] by solid evidence. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to be the parts that something consists of
dictionaryExamples: The committee was composed of elected leaders and citizens.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is composed of more than 50 members and they have various taste[s] [in] film: old and modern, comedy, action and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to write a piece of music
dictionaryExamples: Who composed the music for the film?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been composing music on a computer for over five years and I have a lot of knowledge when it comes to hardware. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: someone who writes music
dictionaryExamples: a famous composer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I would like to participate in the planned lectures about the opera composers of the 18th century. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: a short piece of writing about a particular subject, done by a student
dictionaryExamples: a 500-word composition
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have [to] do a composition in English to cover the work I missed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of music that someone has written
dictionaryExamples: This concerto is one of her later compositions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He sang Schubert's "Die Winterreise" although it's already Spring - this composition [can be heard in] every season. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the parts, substances, etc. that something consists of
dictionaryExamples: the composition of the atmosphere
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The eating procedure takes approx. 3 hrs, as each course is introduced by a detailed description of its preparation and composition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the way that people or things are arranged in a painting or photograph
dictionaryExamples: The composition of the painting was perfect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The study of acting, directing, and generally speaking of the scene has always demanded a certain degree of visual composition, a sense of image and of that which is immediately seen (or not seen). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: the process or skill of writing music
dictionaryExamples: He taught composition at Yale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He finished music composition at the University in Cracow, [and] he soon became the professor of composition at the same school of music. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: including everything
dictionaryExamples: a comprehensive study of the subject
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Presentations on making a career in media, finance and IT could have been more comprehensive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovak

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: Sources are comprehensively listed at the back of the book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However enjoyable and relaxing, driving needs [your] full attention. Therefore, it should be learn[ed] comprehensively and being experienced shouldn't be relied on. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to consist of particular parts or members
dictionaryExamples: The orchestra was comprised of amateur and professional musicians.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It comprises only twelve single and six double bedrooms, which will provide the intimacy we need. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to form part of something, especially a larger group
dictionaryExamples: Women comprise 15% of the police force.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to [a] survey carried out in 1997, the urban population comprises 71% of the total population in Pakistan. International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi

sense.def: when you agree to something which is not exactly what you want
dictionaryExamples: It is hoped that a compromise will be reached in today's talks.
You've both got to be willing to make compromises.
In a compromise between management and unions, a 4% pay increase was agreed to in return for an increase in productivity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope that we'll find a compromise. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to agree to something that is not exactly what you want
dictionaryExamples: In a relationship, both people have to compromise.
I'm not going to compromise on quality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The  famous stars and the journalists should compromise and respect each other's rights. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to have a harmful effect on something
dictionaryExamples: The trial has been seriously compromised by sensational media coverage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sportsmen are usually under an enormous amount of pressure, because the slightest failure could compromise their career. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: A compulsive habit is something that you do a lot because you want to so much that you cannot control yourself.
