dictionaryExamples: a compulsive eating disorder
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, the cent[e]r has a potential to affect shoppers, rendering them more compulsive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: so interesting or exciting that you cannot stop reading, playing, or watching it
dictionaryExamples: This documentary about life in prison makes compulsive viewing.

sense.def: If something is compulsory, you must do it because of a rule or law.
dictionaryExamples: Wearing seat belts in cars is compulsory by law.
Swimming was compulsory at my school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have asked participants to wear a typical traditional dress/suit from their country - of course, this is not compulsory but everyone is warmly invited to do so. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: an electronic machine that can store and arrange large amounts of information
dictionaryExamples: We've put all our records on the computer.
computer software/hardware
computer graphics
a computer program
computer games
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of books and computers. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: to hide something
dictionaryExamples: The listening device was concealed in a pen.
She could barely conceal her irritation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had managed to conceal her dark secret from everybody. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to admit that something is true, even though you do not want to
dictionaryExamples: Even the company chairman concedes that the results are disappointing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a frequent user of the town library, I had to concede that the article was telling the truth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to allow someone to have something, even though you do not want to
dictionaryExamples: The government will not concede to rebel demands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "It's wonderful, isn't it, how you always get what you pray for." This quote, Milly's reaction when her father concedes to buying her a horse, is a good illustration of her general attitude towards religion and life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: too proud of yourself and your actions
dictionaryExamples: I find him very conceited.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is not to say that the successful person must be smug, conceited or bumptious; but he has to be convinced of his own skills and abilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to think of an idea or plan
dictionaryExamples: The original idea for the novel was conceived in Rome.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder what kind of person conceived this terrible and ignorant idea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be able to imagine something
dictionaryExamples: I cannot conceive of anything more horrible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You cannot conceive of any other way of existence than the one you know. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to become pregnant
dictionaryExamples: She had been trying for years, but never managed to conceive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By then she had everything she could ask for but for some reason she did not conceive for 2 years. [T]hen she conceived but had two miscarr[i]ages. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tamil

sense.def: to think very carefully about something you are doing and nothing else
dictionaryExamples: Come on, concentrate! We haven't got all day to do this.
I can't concentrate on my work with all that noise.
I'm going to concentrate on my writing for a while.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't concentrate on studying. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to be present in large numbers or amounts in a particular area
dictionaryExamples: Most of the fighting was concentrated in the mountains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However it might imply a shift from large stores, concentrated in a few areas within or outside the city, to more local services. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: the ability to think carefully about something you are doing and nothing else
dictionaryExamples: The noise outside made concentration difficult.
There was a look of intense concentration on her face.
I find that yoga improves my powers of concentration.
I found it hard to follow what the teacher was saying, and eventually I lost concentration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, in my opinion, watching a film is more relaxing, because you don't have to concentrate to[o] much on it. You only have to watch the screen, while books require more concentration. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a large number or amount of something in the same place
dictionaryExamples: high concentrations of minerals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Again, we may need to think about [the] implementation of more strict regulations related to the concentration of toxic chemicals in exhausts. International English Language Testing System; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a principle or idea
dictionaryExamples: the concept of free speech
I failed to grasp the film's central concept.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had been trying very hard to get the point of the concept. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: an idea about what something is like or a way of understanding something
dictionaryExamples: They have no conception of how ordinary people live.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, unless we stretch the conception of personality to cover conformity with practice and social norms, economic decisions, and the choice of identities we aspire [to], the clothes that people wear may not reflect their personality, as [this] can be conditioned by many contingencies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to be important to someone or to involve someone directly
dictionaryExamples: Matters of pollution and the environment concern us all.
There are one or two other matters that don't concern you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fitness and health are two important issues in life which concern all of us. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to be about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: The next item on the agenda concerns staffing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your other question concerns clothes. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to worry or upset someone
dictionaryExamples: What really concerns me is her lack of experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read your newspaper announcement and because I am seriously concerned I decided to write you this letter. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when you feel worried or nervous about something, or something that makes you feel worried
dictionaryExamples: Concern for the safety of the two missing teenagers is growing.
There's a lot of public concern about/over dangerous toxins recently found in food.
The situation has been causing concern for some time now.
My concern is that you're not getting enough work done.
There's a matter of some concern that I have to discuss with you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All those days I put aside all my concerns about my studies. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that is important to you, or when something is important
dictionaryExamples: Our primary concern is safety.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My concern is what present to buy for Mr Brown. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: worried
dictionaryExamples: He's very concerned about her health.
I'm concerned that sales figures haven't improved
Concerned parents have complained about the dangerous playground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are getting more and more concerned about our health and how to get and keep fit nowadays. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: as far as sb is concerned

sense.def: used to say what someone's opinion is
dictionaryExamples: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is just nonsense.
As far as our customers are concerned, price is the main consideration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

blocks.phrase: as far as sth is concerned

sense.def: used to say what you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to be about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: The program was more concerned with politics than the history of the place.
This field of linguistics is concerned with language acquisition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This report is concerned with finding the best accom[m]odation for the three-day trip in north-west England. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: involved in something or affected by it
dictionaryExamples: A letter will be sent out to everyone concerned.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The amount of refund is to be negotiated with everyone concerned separately. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: about
dictionaryExamples: I got a letter from the state tax department concerning the new commuter tax.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing in reply to your letter concerning the prize I won in your competition, which is two weeks at Camp California in the U.S.A. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a performance of music by one or more musicians or singers
dictionaryExamples: a pop/classical concert
a school concert
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To help with the concert I can sell tickets. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: something that you agree to do or give to someone in order to end an argument
dictionaryExamples: Both sides will have to make concessions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, I still have the impression that some concessions have to be made and from personal experience, I can say it is very different to base your choice on a single criterion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to decide something after studying all the information about it very carefully
dictionaryExamples: The report concluded that the drug was safe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking all th[ese] reasons into consideration, it can be concluded that there are many advantages & disadvantages of the decision to ban cars in city centers. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: to end something such as a meeting, speech, or piece of writing by doing or saying one last thing
dictionaryExamples: The concert concluded with fireworks.
I would like to conclude by thanking you all for attending.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To conclude, I would like to underline one more time how crucial the setting up of a library would be for our college. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the opinion you have after considering all the information about something
dictionaryExamples: At first I thought he was being rude, but I've come to/reached the conclusion that he's just shy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jack and Ben: I['ve] been thinking about your last letter for quite a long time and I came to the following conclusion. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to introduce the last part of a speech or a piece of writing
dictionaryExamples: In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker for her fascinating talk.
In conclusion, swimming is an enjoyable form of exercise and an excellent way to stay in shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, music, TV and clothes are very important in a young person's life and can reflect each person's character. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to guess the facts about a situation without having all of the information
dictionaryExamples: It’s not fair to jump to conclusions based on one incident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think, before jumping to conclusions, we should first try to anal[ys]e the situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the final part of something
dictionaryExamples: the dramatic conclusion of the movie
The case should finally be brought to a conclusion this week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When it comes to the crunch, he is patient and persistent enough to carry a project to a successful conclusion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause you to think that something is probably true
dictionaryExamples: So you thought I was leaving, did you?  What led you to that conclusion?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These results lead us to the conclusion that only people with "minds tough enough" will survive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: proving that something is true
dictionaryExamples: conclusive evidence/proof
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although there is no conclusive evidence of the influence of food on people's behavior, we can observe certain patterns of beh[a]vior depending on what kind of food people eat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that proves that something is true
dictionaryExamples: It is possible to prove conclusively that he was at home at the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This undeniable fact implies advantages that were unthinkable in the past, yet we cannot prove conclusively that the gains outweigh the losses. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a very hard building material made by mixing together cement, sand, small stones and water
dictionaryExamples: reinforced concrete
a concrete floor/path
a gray concrete building
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of our children, brought up in modern cities, in a world of concrete, cars, motorways and supermarkets, when asked: "What is a fish?" are only able to answer: "a square piece of white flesh we take from the freezer". First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: certain or based on facts
dictionaryExamples: They think she killed her husband, but they have no concrete evidence/proof.
We've got a general idea of what we want, but nothing concrete at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another piece of concrete evidence to suggest that children from a poorer background cannot cope with social problems properly compared to the other group is the fact that they are more inclined to be the troublemakers themselves.  International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai

sense.def: existing in a real form that can be seen or felt
dictionaryExamples: concrete achievements/actions
concrete objects
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order to turn it into a feasible concept, this process of learning should be applied to concrete situations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to say very strongly that you think something is wrong or very bad
dictionaryExamples: The President was quick to condemn the terrorists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first these needs were satisfied by different religions, but as we are living in a material world that does not care about spiritual things any more, we created our own idols whom we can look at, judge, admire or condemn - celebrities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the particular state that something or someone is in
dictionaryExamples: My bike's a few years old, but it's in really good condition.
They left the apartment in a terrible condition - it was a mess.
He's in no condition to drive home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very beautiful and in good condition. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the physical situation that someone or something is in and affected by
dictionaryExamples: The prisoners were kept in the most appalling conditions.

Severe 
                         weather conditions are making driving difficult.
What are their living/working conditions like?
Under what conditions do plants grow best?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Althoug[h] I had fun the weather conditions were horrible - it was raining all the time and the road was too wet to ride on. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an illness
dictionaryExamples: a medical condition
He suffers from a rare heart condition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, all the fats we eat every day plus the accumulated stress of a job, makes us the perfect candidates [for] a heart condition. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: only if
dictionaryExamples: I'll come with you on the condition that we're back before midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name [on] the website. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that must happen or be agreed before something else can happen
dictionaryExamples: One of the conditions of the contract is that we can't keep pets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I want you to pay for that as it was agreed between us and according to the terms and conditions of the contract. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to make a person or animal behave in a particular way by influencing the way they think
dictionaryExamples: The boys were conditioned to be aggressive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people are being subconsciously conditioned to become consumers in every sense of the word. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to organize and perform a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: We are conducting a survey to find out what our customers think of their local bus service.
The experiments were conducted by scientists in New York.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is based on a questionnair[e] conducted in the school and our English department's investigation. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to stand in front of a group of musicians and control their performance
dictionaryExamples: The orchestra was conducted by Charles Miller.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The o[r]chestra conducted by Mr Miller was just superb. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to behave in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: She conducted herself with great dignity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The qualities I admire most in other people are, first of all, the ability to hide your own feelings - being a little reserved - and at the same time the ability to conduct yourself in such a way so that other people are influenced by you. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who stands in front of a group of musicians or singers and controls their performance
dictionaryExamples: a famous conductor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am fifty five years old and have experience [as] a conductor of a choir. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a large, formal meeting, often lasting a few days, where people discuss their work, politics, subjects they are studying, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a conference on women's rights
the annual sales conference
They frequently hold conferences at the hotel.
I'm speaking at/attending a conference next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, I went to Canada in order to take part in an environmental conference. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about
dictionaryExamples: She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.
He has confessed to the murder.
He confessed to sleeping through most of the film.
I have to confess, I was a little confused at first.
I found it all very confusing,  I must confess.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must confess I've put on four kilos in the last three months and the bicycle will help me to become fitter. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you admit that you have done something wrong or illegal
dictionaryExamples: He made a full confession to the police.
I  have  a confession to make - I've lost that book you lent me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also have a confession to make. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when you are certain of your ability to do things well
dictionaryExamples: He's got the confidence to walk into a room of strangers and immediately start a conversation.
The training has given me the confidence to deal with any situation that arises.
She has ability but she  lacks confidence.
I have every/complete confidence in her. She'll be perfect for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result of such a bad appearance he lacks confidence. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: trusting someone's ability or believing that something will produce good results
dictionaryExamples: Kate's new to the job, but I've got every confidence in her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have every confidence in your ability to reach a compromise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else.
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry, she told me that in confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His real name isn't Piggy but he told Ralph in confidence that they called him that in school because of his appearance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: certain about your ability to do things well
dictionaryExamples: Be a bit more confident in yourself!
It was a confident performance.
He feels confident of winning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I soon felt more confident, as I saw what activities they were doing: some people were playing tennis, others were sunbathing in the garden. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: being certain that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: Are you confident that enough people will attend the event?
They don't sound confident about the future of the industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, I'm confident that a solution will be found and our town will soon regain its former attractive look. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: secret, especially in an official situation
dictionaryExamples: These documents are strictly confidential.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember, you are under no obligation to do anything and of course we will treat the confidential information you give us with discretion and respect. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: with confidence or in a confident way
dictionaryExamples: Try to act confidently, even if you feel nervous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am quite [a] hard worker and I can confidently say that I am quite [a] reliable person. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to prevent someone from leaving a place or to prevent something from spreading
dictionaryExamples: He was confined to a prison cell for several days.
The disease outbreak was confined to the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being Portuguese, I was confined to this small rectangle until I was a 15-year-old boy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make an arrangement or meeting certain, often by telephone or in writing
dictionaryExamples: Six people have confirmed that they will be attending and ten haven't replied yet.
Flights should be confirmed 48 hours before departure.
I've accepted the job over the phone, but I haven't confirmed in writing yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just want to confirm that we're going to the ABC cinema tonight. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to say or show that something is true
dictionaryExamples: His wife confirmed that he had left the house that morning.
The leader's speech was impressive and confirmed her faith in the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, it was confirmed by scientists that consum[er]ism may develop [in]to a compulsion. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a statement, often written, that an arrangement or meeting is certain
dictionaryExamples: a letter of confirmation
We've only had five confirmations for the conference so far.
We will send you written confirmation of our offer shortly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to receiving your confirmation. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: serious disagreement between people with opposing opinions or principles
dictionaryExamples: There was a lot of conflict between the two parties.
The Government was in conflict with the unions over pay.
It was an unpopular policy and caused a number of conflicts within the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I was in conflict with myself, should I buy a computer or a bicycle? First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: fighting between two or more groups of people or countries
dictionaryExamples: armed conflict
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In these years, Europe was in conflict with China, which meant war. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a situation where someone cannot make fair decisions because they are influenced by something
dictionaryExamples: She resigned from the committee because of a conflict of interest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It could become a conflict of interest, but he never lets it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to tell someone something, or show them something to try to make them admit they have done something wrong
dictionaryExamples: Confronted with the evidence, she broke down and confessed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had bills coming in our door, old ones which w[ere]n't paid and whenever I confronted him, he told me he would take care of it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be in a difficult situation, or to be shown something which may cause difficulties
dictionaryExamples: We are confronted by the possibility of war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Youngsters are confronted with a lot of difficulties and dangers and are often bound to collapse psychologically from the hard pressure on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to see that a problem exists and try to deal with it
dictionaryExamples: First, they must confront their feelings of anger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His inability to confront Ethan's death, as well as his being too methodical, cause[s] his wife Sarah to reconsider their marriage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a fight or argument
dictionaryExamples: She witnessed a confrontation between the two men.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There, he finds himself in a direct confrontation with Captain Beatty, the head of the fire station, who represents everything that's evil, as he knows about books but still willingly destroys them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to make someone unable to think clearly, or to make something difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: You're confusing him! Tell him slowly and one thing at a time.
Stop confusing the issue!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the corpse was found he - successfully - tried to confuse Mrs. Marple, Scotland Yard and the members of the family where he was the doctor. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to think that one person or thing is another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: I think you're confusing me with my sister - we look quite similar.
It's easy to confuse his films, because he tends to use the same actors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had confused the two words, "uvas", which means grapes, and "huevos", which means eggs and said "huevas", which unfortunately means testicles, instead... First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: unable to think clearly or to understand something
dictionaryExamples: People keep telling me different things and I'm getting very confused.
Sorry, I'm a bit confused - are we meeting here or in town?
She seemed a bit confused about the arrangements.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first I felt very confused. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: not clear
dictionaryExamples: The witnesses gave confused accounts of what happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What can a child [think], hearing such confused explanations about animals that don't live where they s[h]ould live, that don't live how they should live. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: I found the instructions very confusing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a secret agent I was prepared [for] this sort of thing but it was surprising and confusing. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: when people do not understand what is happening, what they should do or who someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: There seems to be some confusion about/over who is actually giving the talk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This caused some confusion because the courses were not completely prepared. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a situation, often with a lot of activity and noise, in which people do not know what to do
dictionaryExamples: In the confusion after the bomb blast, I lost my bag.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the confusion someone pushed her against the wall and she hurt her shoulder. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a feeling of not being able to think clearly
dictionaryExamples: He could see the confusion on Marion's face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I thought he recogni[z]ed my confusion; therefore, he opened the box, picking up something from [it]. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: when something is full or blocked
dictionaryExamples: There is always traffic congestion on this highway.
Nasal congestion is a common symptom when you have a cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The traffic congestion in Belo Horizonte is an issue that can't be ignored. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to tell someone that you are happy because they have done something good or something good has happened to them
dictionaryExamples: I was just congratulating Ceri on winning her race.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Needless to say, everybody congratulated her and she spent all evening answering questions such as: "Why did you choose water jumping?" or "Isn't it difficult for a teenager to train five hours a day and to study?" First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: something that you say when you want to congratulate someone
dictionaryExamples: "I passed my driving test yesterday." "Congratulations! That's fantastic."
Congratulations on your engagement!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Congratulations on your wedding. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Korean

sense.def: a word such as 'and', 'but', 'while' or 'although' that connects words, phrases and clauses in a sentence
working, used, or happening with something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: Our librarians use their knowledge in conjunction with the computer network.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore if the banning of private cars takes place in conjunction with development in the public transport[ation] system in that city, this whole development will [have] more advantages despite some slight difficulties at the start. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tamil

sense.def: to join or be joined with something else
dictionaryExamples: Can I connect my printer to your computer?
Where does the cooker connect (up)to the electricity?
Has the water/electricity/gas/telephone been connected in your new place yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to buy [a] computer to play games and connect to [the] Internet as well as listen to music in my free time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to see or show that two or more people or things are involved with each other
dictionaryExamples: There is no evidence to connect him with the crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Happiness should not be defined as material access, it should be connected with one of the most basic human needs, love. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: something that joins things together
dictionaryExamples: Many companies now offer free connection to the Internet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, some portable phones have a connection to the web, so it is easy to read newspapers if one hasn't enough money to buy [them]. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when someone or something is involved with or related to someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: The connection between smoking and heart disease is well known.
He has denied having any connection with the terrorists.
They're sisters, are they? I knew their surname was the same, but I never made the connection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are aware of the connection between food and health you can start changing your eating habits. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to say what something is about
dictionaryExamples: I am writing in connection with the above job advertised in The Daily Press on Monday 12th February.
A man has been arrested in connection with last month's murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mrs Brown, I am writing in connection with a surprise birthday party for your husband, Mr Brown. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a train, bus or aircraft that leaves a short time after another arrives, so people can continue their journey
dictionaryExamples: The train was half an hour late and I missed my connection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because of bad bus connections it's not easy to get there. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to take control of a country or to defeat people by war
dictionaryExamples: The English were conquered by the Normans  in 1066.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, following imper[i]alistic politics, the Persian King Darios wanted to expand his Kingdom in Europe, so he had to conquer Greece. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the part of you that makes you feel guilty when you have behaved badly
dictionaryExamples: a guilty conscience

My conscience is clear 
                         because I've done nothing wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people have pangs of conscience and are invariably hit by pestering anxiety but they adamantly [refuse] to admit it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: always doing your work with a lot of care
dictionaryExamples: a conscientious student
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is conscientious and hardworking. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: when someone is awake and can think and notice things
dictionaryExamples: He lost consciousness for several minutes.
He never regained consciousness after the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He lost consciousness and lay there on the floor just in front of me. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when someone knows about something
dictionaryExamples: There's a growing consciousness about environmental issues among young people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It also springs up out of a pleasure of playing the game and a consciousness that their health matters and being fit is an important element of it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: Consecutive events, numbers, or periods of time come one after the other.
dictionaryExamples: the third consecutive day of rain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Complaints from students have been increasing for the second consecutive year, tape players are repeatedly reported not fun[c]tioning. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: when all the people in a group agree about something
dictionaryExamples: to reach a consensus
The general consensus is that we should wait and see what happens.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, as the general consensus is that young people enjoy communicating through radio programs, I suggest there is a time when messages sent by listeners are read. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: permission for someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: You can't come without your parents' consent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The role of the council is to organi[z]e things [well] and to do so with the consent of people living in the city. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; French

sense.def: to agree to do something, or to allow someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: They eventually consented to let us enter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fascism is regarded as one of the worst manifestations of human nature, for it was not only a man or even a larger group of men who committed the crimes against mankind that will long remain in our minds, but a whole nation who consented in silence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the result of a particular action or situation, especially a bad result
dictionaryExamples: The ship sank with disastrous consequences.
Excessive drinking can have serious consequences for a person's health.
If you neglect your relationships like that, you'll suffer the consequences.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My work was the best because I drew a big drawing about [the] consequences of us not caring [for the] environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Azerbaijani

sense.def: used to talk about one thing that is the result of another
dictionaryExamples: A lot of birds died as a consequence of the oil spill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The influence from Italy is very strong and, as a consequence, pasta with different s[a]uces is common in Slovenia, especially among students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: not important
dictionaryExamples: The money was of little consequence to Tony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, the downpour of rain which was mentioned was in fact nothing more than a small shower, of no significant consequence for the dance display and horse show. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: as a result
dictionaryExamples: I spent most of my money in the first week and consequently had very little to eat by the end of the holiday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Because of their job or school, people are much more stress[ed]. Consequently, they don't take [the] time to eat correctly. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the protection of nature
dictionaryExamples: wildlife conservation
conservation groups
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that trying to save the wildlife in your area is a great aim because you don't have conservation areas and people can easily go hunting without telling anyone and in that way they destroy the wildlife. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when you are careful not to waste energy, water, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Our top priority is conservation of water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the issue of energy conservation is becoming more and more important, our company has decided to start doing something about it, as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: not trusting sudden changes or new ideas
dictionaryExamples: Older people are often more conservative.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, some people, especially some youngsters, would say that she's too conservative - I heard lots of people describing her as a 'fuddy-duddy lady'. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: Conservative political ideas emphasize the importance of personal responsibility and preserving traditional cultural and religious values.
dictionaryExamples: Voters in this state are usually more likely to vote for conservative politicians.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He only had to make a marvelous speech on TV to make people realize about the seriousness of the crisis that Europe is going through (and of course Spain) and the importance of keeping the same economic policy and not changing the present government for a more conservative one. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to think carefully about something, often before you decide what to do
dictionaryExamples: Have you considered what you'll do if you don't get the job?
We're considering selling the house.
She's being considered for the job.
I'd like some time to consider before I make a decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must say thanks to you for your birthday money for me to buy a DVD. After considering [what to buy], I decided to buy 'The Legend of Narnias'. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to have a particular opinion about someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I don't consider myself to be a great athlete.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I consider myself to be punctual, hard-working, reliable and responsible. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to give attention to a particular subject or fact when making a decision or judging something else
dictionaryExamples: You've got to consider the time element when planning the whole project.
If you consider how long he's been learning the piano, he's not very good.
If you buy an old house, you have to consider the cost of repairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only point we have to consider will be the price of food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to think that something may exist or be true
dictionaryExamples: Have you considered the possibility that he might be lying?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many students this year refuse even to consider the possibility of going to one. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: used for saying that something is true in general if you think about all its aspects
dictionaryExamples: The show was a great success, all things considered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All things considered, it seems like "Kavanagh Catering Services" would be most suitable for the students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to care about  or respect other people or their feelings or wishes
dictionaryExamples: She never considers anyone but herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly you should always consider other people in your group once you start working together in a group.  International English Language Testing System; C2; Panjabi

sense.def: large or important enough to be noticed
dictionaryExamples: It's a considerable sum of money.
The effect on the region has been considerable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have considerable experience as a worker on [a] farm, having worked on my father's farm from 1956 to 1986. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a way that is large or important enough to be noticed
dictionaryExamples: Rates of pay vary considerably.
He's considerably fatter than he was when I knew him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The departures are at 8 am. and 10 a.m. daily, but I suggest that your group be there at the time of the first departure because it is considerably less crowded. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: showing concern for other people and their feelings
dictionaryExamples: He is always a kind and considerate host.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: As a colleague, I always found him thoughtful and considerate. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: when you think about something very carefully
dictionaryExamples: After careful consideration, we decided to offer her the job.
The matter needs to be given serious consideration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please give this your careful consideration. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when you think about a particular fact or detail and let it influence your decision
dictionaryExamples: It may be cheap to buy, but you've got to take into consideration the money you'll spend on repairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the reasons I have stated, and taking into consideration that I am an ambitious and sociable person, I think I am suitable for the job. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that you have to think about when you make decisions or plans
dictionaryExamples: Safety is our main consideration.
Cost, of course, is another consideration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The next consideration is the activities. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: when you are kind to people or think about their feelings
dictionaryExamples: They always treated me with consideration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is very friendly and sympathetic towards those who, like Ralph and the twins, treat him with consideration, accepting him as he is, in spite of his deficiencies as to his manual or hunting abilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: used for saying that you have a particular opinion about something, because of a particular fact about it
dictionaryExamples: She did really well, considering how little experience she'd had.
Considering the weather, we got here quite quickly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Considering all the above, I think that your article was completely misleading. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: always behaving or happening in a similar, usually positive, way
dictionaryExamples: consistent effort/improvement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you make a consistent effort you will improve your work at a very brisk pace. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: having the same principles as something else, or agreeing with other facts
dictionaryExamples: His account of events is entirely consistent with the video evidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An accurate selection of these categories of people should be made by the producers so [as] to offer to viewers the best possible models in a way which has to be consistent with the program's title. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that does not change, often a positive way
dictionaryExamples: He has consistently denied the rumors.
She performed consistently throughout the whole tournament.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: one of the speech sounds or letters of the alphabet which is not a vowel
happening a lot or all the time
dictionaryExamples: He's in constant trouble with the police.
These machines are in constant use.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for me, constant practice in [the] English language is quite important,  it is the essence of my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: staying at the same level
dictionaryExamples: The temperature remained constant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Spain had the highest average number of children (2.2) in 1980. [T]his figure took a dip downward to 1.6 in 1985, decreased steadily to 1.2 average number of children in 1995 and remained relatively constant afterwards. International English Language Testing System; C2; Yapese

sense.def: all the time or often
dictionaryExamples: He's constantly changing his mind.
She has the television on constantly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stood up and walked around the house, constantly bumping into things! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to be or form something
dictionaryExamples: This defeat constitutes a real setback for their championship hopes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Women constitute nearly half (48%) of the university students, and in some departments (educational colleges, medicine schools) they are clearly the majority. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Latvian

sense.def: the set of laws and principles that a country's government must obey
dictionaryExamples: the US Constitution
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is to be seen as progress, although this development seems to start rather late as already in 1949, the German constitution indicated th[at] men and women have equal rights. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the state of someone's health
dictionaryExamples: a strong/weak constitution
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another obvious feature of his character is his physical constitution: he is rather weak and needs glasses because he is short-sighted. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: relating to the constitution of a country
dictionaryExamples: a constitutional crisis
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Acting likewise, not only will a generation of co-dependent individuals run this country, but also devalue some constitutional principles and even jeopardi[z]e democratic institutions already established. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to control something by limiting it
dictionaryExamples: regulations that constrain industry
I'm constrained by decisions made in the past.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It must be acknowledged that he is a man constrained by an imposed marriage, which is going to leave him without an heir. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: something that limits what you can do
dictionaryExamples: budget/financial constraints
There are constraints on the medicines doctors can prescribe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course there are different preferences and priorities as well as constraints. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to build something from several parts
dictionaryExamples: The building was constructed in 1930.
The walls are constructed of concrete.
You need this information to construct a basic sentence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Using some wood, we constructed small seats and tables. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the work of building something, especially houses, offices, bridges, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the construction industry
The next decade saw the construction of many more office blocks.
She works in construction.
This website is currently under construction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It [is] worth mentioning that a huge gym is under construction. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: something that is built
dictionaryExamples: a large steel construction
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be a pity to build a modern construction there. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: The construction of a sentence or phrase is the way the words are arranged.
dictionaryExamples: Pay attention to sentence construction and check word order.

sense.def: helpful or useful
dictionaryExamples: constructive advice/criticism
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, I have quite often [asked] for the opinion of Mr. Walker on the making of our marketing plan and his comments were always very helpful and constructive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to go to a particular person or book to get information or advice
dictionaryExamples: For more information, consult your travel agent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if I think I know what to write, I usually consult an interpreter and/or a lawyer. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to discuss something with someone before you make a decision
dictionaryExamples: Why didn't you consult me about this?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As it is just after Christmas I had to consult my wife - that is why it took some time to write this reply. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: someone who advises people on a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: a management/financial consultant
a firm of public relations consultants
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I work in a bank as a consultant. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when you discuss something with someone in order to get their advice or opinion about it
dictionaryExamples: After consultation with his lawyers, he decided to abandon the case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After full consideration and consultation of the three groups of people mentioned above, we come to the result that charity workers should [have the opportunity] to present the work they are doing on TV. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a meeting to discuss something or to get advice
dictionaryExamples: a medical consultation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We also plan to employ 2 graduate students from the psycholog[y] department in giving free consultations to the children to help them cope with their concerns and worries. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to eat or drink something
dictionaryExamples: People generally consume far too much sugar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who eat fresh vegetables and meat tend to have good digestion and tend to consume less salt. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to use fuel, energy or time, especially in large amounts
dictionaryExamples: Our high living standards cause our present population to consume 25 percent of the world's oil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It did consume a lot of time, but it was very rewarding. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to have so much of a feeling that it affects everything you do
dictionaryExamples: a dancer consumed by ambition
He was consumed with jealousy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, we find ourselves unable to enjoy a pleasant meal without being consumed by the deepest guilt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a person who buys goods or services for their own use
dictionaryExamples: The new telephone rates will affect all consumers including businesses.
consumer rights/advice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people might argue that this system is convenient for consumers as they can go shopping whenever they would like to, and it makes the shops more secure against burglary and vandalism since the shops are packed with people inside. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the amount of something that someone uses, eats, or drinks
dictionaryExamples: We need to reduce our energy consumption.
fuel/water consumption
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One less obvious aspect of pollution is the surge in energy consumption caused by technological development. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: someone you know, especially someone who can help you because of their job or position
dictionaryExamples: Julia's mother had contacts who helped her with her career.
business contacts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my contacts are in my cell phone and it is very important. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: communication with someone, especially by speaking or writing to them regularly
dictionaryExamples: Do you still keep in contact with Peter?
I'm still in contact with Sarah - we write a couple of times a year.
There isn't enough contact between teachers and parents.
I'd hate to lose contact with my old school friends.
If you manage to make contact with her, do let me know.
The school likes to have a contact number for parents during school hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, we'll [be] in contact in one week['s time]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when two people or things are touching each other
dictionaryExamples: She dislikes any kind of physical contact.
Wash your hands if they come into contact with chemicals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I might even have become afraid of physical contact and of being face to face with others. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a small piece of plastic that you put on your eye to make you see more clearly
dictionaryExamples: I wear contacts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Thank you," Jason said with delight, "You must know I am almost blind without my contacts." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when people look directly at each other, for instance when they are talking to each other
dictionaryExamples: There was very little eye contact between them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to avoid having eye contact with people just because of this humility. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to communicate with someone by telephoning them or sending them a letter, e-mail, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I tried to contact him at his office, but he wasn't in.

You can contact me
                      on  my cell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please contact me on 3333333. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: If one thing contains another, it has it inside it.
dictionaryExamples: a box containing a diamond ring
How much liquid do you think this bottle contains?
I've lost a file containing a lot of important documents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So he asks the man if that suitcase is his, [and] the man runs to get it but the security guards don't let him until he shouts: "It contains my daughter's wedding dress!" Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to have something as a part
dictionaryExamples: Does this drink contain alcohol?
Try to avoid foods which contain a lot of fat.
The allegations contained in this report are very serious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] food was not wonderful, but it was healthy and contained a lot of vitamins. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to control your emotions
dictionaryExamples: He could barely contain his anger.
I could not contain myself any longer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without being able to contain himself and helped by the alcohol in his blood, he shouted and danced and kissed everyone around him, acting in an exceptional way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an object such as a box or a bottle that is used for holding something
dictionaryExamples: an airtight container
a plastic drinks container
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, a mountain of plastic containers and harmful chemical fluid is [ruin]ing mother earth. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to think about something for a long time or in a serious way
dictionaryExamples: I'm contemplating changing my name.
He even contemplated suicide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While the popular girl gets very drunk at parties, the other one sits alone in her room, contemplating suicide. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: existing or happening now
dictionaryExamples: contemporary music/literature/art/fashion
Although it was written hundreds of years ago, it still has a contemporary feel to it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always read a lot of different magazin[e]s and know a lot about contemporary writers. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a strong feeling that you do not respect someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He has utter contempt for anyone with power.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being a compulsory subject at school, history inevitably arouses contempt, as anything mandatory [does]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: pleased with your situation and not hoping for change or improvement
dictionaryExamples: He seems fairly content with life.
They're content to socialize with a very small circle of people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He looked really content and happy. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the ideas that are contained in a piece of writing, a speech or a film
dictionaryExamples: the content of the article
It's a very beautiful film, but it seems to me to lack content.
We've discussed the unusual form of the book - now, what about the content?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest explaining the content of the film. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: the amount of a particular substance that something contains
dictionaryExamples: Most soft drinks have a high sugar content.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, I think to eat what is and has been considered healthy for ages, to focus on variety rather than fat content and to do a lot of exercise is the best option. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: everything that is contained within something
dictionaryExamples: The contents of his bag spilled all over the floor.
He hardly needed to open the letter because he already knew the contents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He looked for the owner and gave him the suitcase. He also asked about its contents. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the information or ideas that are written in a book, letter, document, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the contents of his will
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first lesson the teacher explaine[d] the rules and [the] contents of the course, and finally we d[id] a group activity. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a list in a book that tells you what different parts the book contains
dictionaryExamples: a table of contents

sense.def: a competition to do better than other people, usually in which prizes are given
dictionaryExamples: a dance/sports/essay contest
She's won a lot of beauty contests.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next week there will be a "Freestyle Battle", a rap contest, where [a] rapper can mess with others. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an election with two or more people running for the same position
dictionaryExamples: This is the city's most important mayoral contest in decades.
In the last election, he survived a close contest against a political newcomer.

sense.def: someone who competes in a contest
dictionaryExamples: All the contestants are ready to begin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The contestants have to sing in front of an audience and the jury. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: all the facts, opinions,  etc. relating to a particular thing or event
dictionaryExamples: This small battle is very important in the context of Scottish history.
It is important to see all the fighting and bloodshed in his plays in historical context.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is interesting to see wild animals in their natural surroundings but for a number of reasons this is mostly impossible. In this context, I think a zoo is a good alternative. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: other words that were said or written at the same time as the word or words you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: In this exercise, a word is blanked out and you have to guess what it is by looking at the context.
Taken out of context, her remark sounded like an insult.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's not like studying new words from [a] textbook as you hear or use the words [in] real situations and [an] appropriate context. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: one of the seven main areas of  land on the Earth, such as Africa, Asia, Europe or South America
dictionaryExamples: the North American continent
Asia and Africa are the two biggest continents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Brazil is a large country, almost as big as a continent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to or located on a continent
dictionaryExamples: The continental US includes all the states except Hawaii.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To us from continental Europe it comes as a surprise if we see people on the streets with naked shoulders and naked legs at a temperature of 16 degrees celsius! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: happening again and again over a long period of time or happening without stopping
dictionaryExamples: I can't work with these continual interruptions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, if you are seeking [a] developed city, Buenos Aires is your answer, as it is considered to be a city in continual improvement. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: again and again or without stopping
dictionaryExamples: Dad continually complains about money.
House prices have been rising continually for the last five years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all I would like to mention that new blood is re[q]uired in the club, as the membership is continually falling. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to keep happening, existing or doing something
dictionaryExamples: It continued to snow heavily for two days.
If the rain continues, we'll have to cancel tonight's plans.
The article continues on page ten.
I'll continue working until the end of June.
Should I continue with this job?
Sally Palmer will be continuing as chairperson this fall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I t[h]ought that he wasn't calling me, so I continued walking to the car. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: to start doing or saying something again, after stopping for a short period
dictionaryExamples: We'll have to continue this discussion tomorrow.
It's getting late - why don't we continue tomorrow?
After stopping for a quick snack, they continued on their way.
He paused for a moment to listen and then continued eating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We continued our journey early in the morning. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the state of continuing for a long period of time without being changed or stopped
dictionaryExamples: We are trying to provide continuity of care for these children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the young who demonstrate that there is a sense of continuity in a family, and that was what I was looking for. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: being the form of a verb used to show that an action is continuing to happen
dictionaryExamples: the present/past continuous
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lesson was about the present continuous form. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: happening or existing without stopping
dictionaryExamples: continuous pain
My computer makes a continuous low buzzing noise.
A continuous white line in the middle of the road means no passing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since the development of nuclear weapons, the Earth's fate has been in continuous danger. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: without stopping
dictionaryExamples: You can't work continuously for six hours without a break!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They continuously claim that [the] destruction of the environment is totally all human beings' responsibility. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: methods that prevent a woman from becoming pregnant
dictionaryExamples: What form of contraception do you use?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should the Church have taken a more pro-active role in educating its followers on matters related to health care such as contraception, pregnancy and basic self care - perhaps we would not see such ap[p]alling numbers of [i]mpoverished large families living in [s]hanty towns. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a drug or object that prevents a woman from becoming pregnant
dictionaryExamples: They were not using contraceptives.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lack of contraceptives in her village (due to the religious pressure) in addition to the poor availability of information result in Maria's almost inevitable pregnancy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a legal  agreement between two people, two organizations or a person and an organization
dictionaryExamples: an employment/construction/service contract
a long-term/short-term contract
He signed a new three-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals.
My lawyer is drawing up a contract.
Don't sign/enter into any contract before examining its conditions carefully.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He went to the 1994 World Cup in the USA and Brazil's victory helped him to sign a contract to play in Holland. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a legal agreement with someone to do work or to have work done for you
dictionaryExamples: He's been contracted to perform in five shows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have contracted a famous lawyer who is ready to take the case [to] court if our demands are not [met] by the end of the year. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to get a serious disease
dictionaryExamples: She contracted malaria while living abroad.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should be proud of ourselves that we are in a position to help and cure people who have contracted very complex diseases. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to say that what someone has just said is wrong
dictionaryExamples: Nobody dared to contradict her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jane: Be pa[t]ient with her, she is a lovely lady, although she doesn't like people to contradict her. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If two things that are said or written about something contradict each other, they are so different that they cannot both be true.
dictionaryExamples: His account of the accident contradicts the official government report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I strongly agree with you that people should enjoy their food I also think that you contradict yourself within your last statement. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a big difference between two things that are said or written about the same subject, or between what someone says and what they do
dictionaryExamples: There is a clear contradiction between what she says and what she does.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More often than not, however, such events will also give rise to all sorts of contradictions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: If two statements about the same subject or two actions by the same person are contradictory, they are very different.
dictionaryExamples: The witness statements were contradictory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So parents need to be good role models and not behave in a contradictory way to what is being taught at school. International English Language Testing System; C2; Lithuanian

sense.def: an obvious difference between two or more things
dictionaryExamples: The contrast between their lifestyles couldn't be greater.
The busy north coast of the island is in sharp contrast to the peaceful south.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The contrast between the wild mountains and the crowded but charm[ing] beach on the ocean shore would have pleased you. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: used to show that someone or something is completely different
dictionaryExamples: Their economy has expanded enormously, while ours, by contrast, has declined.
She's quite short, in contrast to her tall sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: TV, by contrast, is a more passive activity. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: If one thing contrasts with another, it is very different from it.
dictionaryExamples: The sharpness of the lemons contrasts with the sweetness of the honey.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her pale expression contrasted with her long, dark hair that hung down beyond her shoulders. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to compare two people or things in order to show the differences between them
dictionaryExamples: If you contrast his early novels with his later work, you can see how his writing has developed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ruth Jhabvala's "Heat and Dust" describes the growing attraction of two British women to India in two parallel stories skilfully interwoven to contrast two periods of time fifty years apart. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to give something, especially money, in order to provide or achieve something together with other people
dictionaryExamples: Her family contributed $50,000 to the fund.
You should come to the meeting if you feel you have something you want to contribute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, it is unfair to judge other performers as second-rate, as they did their best to contribute. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to write articles for a newspaper, magazine, or book
dictionaryExamples: She contributes to several magazines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a lot of thinking and discussing with our members and with people who would like to contribute to our magazine, I decided to suggest our well thought[-out] ideas. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something that you do or give to help produce or achieve something, or to help make something successful
dictionaryExamples: This invention made a major contribution to road safety.
She didn't make much of a contribution at today's meeting, did she?
All contributions, no matter how small, will be much appreciated.
a generous contribution to charity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am willing to make a significant contribution to the club. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to make someone or something do what you want
dictionaryExamples: If you can't control your dog, put it on a leash!
This switch controls the temperature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The movie was about a ring which [was] found in the river and used to control the world. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: to stop yourself expressing strong emotions or behaving in a silly way
dictionaryExamples: You're going to have to learn to control your temper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to control myself and started to speak politely and in a friendly way. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to limit the number, amount or increase of something
dictionaryExamples: Fire fighters struggled to control the blaze.
No attempt was made to control the spread of the disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to control the [number of] cars, we can't allow as many car[s] as we drive [now]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to rule or govern an  area
dictionaryExamples: The whole area is controlled by rebel forces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: BRAVE NEW WORLD The part of the book I have read and I remember best is when John, the savage, comes into the New World [State] controlled by several World Controllers from the savage reservation. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when you make someone or something do what you want, or the power to do this
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't have any control over that child.
He lost control of the vehicle.
The police are in control of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ap[p]arently he lost control of the wheel, so the car crashed into a tree. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If something or someone is beyond control or out of control, you cannot influence, limit or direct them.
dictionaryExamples: The car skidded and went out of control, crashing into an oncoming truck.
There's nothing we can do - the situation is beyond our control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had just driven through Piazza Duomo, when another car came [a]round a corner much too fast, skidded, and went out of control. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: being dealt with successfully
dictionaryExamples: Don't worry - everything's under control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Everything is under control," said the captain. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a switch or other device used to operate a machine, such as a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: Where's the volume control on your stereo?
The main instruments are in the center of the control panel.
The captain sat at the controls of the aircraft.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He touched a switch on the control panel and heard that characteristic hiss. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to start to rule or govern an area
dictionaryExamples: The dictator took control of the country in 1933.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first part of the story animals take control of a farm in England. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a rule or law that limits something
dictionaryExamples: gun/weapons control
He wants the government to impose strict controls on dog ownership.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It is important] to find a way to regulate the information show[n] [o]n the internet, because right now there is no control over the information. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: the ability to be calm
dictionaryExamples: It took a lot of control to stop myself hitting him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you think you [are doing] something wrong during your test you shouldn't [start] panic[k]ing and losing your control. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: causing disagreement or discussion
dictionaryExamples: a controversial issue/decision/speech/figure
The book was very controversial.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From my point of view it is a very controversial issue. First Certificate in English; B2;Polish

sense.def: a lot of disagreement and argument about something
dictionaryExamples: There is a lot of controversy over/about cell phone towers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Traveling abroad to work has been a matter of controversy. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: the quality of being convenient
dictionaryExamples: the convenience of credit cards
