I like the convenience of living so close to the stores and supermarket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the first reason is its convenience. [...] Just by sitting in front of it, you can enjoy TV programs.First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: at a time that is convenient to you
dictionaryExamples: We can meet at your convenience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to hearing from you at your earliest convenience. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that makes life easier
dictionaryExamples: Fortunately, the house has every modern convenience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, we have many facilities and conveniences in comparison with the past. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: easy to use or suiting your plans well
dictionaryExamples: We could meet at either place - whichever is more convenient for you.
A bike's a very convenient way of getting around.
I find it more convenient to be able to do my banking online.
What would be a convenient time for me to stop by?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If it would be possible for you, I can attend another class at any time which is convenient for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: near or easy to get to
dictionaryExamples: My new house is more convenient to the station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is near the train station [so] it is very convenient to get there. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: in a way that is convenient
dictionaryExamples: The house is conveniently situated near the station and shopping.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both places are conveniently situated. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a large formal meeting of people who do a particular job or have a similar interest, or a large meeting for a political party
dictionaryExamples: the national Democratic convention
Where are they holding their party convention?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Conference facilities: Being completely renovated, the historic building of Edessa's Cultural Association is the ideal place for a modern scientific convention. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a usual and accepted way of behaving or doing something
dictionaryExamples: In many countries it is the convention to wear black at funerals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, people tend to avoid traditions and conventions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: traditional and ordinary
dictionaryExamples: conventional behavior/attitudes/clothes
conventional medicine/farming
I find his art rather dull and conventional.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One is [a] very exotic place, the other one is [a] conventional one. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: what most people believe
dictionaryExamples: These ideas about childcare go against conventional wisdom on the subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, against conventional wisdom, I think that while a lot of adult problems are caused by money or the lack of it, it is really the ability to deal with money and to see money as a means rather than an end. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malay

sense.def: a talk between two or more people, usually an informal one
dictionaryExamples: a conversation about football.
I had a strange conversation with the guy who moved in upstairs.
It's impossible to hold/carry on a conversation with all this noise going on!
I struck up an interesting conversation with a man on the bus today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But every day we have [a] spelling test and [a] conversation with our teacher or in pairs. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to have a conversation
dictionaryExamples: I can just about hold a conversation in Italian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know the grammar and many different expressions, and I can hold a conversation with other people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when the appearance, form, or purpose of something is changed
dictionaryExamples: the country's conversion to democracy
Solar power is the conversion of the sun's energy into heat and electricity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This 'magic' conversion of energy can be performed in several ways, which result in different degrees of 'dignity' or 'cleanness' for the resulting electrons, freely running through our cables. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to change the appearance, form, or purpose of something
dictionaryExamples: Could we convert the small bedroom into a second bathroom?
What's the formula for converting pounds into kilos?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even some medieval castles have been converted into museums. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to change to a new religion, belief, etc., or to make someone do this
dictionaryExamples: When did he convert to Islam?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Frederica converted to Catholicism and devoted her life to mentally ill children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to communicate information, feelings, or images to someone
dictionaryExamples: She always conveys a sense of enthusiasm for her work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being an Ambassador for Youth bears lot of responsibility, not only because the person must be an outstanding character and widely well-known, but also because they must behave accordingly and be able to convey a positive message. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: to decide officially in a court of law that someone is guilty of a particular crime
dictionaryExamples: He was convicted of murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently he was convicted of robbery and murder and was sentenced to 20 years in prison. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when someone is officially found to be guilty of a particular crime
dictionaryExamples: He already had two convictions for burglary.
The conviction of all three protesters caused anger in the local community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, she had no previous convictions so nobody believed that such a pretty, intel[l]igent and polite woman could do any harm to anybody. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a strong opinion or belief
dictionaryExamples: religious/moral convictions
a deep/strong conviction
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of the fact that I respect their convictions, I totally disagree with this viewpoint. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: to persuade someone or make them certain
dictionaryExamples: She tried to convince me that I needed a new car.
I hope this will convince you to change your mind.
He managed to convince the jury of his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was the one who convinced me to go, and I am glad she did. Preliminary English Test; B1; Norwegian

sense.def: certain
dictionaryExamples: My boyfriend says I'd enjoy a hiking vacation, but I'm not convinced.
I'm convinced (that) she is lying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm convinced that I would benefit from this experience in the future. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: able to make you believe that something is true or right
dictionaryExamples: a convincing argument/explanation
I didn't find the ending of the movie very convincing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The school didn't give us a real and convincing explanation for this. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: to prepare food and usually heat it
dictionaryExamples: I don't cook meat very often.
Who's cooking this evening?
He cooked us an enormous meal./He cooked an enormous meal for us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like you to cook Camerounian traditional foods (Ndole, Pistache, Couscous, Khaki). Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: someone who prepares and cooks food
dictionaryExamples: She's a wonderful cook.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example my mother wake[s] up at 4am.  She is [a] cook like me. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech

sense.def: a small, flat cake that is dry and usually sweet
dictionaryExamples: chocolate-chip cookies
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, we ate the cookies my mother had baked. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: a piece of information stored on your computer which contains information about an Internet site you have looked at
dictionaryExamples: You need to enable cookies to use this Web site.

sense.def: preparing and cooking food, or a particular way of preparing and cooking food
dictionaryExamples: My mother always hated cooking.
Who does the cooking in your house?
I love my dad's cooking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really like it because I love cooking and also baking. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used when you like something or agree to something
dictionaryExamples: You've got your own apartment? Cool!
"We'll meet at ten, then?" "Cool."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's very exciting. Cool! Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: good, stylish, or fashionable
dictionaryExamples: It was a really cool gig.
She's really cool.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got this mega cool T-shirt. Key English Test; A2; Dutch

sense.def: slightly cold, but not too cold
dictionaryExamples: cool water
a nice cool breeze
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes a cool wind blows [in Bodrum]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: calm and not emotional
dictionaryExamples: She seemed cool and confident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember saying to myself that "this little boy will survive" and after that I felt totally cool and calm and did what had to be done. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: unfriendly
dictionaryExamples: She was very cool towards us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I encouraged him to tell me what was going on and I could hardly believe [it] when he explained the reason why he had been treating me in a cool manner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to remain calm in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: To be successful in business, you need to keep a cool head in negotiations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Kevin managed to keep a cool head and took over the navigation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to become less hot, or to make something become less hot
dictionaryExamples: Allow the bread to cool before slicing it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the summer many people were delighted by fountains which cooled the air. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to become less hot, or to make someone or something become less hot
dictionaryExamples: She waited until her coffee had cooled down and then took a sip.
We went for a swim to cool off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The pool is a very popular place to cool down [in]. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to become calmer, or to make someone become calmer
dictionaryExamples: Just leave her to cool off and then talk to her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seemed to me that you were stressed.  If I were you, I would cool down a little. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to remain calm
dictionaryExamples: You did well to keep your cool in all that panic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whatever the problem is, keep your cool, don't panic. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to suddenly become very angry
dictionaryExamples: She lost her cool and started shouting.

sense.def: the quality of being cold
dictionaryExamples: the coolness of the breeze
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The coolness of the [bus] made me ill. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the quality of being calm
dictionaryExamples: He was admired for his coolness under pressure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, a successful person should have [their] own style and opinion to distinguish from other people, enough patience to wait for important opportunities, a certain coolness to "survive" critical situations, and last but not least, a good deal of luck, which often decides whether you are successful or not. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the quality of being unfriendly
dictionaryExamples: He was a little insulted by her coolness towards him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: James eyed her with a mixture of contempt and admiration for her coolness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to work together with someone in order to achieve the same aim
dictionaryExamples: The Spanish authorities cooperated with the British police in finding the terrorists.
Several companies are cooperating in the relief effort.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lime has become a sort of monster, with no consideration for life any more, and Martins decides to cooperate with the police to catch and kill him. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to help someone or do what they ask
dictionaryExamples: I find it very hard to dress my two-year-old when she refuses to cooperate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He tried to get on to his feet but h[i]s head refused to cooperate so he decided to sit where he was for the time being. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when you work together with someone or do what they ask you
dictionaryExamples: This documentary was made with the cooperation of the transportation authority.
There's very little cooperation between the two countries.
We thank you in advance for your cooperation.
They work in cooperation with other health care professionals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you in advance for your cooperation in this respect. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: willing to help or do what people ask
dictionaryExamples: I found them very cooperative.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can rely on me - I love children and I am energetic and cooperative. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to deal successfully with a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: How does she cope with three small children and a job?
It was too stressful and eventually he just couldn't cope.
Tires generally don't cope well on wet roads.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover she can't cope with life. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

sense.def: a reddish-brown metal used especially for making wire and coins, or the reddish brown color of this metal
dictionaryExamples: copper wire/pipes
Rosie's hair shone like copper in the sunlight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its domes are made of pure copper, inside there's a big bell called "Zygmunt". First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to produce something that is similar or exactly the same as something else
dictionaryExamples: They've copied the basic design from the Japanese model and added a few of their own refinements.
Copy the file onto disk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will copy the CD on[to] my computer. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to cheat by looking at and using someone else's work
dictionaryExamples: He was always copying from/off other children, but never got caught.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm certain she thought we had copied in the test. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to behave like someone else
dictionaryExamples: He tends to copy his brother in the way he dresses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has to eat salads now, in [the] hope [that] the kids'll copy his attitudes and eat fresh and healthy food instead of sweets and unhealthy st[u]ff. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something that has been made to be exactly like something else
dictionaryExamples: This painting is only a copy - the original hangs in the Louvre.
I always keep a copy of any official or important letters that I send off.
Could you make a copy of this for tomorrow's meeting, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For covering the work I missed, I will ask May on Thursday if I can borrow her exercise book and make a copy. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a single book, newspaper, etc. of which many have been produced
dictionaryExamples: Over a million copies of the book have been sold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The single with her new song sold more than 15 million copies, now she was a powerful star. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a hard, usually pink or white substance produced by a type of very small sea animal
dictionaryExamples: a coral reef
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main [attraction] of the place is scuba diving, due to the excellent visibility of the water and the impressive coral reefs which surround the island. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the most important part of a system or principle
dictionaryExamples: core values
Better health care was at the core of the senator's campaign.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this paper is to respond to a call for proposals [from] a TV company which is planning to launch a program called "Making the World a Better Place" and to select the group of people which represents the core idea of this program. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Czech

sense.def: the hard, central part of certain fruits, such as apples, which contains the seeds
dictionaryExamples: Peel the apples and remove the cores.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So there it was, hidden in nature, occasionally trampled by a stray dog with no other companion than old cans and apple cores. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a tall plant with yellow seeds that are eaten as food
dictionaryExamples: a corn field
I bought four ears of corn for dinner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [k]now she is a farmer and we have to plant yams, corn, be[a]ns and other crops. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the point, area or line which is formed by the meeting of two lines, surfaces, roads, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Click the icon in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.
There's a mailbox on/at the corner.
I've got a bruise where I hit my leg against the corner of the table.
They live just around the corner - so we see them all the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's at the corner of East Street and Beach Street. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: She had been in a tight corner before and had always managed to cope.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a great pressure, requiring a lot of effort and sense of humor but does work in most cases, helping to find the best way out of a tight corner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: relating to a large company or group
dictionaryExamples: corporate finance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This proposal highlights advisable amendments to the ABC Company's management structure, namely the marketing department, in view of unforeseen corporate losses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: a large company or group of companies that is controlled together as a single organization
dictionaryExamples: a multinational corporation
the Microsoft Corporation
She didn't want to work for a big corporation where everything was so impersonal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since I was a child, I've always dreamed about being a car designer in a large and powerful corporation like  Ferrari, Porsche, Mercedes-Benz, etc.  (576235; First Certificate in English; Chile; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Spanish; Spanish; Fail)

sense.def: a dead person's body
dictionaryExamples: There were several corpses in the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Evian and I just stood there and gazed at the corpse for a few hours. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: accurate, or having no mistakes
dictionaryExamples: a correct answer
Check that you have the correct information.
Is that the correct spelling?
"Your name is Angela Black?" "That is correct."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must learn more [from] English people [so] that I hear correct English. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian

sense.def: suitable for a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: correct behavior
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that is the correct option because I really like this [kind of] film! Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: to show someone the mistakes in something they have said or written
dictionaryExamples: Our teacher normally corrects our pronunciation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Until now, I have never had someone really teaching me and correcting my mistakes. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to make a mistake or problem right or better
dictionaryExamples: The new software finds and corrects any errors on the hard disk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example if I have to write a formal letter or something like this, I use my PC because the paper looks nicer and [the] computer corrects my mistakes. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a change made to something in order to correct or improve it, or when you make such a change
dictionaryExamples: I made some corrections before handing in my essay.
She was disappointed to see her essay returned with a mass of corrections in red ink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My new teacher is friendlier and he is more careful [with his] correction [of] the work and exams we do. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: in a correct way
dictionaryExamples: Have I pronounced your name correctly?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't speak English correctly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be the same or very similar
dictionaryExamples: The money I've saved corresponds roughly to the amount I need for my course.
The American FBI corresponds to the British MI5.
His story of what happened that night didn't correspond with the witness's version.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, I would like to ask you for my entrance fee, as this evening did not correspond to your advertisement. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to communicate with someone by writing letters
dictionaryExamples: They had corresponded ever since the war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Tom It would be wonderful to see you because we've been corresponding for a long time but I've never had [the] pleasure [of meeting] you. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: similar or related
dictionaryExamples: Draw a line between the words with corresponding meanings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In terms of the consequences for society as a whole, an increase in life expectancy might pose problems if the percentage of old people increases without being accompanied by a corresponding increase in the birth rate. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a long passage in a building or train
dictionaryExamples: Her office is at the end of the corridor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The invigilator left the room and walked down the corridor looking for some help. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: dishonest or illegal
dictionaryExamples: a corrupt government
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am not saying he is corrupt - I don't believe that - but he com[m]ands many corrupt people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone or something become dishonest or immoral
dictionaryExamples: He became corrupted by power and money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe wealth can corrupt people's mind[s] and make people weak. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: dishonest or immoral behavior, usually by people in positions of power
dictionaryExamples: He was arrested for corruption and bribery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that both have lost respect because of corruption. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when you cause someone or something to become dishonest or immoral
dictionaryExamples: the corruption of innocent young children
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The contrast between those two groups was getting bigger and bigger and it ended up [in] a destructive war, destructive doesn't refer only to deaths and city damage but also to the corruption of morals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: consisting of people and things from many different countries
dictionaryExamples: London is a very cosmopolitan city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I chose London because it's a cosmopolitan city, and very near to the other European countries. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: the amount of money that you need to buy or do something
dictionaryExamples: The cost of building materials has risen.
The cruise ship was built at a cost of $400 million.
Software is included at no extra cost.
The supermarket chain announced that it was cutting the cost of all its fresh and frozen meat.
The cost of living has gone up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The country [is] still the same, the cost of living [is] still high.Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: something that you give or lose, in order to get or achieve something else
dictionaryExamples: He rescued four people at the cost of his own life.
She finally got the job she wanted, but at great personal cost.
It's not worth getting into an argument with Tim, as I learned to my cost.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We wanted to travel by car and, to my cost, my friend began to drive the car. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If something must be done at all costs, it is very important that it is done.
dictionaryExamples: We have to succeed at all costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One thing was sure: he was convinced [he had] to save Anne's life at all costs. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If something costs an amount of money, you must pay that amount to buy or do it.
dictionaryExamples: How much did your bike cost?
The trip will cost you $1000.
It costs a lot to buy a house in this part of London.
It cost me £200 just to get it fixed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How much does it cost? Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: to cause someone to lose or destroy something valuable
dictionaryExamples: Drinking and driving costs lives.
His affairs cost him his marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, many people are talking about car accidents which cost human lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a set of clothes worn in order to look like someone else, especially for a party or a film or play
dictionaryExamples: actors in costume
a clown costume
The children were dressed in Halloween costumes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything becomes alive with music and dancing, and everybody wears amazing costumes. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: the set of clothes typical of a particular country or period of history
dictionaryExamples: Japanese national costume
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You also can take some terrific [ph]otographs of national costumes, hear music and take part in dances. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a small house, usually in the countryside
dictionaryExamples: They live in a country cottage, with roses around the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in a typical Norwegian cottage with a huge fireplace, and everything is natural and simple. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: cloth or thread made from the fibers of the cotton plant
dictionaryExamples: a shirt made of pure cotton
a simple cotton dress
cotton  sheets
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Normally, I would prefer my blouses to be made of cotton or silk as these materials make me [feel] comfortable. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: a long, comfortable seat that is large enough for two or  more people
dictionaryExamples: The kids are sitting on the couch, watching television.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was fun, we were sitting there on the couch eating popcorn. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: to force air out of your lungs through your throat with a short loud sound
dictionaryExamples: The smoke made me cough.
I coughed all night long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I kept coughing, my nose kept running! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: when you cough or an illness that makes you cough
dictionaryExamples: a dry cough
Emily has a nasty cough.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because of swimming so much I got a terrible cough and so I had to be sent back to school so that I could be treated properly. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used as the past form of "can" to talk about what someone or something was able to do
dictionaryExamples: When I was younger I could stay up all night and not get tired.
It was so noisy that we couldn't hear ourselves talk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't find the information [either] but I phoned the school. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used as a more polite form of "can" when asking someone to provide something or do something
dictionaryExamples: Could you lend me $5?
Could you turn the music down a little, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could you please send it? Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used for making a suggestion
dictionaryExamples: We could go for a drink after work tomorrow, if you like.
You could always call Susie and see if she would babysit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could take you to a nice hotel. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: used to talk about what will possibly happen or is possibly true
dictionaryExamples: She could arrive any time now.
A lot of crime could be prevented.
This new drug could be an important step in the fight against cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This could be a big advantage but on the other [hand], books contain more details and sometimes some parts of the book are cut out [in] the film. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used as a more polite form of "can" when asking for permission
dictionaryExamples: Could I speak to Mr. Davis, please?
Excuse me, could I just say something here?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could I bring you the missing work [to the] next class? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to talk about things that possibly happened in the past or might possibly have happened by some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: She could have been killed.
Let's go to the coast anyway - the rain could have stopped by the time we get there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then they thought about the situation and tried to [develop] a theor[y] about what could have happened with the dead body and who could be the murderer. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to express certainty that something in the past was impossible or didn't happen
dictionaryExamples: He couldn't have damaged your bike - he was with me all evening.
That book couldn't have been on sale last week - it only come out today!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The blood froze in our veins, and we were all sure that it couldn't have been anything but a ghost! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the group of people elected to govern a particular area, town or city, and organize services for it
dictionaryExamples: the New York City Council
The town/city council is responsible for keeping the streets clean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, we all know that all this can't be done by our city council without our support. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: one or more of the lawyers taking part in a case or legally representing a person or organization
dictionaryExamples: counsel for the corporation
defense counsel
Maloney skipped the meeting on the advice of counsel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As counsel for the prosecution insisted on severe punishment; John was sent to serve his sentence in one of the worst jails in the country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the job or process of listening to people and giving them advice about their problems
dictionaryExamples: a counseling service
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to this fact we were always tired and annoyed and our children were not able to concentrate on their homework, they were nervous, noisy, and hyperactive and finally they had to go to a psychiatrist for counseling. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: someone whose job is to give people advice and help
dictionaryExamples: a marriage/guidance counselor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A year ago my mother found an advertisement in a newspaper: some American directors of a summer camp were looking for [i]nexperienced but willing to work counselors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to see how many people or things there are
dictionaryExamples: The teachers counted the students as they got on the bus.
Count your money carefully to make sure it's all there.
We're still waiting for the votes to be counted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I counted them and there were 5 suitcases. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to say numbers in their correct order
dictionaryExamples: Can you count to ten in French?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What he told me is "If you have any wishes, count 1 to 100 every Sunday for one month". Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to be important
dictionaryExamples: I've always believed that happiness counts more than money.
My opinion doesn't count for anything around here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't romantic, there were no flowers but Carla knew [that] what counts is in the h[e]art. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: to think of someone or something in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: She counted Tim as her closest friend.
You should count yourself lucky you weren't hurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a way, I think I should count myself very lucky. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to be accepted or allowed as part of something
dictionaryExamples: I've been to sixteen different countries, but I only spent half an hour in Luxembourg, so that doesn't really count.

sense.def: to include something or someone in a calculation
dictionaryExamples: There are 1500 people at my school, counting teachers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was not until I married Paul that I began to receive a bunch of telephone calls from my closest relatives, not counting my mother because she had [already] become a part of our house. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to forget how many of something there is
dictionaryExamples: I've lost count of how many of times she's been late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I lost count [of] how often I heard this sentence when I used to work for a drug company. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when you count something, or the total number you get after counting
dictionaryExamples: At the last count there were 410 club members.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At the] last count they still had 5 thousand dollars and one night to spend it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to include someone in an activity
dictionaryExamples: If you're going for a pizza, you can count me in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can always count her in. She is always there by my side. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to have confidence in someone because you know they will do what you want
dictionaryExamples: I can always count on my parents to help me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So Jan, I'm sure I can count on you. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to expect something to happen and make plans based on it
dictionaryExamples: I didn't count on so many people coming to the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This town can always count on the same quality and variety of films as any other city in the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be part of what is needed to complete something or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: This essay counts toward my final grade.

blocks.phrasalVerb: count up sb/sth or count sb/sth up

sense.def: to add together all the people or things in a group
dictionaryExamples: If you count up all the money in your various savings accounts, it is quite a large sum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People might not consider food to be of great importance, but it surely is, especially counting up all the hours we spend in kitchens or in supermarkets (looking for food, thinking of what we might fancy having for dinner). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a long, flat, narrow surface or table in a store, bank, restaurant, etc. at which people are served
dictionaryExamples: There was nobody at/behind the counter when I went into the bank, and I had to wait.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At McDonalds you buy food at a counter and take your seat, listening to a modern music. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a small disc used in some games that are played on a board
dictionaryExamples: Move the counter forward two squares.

sense.def: to have an effect opposite to something else
dictionaryExamples: David’s decision to drop out of school to write plays ran counter to his parent’s expectations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The saying goes "money can't buy happiness." [H]owever, he seems to run counter to these tenets since he leads quite a pleasant life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: someone or something that has the same job or position as someone or something in a different place or organization
dictionaryExamples: I had a meeting with my counterpart in our other branch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel much more confident at work in terms of both my English and the ability to negotiate with my counterparts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: very many
dictionaryExamples: The song has been played countless times on the radio.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are countless reasons why I support this view, I would like to mention a few of [the] important ones here. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a noun that can be used in the singular and the plural
dictionaryExamples: Count nouns are shown here with [C].

sense.def: an area of land that has its own government, army, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Which is the largest country in South America?
Sri Lanka is my native country, but I've been living in Belgium for the past five years.
The climate is cooler in the eastern part of the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really like this day in my country. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: land that is not in towns, cities or industrial areas and is either used for farming or left in its natural condition
dictionaryExamples: He lives out in the country somewhere.
Would you prefer to live in the country instead in town?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's in the country, near Sopramonte. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the people who live in a country
dictionaryExamples: The country was shocked by the President's decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The country was partying for two weeks. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: land that is not in towns, cities or industrial areas and is either used for farming or left in its natural condition
dictionaryExamples: The countryside around there is beautiful.
The house is set in 90 acres of beautiful, unspoiled countryside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the countryside is very lovely to visit, too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Albanian

sense.def: the largest political division of a state or country
dictionaryExamples: County Antrim
Westchester County
A county usually consists of several cities and towns and the rural areas surrounding them.
Rutland used to be the smallest county in England, but in 1974 it became part of Leicestershire.
Texas is divided into 254 counties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since my family originates from the county of Dalarna, where "Dal" paintings are both very popular and common, I have started to paint a little on my own. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when a group of people suddenly takes control of a country using force
dictionaryExamples: a military coup
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The government of the country was formed three years ago after a military coup and is constituted primarily by the nephews of General Tomba, who headed the rebellious troops during the coup. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: two or a few
dictionaryExamples: He'll be better in a couple of days.
I'm going away with a couple of friends.
We'll have to wait another couple of hours for the paint to dry.
She'll be retiring in a couple more years.
The weather's been terrible for the last couple of days.
Many economists expect unemployment to fall over the next couple of months.
I've been so busy over the past couple of weeks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went there a couple of times and I would love to go once more. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: two people who are married or in a romantic or sexual relationship, or two people who are together for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a married couple
A young couple walked into the bar.
The couple skated well throughout the competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The couple can say what they want to eat on their [wedding] day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the ability to deal with a dangerous or difficult situation without being frightened
dictionaryExamples: I wanted to talk to him, but I didn't have the courage.
People should  have the courage to stand up for their beliefs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He [had] wanted to do it for a long time but never had the courage. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: brave
dictionaryExamples: a courageous decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The people were very courageous and showed an extraordinary sense of calm. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a set of classes or a plan of study in a particular subject, usually a part of a program of study for a diploma, certificate, or degree
dictionaryExamples: a writing/math/English, etc. course
Mike's six-month paralegal course ends in December.
Which course did you register for/enroll in?
Judy is taking an online course in medical records management.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like my ESOL course because I want to learn more English and improve my English. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to say "yes" and emphasize your answer
dictionaryExamples: "Can you help me?" "Of course!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes of course I can come. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a part of a meal which is served separately from the other parts
dictionaryExamples: a four-course lunch
For my main course, I had fish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For a main course we like potato with some meat. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: used to say "no" and emphasize your answer
dictionaryExamples: "Do you mind if I borrow your pen?" "Of course not."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Pardon. You said your [u]ncle's will? Would you mind explaining [that], please?" "Of course not!" First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to show that what you are saying is obvious or already known
dictionaryExamples: Of course, the Olympics are not just about money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I met many new people. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an area of land or water used for a sports event
dictionaryExamples: a golf course
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a very nice club, it has 20 tennis courts, 2 soccer fields and an 18-hole golf course. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something that you can do in a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: I think the best course of action would be to write to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I believe that the best course of action in this case is to give our student a refund. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: during a particular time or activity
dictionaryExamples: He always chats with waiters and waitresses and becomes their best friends during the course of dinner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the course of my studies and internship, I worked not only with people suffering from certain disorders, but also with people who faced problems in interpersonal relationships. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the route that a car, ship, aircraft, etc., is following or the route a river flows along
dictionaryExamples: During the storm, the boat was blown off course.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Anyway, you will drive a certain course with an examiner, who will [check] your skills. The best way to prepare for this test is to drive the same course several times before the test.  
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: If something happens as a matter of course, it always happens as part of the normal process or system.
dictionaryExamples: Babies were tested for the disease as a matter of course.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The transform[ation] has succeeded so far and caused enormous changes in ordinary life as a matter of course, including eating habits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: the way something develops, usually over a long time
dictionaryExamples: Nuclear weapons have changed the course of modern history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Civilizations have appeared changing the course of history and they have also disappeared, but they have all left something as a heritage or a legacy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an area drawn out on the ground that is used for playing sports such as tennis and basketball
dictionaryExamples: a tennis/basketball/squash court
They were penalized for having too many players on the court.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stayed in a hotel with [a] swimming pool, tennis court and private beach. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: the place where a judge decides whether someone is guilty of a crime
dictionaryExamples: He's due to appear in court again on Monday.
Please describe to the court exactly what you saw.
the Court of Appeals
the European Court of Human Rights
The lack of evidence means that the case is unlikely to go to court.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two days after, I went to the law court as a witness. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: polite and showing respect
dictionaryExamples: We received a very courteous reply.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The library staff deserve congratulations: they are all very courteous and helpful. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: polite behavior
dictionaryExamples: The hotel staff must treat guests with courtesy at all times.
He could have at least had the courtesy to say he's sorry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As McDonald's is a fast food restaurant, the service is speedy, but courtesy is sometimes poor. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a child of a person's aunt or uncle
dictionaryExamples: My brother's wife and I both had babies around the same time, so the cousins are very close in age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could help you with the instruments, [as] my cousin has a music shop. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to put something over something else, in order to protect or hide it
dictionaryExamples: The light was so bright that I had to cover my eyes.
She covered him (up)with a blanket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bring a cap or somet[h]ing to cover your hair. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: to form a layer on the surface of something
dictionaryExamples: Snow covered the hillside.
Cover the pasta with a layer of sauce.
The bandages were covered with/in blood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The hills are covered by the snow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: to deal with or include a subject or piece of information
dictionaryExamples: This leaflet covers what we've just discussed in more detail.
The book covers European history from 1789 to 1914.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Teacher, I'm sorry but I won't be able to go to the English class tomorrow. But I can go another day to cover the work I've missed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to travel a particular distance
dictionaryExamples: We covered 150 miles in four days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not even sure if I [can] manage to cover 60 km. I agree with Chris completely, it will be too difficult. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be a particular size or area
dictionaryExamples: The town covers an area of 5 square miles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other suggestion is the flower market, wh[ich] is very famous for tourists because it covers 2 acres and there are plenty of flowers to buy. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to report the news about a particular important event
dictionaryExamples: She's covering the US election for BBC television.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should you have your company's channel cover the [event], your profits from the advertis[e]ments will be innumerable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to provide financial protection if something bad happens
dictionaryExamples: travel insurance that covers accident and injury

sense.def: to be enough money to pay for something
dictionaryExamples: One hundred dollars should cover the cost of the repairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This means that only 15% was [allocat]ed to cover the cost of entertainment and administration costs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

blocks.phrasalVerb: cover sth up or cover up sth

sense.def: to put something over something else, in order to protect or hide it
dictionaryExamples: We used a picture to cover up a hole in the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've seen numerous black and white photographs of my grandparents in traditional Japanese kimonos, covering up their body parts as much as possible. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to stop people from discovering the truth about something bad
dictionaryExamples: She tried to cover up her mistakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Realizing too late that it was the wrong piece of music he was playing, he tried to cover it up, so the audience would not know he had made a mistake. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: the outer part of a book, magazine, etc., that protects the pages
dictionaryExamples: Her picture is on the cover of several magazines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I received it for Christmas [in] 1991, and I immediately decided to write [my name and my address on]  the cover. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: something you put over something else, usually to protect it
dictionaryExamples: I keep my computer printer under a protective plastic cover.
an ironing board cover

sense.def: financial protection so that you get money if something bad happens
dictionaryExamples: The policy provides $150,000 accidental damage cover.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A mere 2% went on insurance cover. International English Language Testing System; C1; Creole

sense.def: protection from bad weather or an attack
dictionaryExamples: They took cover under some trees until the rain stopped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bodyguards immediately reacted, shooting at the window through which Paul had fired, while the judge took cover under a near car. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

blocks.phrase: not judge a book by its cover

sense.def: to not decide what someone or something is like only by looking at them
dictionaryExamples: You know, his desk is a mess but don't judge a book by it's cover, he does careful, detailed work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm simply pointing out one should never judge a book by it's cover as things aren't alway[s] what they seem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the way a newspaper, television program, etc. reports an event or subject
dictionaryExamples: There is live coverage of the game on cable TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jos is very well known among people who love Formula 2 autoracing and I know there are a lot of them all over the world because of the intense media coverage. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a large female farm animal kept to produce meat and milk
dictionaryExamples: a dairy cow
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this house because  there [aren't any neighbors], just cows and fields. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: someone who is not brave and tries to avoid dangerous or difficult situations
dictionaryExamples: You didn't talk to her? You coward!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of behaving like a wise grown-up, I behaved like a coward. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: behaving in a way that shows you are not brave
dictionaryExamples: This was a particularly brutal and cowardly attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bernard was usually weak, depressed, cowardly and pessimistic, but, on the other hand, when he became popular and famous by taking advantage of John, he was so boastful. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: comfortable and warm
dictionaryExamples: This cabin stays warm and cozy all winter.
He led me into a cozy little room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Right now I am staying in a beautiful hotel by a glistening lake. It is warm and cozy. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a sea creature with ten legs and a round, flat body covered by a shell, or the meat from this animal
dictionaryExamples: crab salad
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children can look at live fis[h], crabs and lobsters. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to break something so that very thin lines appear on its surface but it does not separate, or to become broken in this way
dictionaryExamples: A stone hit the window and cracked the glass.
I cracked my tooth when I fell.
The walls cracked and the roof collapsed in the earthquake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bottom tank cracked and the sea-water poured into the tank and further into the engine-room. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to tell a joke
dictionaryExamples: He seemed very relaxed, laughing and cracking jokes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many members will get the chance to show their talent and we will get to crack some jokes too! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to start dealing with bad or illegal behavior in a more severe way
dictionaryExamples: Police are cracking down on crime in the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Introducing a totally new policy, dismissing the members of the parliament and cracking down on the leftist underworld, he proved to be a person really dedicated [to] the country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to become mentally ill
dictionaryExamples: We're worried he'll crack up completely if he doesn't get help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, one must also bear in mind the fact that, since Douglas was overworked, Olivia had a tedious, boring life and was about to crack up, when the Nawab came to res[c]ue her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to laugh a lot or to make someone laugh a lot
dictionaryExamples: His impressions of my Dad really crack me up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One film that I found hilariously funny was "Meet the Parents." Directed by Frank Oz, this film has all the qualifications to make someone crack up. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a line on the surface of something that is damaged
dictionaryExamples: Several cups had cracks in them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Behind the glass doors you could see a Chinese tea-set totally unsuitable for tea drinking as all the cups had cracks but I wasn't allowed to throw [it] away because it had been presented by some relative and that was enough to turn it into an everlasting treasure. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: very early in the morning
dictionaryExamples: He gets up at the crack of dawn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the crack of dawn until bed time citizens have to breathe all kinds of gas coming out of cars, [motor]bikes or [factor]ies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when bad or illegal behavior is dealt with in a very severe way, in order to stop it happening
dictionaryExamples: The police will begin a crackdown on speeding over the holiday weekend.

sense.def: a  flat, dry, small baked bread
dictionaryExamples: cheese and crackers
Do you want some crackers with the soup?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll make some food to eat and buy some crackers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: an activity in which you make something using a lot of skill, especially with your hands
dictionaryExamples: the craft of furniture-making/boat-building
rural/ancient/traditional crafts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will find some interesting Swedish craft work [there] and get the best shots of the local people. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to have an accident in a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: He skidded on the ice and crashed into another car.
The plane crashed into a field.
Her brother borrowed her motorbike and crashed it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I crashed my car and here in my city the bus is terrib[le]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If a computer or computer system crashes, it suddenly stops working.
dictionaryExamples: My computer keeps crashing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will the computers crash after New Year? First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If a financial market crashes, prices suddenly fall by a large amount.
dictionaryExamples: They lost all their savings when the market crashed.

sense.def: an accident in which a vehicle hits something
dictionaryExamples: a car/plane crash
They had a crash on the way to work.
She died in a car crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi, as you know I had a car crash and my car is damaged. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a sudden, loud noise made when something falls or breaks
dictionaryExamples: I heard a crash and hurried into the kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A loud crash disturbed the silence of the night. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when the value of a country's businesses suddenly falls by a large amount
dictionaryExamples: He lost a lot of money in the stock market crash of 1929.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Regarding the economy of the globe, this intensiv[e] trad[ing] may lead to a worldwide crash. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: to want something very much
dictionaryExamples: a child who craves affection
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These people tend to forget the essence of man's heart, which craves only for love, and kindness, and friendship, and loyalty. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a strong feeling that you want or need something
dictionaryExamples: She had a craving for something salty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a well-known fact that many women of all ages sometimes have a craving for chocolate. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to move on your hands and knees
dictionaryExamples: The child crawled across the floor.
The injured soldier crawled to safety.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I crawled out from under the bed and stood [u]p. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If an insect crawls, it uses its legs to move.
dictionaryExamples: There's an ant crawling up your leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is sort of dusting off her legs and skirt. We can't actually see what is happening. We get there to find out that tens of big red ants are crawling on to her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be full of insects or people in a way that is unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: The kitchen's crawling with ants.

sense.def: a very slow speed
dictionaryExamples: Traffic slowed to a crawl.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every morning traffic w[as] reduced to a crawl. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a style of swimming in which you move your arms over your head and kick with straight legs
dictionaryExamples: front/back crawl
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can already swim breaststroke and crawl but I am unable to swim backstroke and the dolphin-like style. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the state of being crazy
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't stand the craziness of their household.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My home might, for an outsider, give the feeling of complete disorder, not to say craziness but I can assure you that it was not true at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: stupid or strange
dictionaryExamples: It's a crazy idea.
You're crazy to buy a house without seeing it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At] the party, we danced, sang and we played many crazy games. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to love someone very much, or to be very interested in something
dictionaryExamples: Mia's crazy about baseball.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm crazy about rap music. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to become very excited about something
dictionaryExamples: When he came on stage the audience went crazy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So when our teachers told us yesterday that a TV company would come and film this project and do interviews with us, everybody went crazy. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: annoyed or angry
dictionaryExamples: The constant noise drove me crazy.
Dad went crazy when I told him what had happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Be careful because you know computers drive me crazy. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: doing something a lot or in a fast way
dictionaryExamples: We worked like crazy to get everything finished.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My heart was beating like crazy and when the ski-boat started its journey along the blue waves of the sea... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the thick yellowish-white liquid that is taken from milk
dictionaryExamples: strawberries and cream
Do you like cream in your coffee?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For dessert [I like] ice-cream with cream and chocolate sauce. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a yellowish-white color
dictionaryExamples: We chose cream for the walls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going paint my bedroom cream in col[o]r. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: a soft substance that you rub into your skin
dictionaryExamples: face/hand cream
moisturizing cream

sense.def: the best people or things in a particular group
dictionaryExamples: the cream of Milan's designers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, many Japanese style hotels and restaurants now have square holes in tatami (straw mat) rooms so that foreign visitors can comfortably stretch their legs under the low table without having to be seated on folded legs like Zen monks! Thus you will find it easier to enjoy the cream of Japanese hospitality without tears. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: having a yellowish-white color
dictionaryExamples: a cream shirt
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, here in Spain the woman always wear[s] a white or cream dress. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make something happen or exist
dictionaryExamples: The project will create more than 500 jobs.
Charles Schulz created the characters "Snoopy" and "Charlie Brown."
He created a wonderful meal from very few ingredients.
It's important to create a good impression when you meet a new client.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had to create a new website for the club, and everybody seemed to have great fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the act of creating something, or the thing that is created
dictionaryExamples: the creation of a new political party
Their policies are all toward the creation of wealth.
This 25-foot-high sculpture is her latest creation.
The fashion magazines were full of the latest Paris creations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, since the creation of the virtual world internet, computers [have been] used to communicate very quickly from [one] computer to another. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: producing or using original and unusual ideas
dictionaryExamples: She's very creative.
creative talents/powers/abilities
creative thinking
Her book is full of creative ways to decorate the home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love to be creative. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: in a creative way
dictionaryExamples: We have to think creatively about this problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that our college should have some of this kind of activities, so that students can spend their time creatively. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the ability to produce new ideas or things using skill and imagination
dictionaryExamples: I admire her creativity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Realistic stories thus, develop our imagination and creativity, which are essential in our lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: anything that lives but is not a plant
dictionaryExamples: Rain forests are filled with amazing creatures.
Don't all living creatures have certain rights?
Blue whales are the largest living creatures.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are some sea creatures (some are poisonous) that you have to avoid. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: when someone can be believed and trusted
dictionaryExamples: This decision has damaged the President's credibility.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The media source and its credibility play a major role in determining the objectivity and realistic portrayal although there ha[ve] been cases where even mainstream publications have participated in manipulative alterations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an amount owed to you and available for you to use on goods or for a service
dictionaryExamples: The coat was the wrong size so I returned it and now I have a credit.
How much credit do you have on your cell phone?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will talk to you on the phone [in a] week['s] time as I [don't] have enough credit. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: a method of paying for goods or services at a later time, usually paying interest as well as the original money
dictionaryExamples: They decided to buy the sofa on credit.
The shop was offering six months' interest-free credit on kitchen appliances.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father spent lots of money without [having the] cash. Unfortunately a credit loan company helped him. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: praise, approval or honor
dictionaryExamples: I did all the work and Amy got the credit for it!
I suppose I should  give him credit for  his honesty.
I can't take full credit for this meal - Sam did quite a bit too
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took part in this event and I think that you haven't given it enough credit. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a unit that shows you have completed a college course
dictionaryExamples: The Italian class is a 5-credit course and meets 4 days a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "How could you get such a result?" her father barked, after seeing her report card which stated only two credits. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If something is to someone's credit, they deserve praise for it.
dictionaryExamples: To his credit, Bill never blamed her for the incident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He also has good sportsmanship, to his credit. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: a small plastic card that allows you to buy something and pay for it later
dictionaryExamples: I paid by credit card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The wallet contains all my credit cards and my ticket to London. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: the people who work together on a ship, aircraft or train
dictionaryExamples: cabin crew
a crew member
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was going back I saw the crew from my plane. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a team of people with special skills who work together
dictionaryExamples: an ambulance/lifeboat crew
a film/camera crew
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend that you and your film crew visit Zurich during August, because it's very cold and the weather is mostly bad in January. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a sport in which two teams of eleven players try to score points by hitting a small ball with a bat, and running between two sets of small wooden posts
dictionaryExamples: a cricket ball/bat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played cricket at the party. Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: an insect that jumps and makes a noise by rubbing its wings together
dictionaryExamples: We could hear the crickets in the grass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The distant chirping of crickets w[as] music to my ears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: illegal activities
dictionaryExamples: crime prevention
serious/violent crime
We need tough new measures to fight crime.
a life of crime
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem is the pollution and the crime. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an illegal act
dictionaryExamples: He admitted committing several crimes, including two robberies.
The defendant is accused of/charged with arson.
A knife was found at the scene of the crime.
Bombing civilians is a crime against humanity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's about the police [in] Los Angeles, I think, trying to discover how the criminals d[id] the crimes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who commits a crime
dictionaryExamples: a dangerous/violent criminal
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At least he didn't attack me, and he even lent me his cell phone, he was such a gentle criminal. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to crime
dictionaryExamples: criminal activity
a criminal act/offence
a criminal investigation
I didn't know he had a criminal record.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of his criminal background I came to believe that man and also like him. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a situation or time that is extremely dangerous or difficult
dictionaryExamples: an economic/financial crisis
The country's leadership is in crisis.
We had a family crisis at the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is [a] crisis not only for animals but also [for] the planet. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: Crisp cloth or paper money is clean and looks new, with no folds.
dictionaryExamples: a crisp linen shirt
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first impression is that of quiet elegance with white table cloths, crisp napkins, lovely pastel flowers on the tables and thick carpeting on the floors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: Crisp weather is pleasantly cold and dry.
dictionaryExamples: a crisp autumn day
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was one of these beautiful crisp September days when the woods are adorned in autumnal browns and golds. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a fact or level of quality that you use when making a choice or decision
dictionaryExamples: We have strict criteria for deciding which students will receive a grant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please do contact me if you have similar apartments under [the] criteria I have mentioned above. International English Language Testing System; C1; Azerbaijani

sense.def: someone whose job is to give their opinion about something, especially movies, books, music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a film/theater/music critic
The play has been well received by the critics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "The Blind Owl" - his masterpiece - is a surrealistic novella which has amused critics and ordinary readers for years. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: someone who says that they do not approve of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: an outspoken critic of the government
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am not a critic of modern technology and I am not among those people who have pessimistic id[e]as about it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: saying that someone or something is bad or wrong
dictionaryExamples: a critical report
The report is highly critical of safety standards at the factory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them are very critical [of] their food. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: of the greatest importance to the way things might happen
dictionaryExamples: The President's support is critical to this project.
a critical decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a critical moment. Tom realized that we have to do something or [the] problems would be wors[e]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: extremely serious or dangerous
dictionaryExamples: The doctors said her condition was critical and she might not survive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doctor only said she was critical, not dead! Preliminary English Test; B1; Assamese

sense.def: giving careful judgments and opinions on something
dictionaryExamples: a critical study of Tennyson's work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, teachers and professors give us the opportunity to broaden our knowledge, sharpen our critical thought and in general to cultivate our mind and soul. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is critical
dictionaryExamples: They were both critically injured in the crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cars are even more important for emergency situations such as [a] fire in a house or if somebody is critically ill.  First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when you say that something or someone is bad
dictionaryExamples: The designs for the new building have attracted widespread criticism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another criticism is that there were not enough plays and films. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to say that someone or something is bad
dictionaryExamples: The government is being criticized by the press for failing to pass air pollution legislation.
The film was criticized for being too violent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion zoos are a dated institution.  Many people have criticized this form of entertainment. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a large reptile with a long mouth and sharp teeth, that lives in lakes and rivers
dictionaryExamples: a crocodile-infested swamp
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend started to walk into the water when suddenly a crocodile grabbed her leg. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a plant such as a grain, fruit or vegetable that is grown in large amounts, or the amount of plants of a particular type that are produced at one time
dictionaryExamples: The main crops grown for export are coffee and rice.
We had a bumper potato crop this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can do lots of things that you can't do in the city, such as plant crops. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to go across from one side of something to the other
dictionaryExamples: It's not a good place to cross the road.
Look both ways before crossing (the street).
Cross the bridge and turn right at the first traffic light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] train station is near my home. Just cross the road and t[ur]n Left and you['ll] see [it] in front of you. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Kurdish

sense.def: If an idea crosses your mind, you think about it for a short time.
dictionaryExamples: It never crossed my mind that she might be married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first thought that crossed his mind was to call the police immediately and that was what he actually did. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to travel over a border or line into a different area, country, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They crossed from Albania into Greece.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was when I was about to cross the U.S. border that I faced my greatest challenge. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: keep your fingers crossed/cross your fingers

sense.def: to hope that things will happen in the way that you want them to, and to put a finger over the one next to it as a sign of that hope
