dictionaryExamples: Let's keep our fingers crossed that she gets the job.
We're crossing our fingers and hoping that the weather stays fine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wish me luck, Winnie," she sighed "keep your fingers crossed, please." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to meet someone, especially by accident
dictionaryExamples: Mike has moved away and I doubt he'll ever cross my path again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are all sociali[z]ed by our peers, family and other people who cross our path at one time or another. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a written mark (x), usually used to show where something is, or that something has not been written correctly
dictionaryExamples: Put a cross next to the name of the person you are voting for.

sense.def: two pieces of wood that cross each other, on which people were left to die in the past as a punishment, or an object in this shape, used as a symbol of the Christian religion
dictionaryExamples: She wears a gold cross around her neck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's the reason why this little cross is so importan[t] to me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Dutch

sense.def: a place where people can go across a road, river, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a pedestrian crossing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The taxi driver shouted at every pedestrian crossing. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a trip across water
dictionaryExamples: regular ferry crossings from Tenerife to Gran Canaria
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the ferry there are rest[a]urants and a Tax-Free Shop. The crossing takes about 50 minutes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a place where two roads cross each other
dictionaryExamples: Turn left at the crossroads.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you go out of the hotel, turn right [and] at the first crossroads turn right again. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a large group of people who have come together
dictionaryExamples: A large crowd gathered outside the pop star's hotel.
Shop early to avoid the crowds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can become [a] volunteer to control the crowds. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: to stand together in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: Protesters crowded the streets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, this is not the case in big cities, since inhabitants from all over the world crowd their streets. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: If a place is crowded, it is full of people.
dictionaryExamples: By ten o'clock the market was crowded.
a crowded room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However I think that you [should] get there by car because the bus is crowded. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: extremely important or necessary
dictionaryExamples: a crucial decision/question
Her work has been crucial to the project's success.
It is crucial that the problem is tackled immediately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Clothes [play] a crucial part in our everyday lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: made or done in a simple way and without much skill
dictionaryExamples: a crude device/weapon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Glancing at the crude plan of the building I realised I ha[d] no choice but to search every room in order to find the required documents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: rude and offensive
dictionaryExamples: a crude comment/remark
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A necessary condition, of course, is a ban on crude words or meanings, as, funnier though such word may make programs of this sort, they also render them inappropriate for younger listeners. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: extremely unkind and unpleasant and causing pain to people or animals intentionally
dictionaryExamples: Don't tease him about his weight - it's cruel.
Children can be very cruel to each other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The terrorists [in the film] are very cruel and also have an atomic weapon. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in a cruel way
dictionaryExamples: She had been very cruelly treated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many young people and children go and look at various kinds of animals cruelly [held] behind the bars. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: cruel behavior or a cruel action
dictionaryExamples: The farmer was accused of cruelty to animals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  The methods he used to become the farm leader, the way he ignored the seven commandments, make him cruel - a cruelty he took to the extreme, causing damage to everyone living [on] the farm except to himself. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a vacation on a large ship, sailing from place to place
dictionaryExamples: My parents are going on a cruise this summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luca gave it to me last year, during our romantic cruise. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to go on a cruise or boat trip
dictionaryExamples: They're cruising around the Caribbean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The end-of-conference party will take place on a boat cruising on the lake. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to break into small pieces, or to make something break into small pieces
dictionaryExamples: Buildings crumbled as the earthquake struck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's completely impossible to sleep under those circumstances: a horrible howling that is so loud you can't even hear yourself think; a house that trembles so fiercely you think it's going to crumble any second in front of your very bulging eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to press something so hard that it is made flat or broken into pieces
dictionaryExamples: Her car was crushed by a falling tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, in the last chapters, one notices that Ralph and Piggy have become insepara[ble] friends, a friendship which is abruptly terminated by that huge rock that also crushes the conch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a crowd of people forced to stand close together because there is not enough room
dictionaryExamples: Many people fell over in the crush.

sense.def: a strong temporary feeling of love for someone
dictionaryExamples: Tim has a crush on Jennifer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that one of his friends had a crush on me and wanted to know if I liked him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to produce tears from your eyes, usually because you are sad, angry or hurt
dictionaryExamples: I could hear someone crying in the next room.
"There, there, don't cry," she said.
We all laughed until we cried.
He cried for joy when he heard that his son had been found alive and well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He always cries and I'm very sad [about] it. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to say something loudly
dictionaryExamples: "Look out!" she cried.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cried out his name. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: If someone cries their eyes out, they cry a lot about a problem or situation.
dictionaryExamples: When she heard the fire had destroyed the houses, she cried her eyes out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She passed away when I was six years old.  I cried my eyes out. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who gives you sympathy when you are upset
dictionaryExamples: I always had a shoulder to cry on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am always there for her and I know I will always have a shoulder to cry on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to need something very much
dictionaryExamples: a school that's crying out for more money
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had the unhappiest look I've ever seen and one could see through her brown, almond-shaped eyes that she was crying out for affection and love. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to shout or make a loud noise because you are frightened, hurt, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She cried out in pain as she fell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The guide ended this bit of information and led the people out of the corridor when one young child cried out in terror. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a shout, especially one that shows someone is frightened, hurt, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a cry of pain
I could hear the cries of children playing in the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. The cry came from the VIP-entrance. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

blocks.phrase: be a far cry from sth

sense.def: to be very different from something
dictionaryExamples: Her luxury mansion is a far cry from the house she grew up in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The museum was a far cry from what we expected. Not only were the machines really old and should have been replaced a long time ago, but they were boring as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a sound that a particular animal or bird makes
dictionaryExamples: an eagle's cry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then one could carefully pick one's way through a lot of shallow ponds, which had been concealed by the salty water before, and accompa[ni]ed by cries of seagulls, climb Castle Rock. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a long, green vegetable that you eat raw in salads
dictionaryExamples: sliced cucumber
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We ask[ed] for three burgers with cucumbers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Basque

sense.def: to prepare land and grow crops on it, or to grow as a crop
dictionaryExamples: This shrub is cultivated in Europe as a culinary herb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We're cutting down our forests to cultivate the plants which give us nourishing food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to try to develop or improve something
dictionaryExamples: She has cultivated an image as a tough negotiator.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, students are not usually encouraged to attend art or drama classes and cultivate their talents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the process of preparing land and growing crops
dictionaryExamples: The area was drained so that cultivation could begin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The basic thing is that people should [be] provided [with] better facilities for their cultivation of crops and farming, so they can earn their bread and butter in their own environment. International English Language Testing System; C1; Sindhi

sense.def: relating to the habits, traditions and beliefs of a society
dictionaryExamples: cultural diversity/differences/identity
cultural heritage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are interested in visiting historic building[s], Palermo is wonderful concerning [its] cultural and artistic heritage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: relating to music, art, theater, literature, etc.
dictionaryExamples: cultural activities/events
a cultural center
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of cultural attractions, [and] nightly discos. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: in a way that relates to culture
dictionaryExamples: It's a culturally diverse society.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I think is that Rome has to become a cultural pole, and becoming culturally vital, it will gradually look better. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the way of life, especially the habits, traditions and beliefs, of a particular group of people at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: youth culture
She's studying modern Japanese language and culture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will tell you about Korean culture when you come here. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: music, art, theater, literature, etc.
dictionaryExamples: popular culture
If you're looking for culture, this may not be the place for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would suggest you to come to visit me here in Genoa, because this is a very unusual city and this year, it is also the capital of culture. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: clever at getting what you want, especially by tricking people
dictionaryExamples: a cunning plan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a result of a cunning plan they had la[i]d months ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a small round container, often with a handle, used for drinking tea, coffee, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a cup of coffee/tea
a cup and saucer
a plastic/paper cup
a coffee cup/teacup
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like [to] drink [a] cup of tea. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: a specially designed cup, usually with two handles and often made of silver, which is given as a prize in a sports competition, or a game or match in which the winner receives such a cup
dictionaryExamples: Anna won this cup in the school squash championship.
The Davis Cup is an important championship.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This weekend we worked hard to win the ten[n]is cup. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a cabinet with shelves inside used for storing things
dictionaryExamples: a kitchen cupboard
I've put  cupboard my grandmother gave me in the entry hall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I opened my cupboard to get my hat I found your watch. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to limit or control something
dictionaryExamples: to curb crime/inflation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "If I become Prime Minister, the first issues on my political agenda will be to curb government spending on armaments, to reorgani[z]e the bureaucratic system, to reduce the rate of unemployment," he told me the last time I saw him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to make someone with an illness healthy again
dictionaryExamples: At the time, they couldn't cure the disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Harry and the other racketeers had watered down the medicine, so it was useless for curing the meningitis. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to solve a problem
dictionaryExamples: the fight to cure social inequality
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found out that this problem can be cured in only one way and that is not going to English courses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: something that makes someone with an illness healthy again
dictionaryExamples: They are trying to find a cure for cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was only an intelligent scienti[st] who looked into an AIDS cure. Laura thought he must have found something very special. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the feeling of wanting to know or learn about something
dictionaryExamples: My curiosity got the better of me and I opened the envelope.
Just out of curiosity, how did you get my address?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the warrior had left, [he] explored the cave out of curiosity and [to] his big surprise [he] found the treasure. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: wanting to know or learn about something
dictionaryExamples: I was curious to know what would happen next.
Babies are curious about everything around them.
"Why did you ask?" "I was just curious."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was curious about it, so I picked it up. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: showing that you want to know or learn more
dictionaryExamples: She looked at him curiously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everyone around looked at me curiously. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: strangely
dictionaryExamples:
Curiously, there didn't seem to be a bank in the
                         town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Curiously, a few days before the murder Emma received a letter from a French girl named Martine saying she wanted to visit them. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: shaped like a curl, or with many curls
dictionaryExamples: curly hair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has got long fair curly hair and big blue eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the money that is used in a particular country at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: foreign currency
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Take local currency in case you want to buy something. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: happening or existing now
dictionaryExamples: Is that your current address?
Have you seen the current issue of Vogue magazine?
The word "thou"  is no longer in current use.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mr Thomas, I was interested in [y]our advertisement in the current edition of "Spotlight" and I would like to apply for a job in one of your campsites. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: at the present time
dictionaryExamples: The company currently employs around 750 people.
He currently is developing a new movie project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am 22 years old and I am currently studying trade and tourism. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the group of subjects studied in a school, college, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the school curriculum
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Introducing [in] schools the system of learning only the things one enjoys would make the curriculum impossible to create. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a type of food, originally from South Asia, consisting of meat or vegetables cooked with hot spices
dictionaryExamples: a hot/mild  curry
vegetable/chicken/lamb curry
curry sauce
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the film we can go and get something to eat like curry and rice. Key English Test; A2; Somali

sense.def: a symbol on a computer screen which shows the place where you are working
dictionaryExamples: Put the cursor over the word you want to look up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The black space reserved for the answer appeared and the text cursor started to blink. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of material which hangs down to cover a window, stage, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Could you close/draw the curtains?
She opened the curtains.
Heavy curtains blocked out the sunlight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it is behind the curtains. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a line that bends around, like part of a circle
dictionaryExamples: a curve in the road
the curve of a graph
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other person was slimmer and she [had] womanly curves. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a cloth bag filled with something soft which you sit on or lean against to make you comfortable
dictionaryExamples: She sank back against/into the cushions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I['ll] go to b[u]y a nice wardrobe, a[n] armchair and a lot of cushions. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: something that protects you from possible problems
dictionaryExamples: Overseas savings provide a cushion against tax increases at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only answer for the Spanish situation is that families are acting as a cushion, by giving the youngest in working age [housing] and help. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the legal right to care for a child, especially when parents separate
dictionaryExamples: When they divorced, it was Nicola who won custody of their two children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents were fighting a long and tiring battle in court, over the custody of us children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: when someone is kept in prison, usually while they are waiting for a trial in court
dictionaryExamples: He is being held in custody in Los Angeles charged with assault.
He was taken into custody by Mexican authorities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only was he badly injured during the following years, but he was [also] kept in custody by the Russians for about two years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a way of behaving or a belief which has been established for a long time
dictionaryExamples: local/ancient customs
In my country, it's the custom to get married in white.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a custom that [the] bride wears [a] white wedding dress and she [carries a] bouq[u]et of flowers in her hands. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: normal or expected for a particular person, situation, or society
dictionaryExamples: It is customary for the chairman to make the opening speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is also customary among youngster[s] to talk about new films or movies. International English Language Testing System; C1; Others

sense.def: a person who buys goods or a service
dictionaryExamples: a satisfied customer
Mrs. Wilson is one of our regular customers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunat[e]ly I will not [be able to] go because this week I have to go to Germany to do business with one of our customers. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: the place where your bags are examined when you are going into a country, to make sure you are not carrying anything illegal
dictionaryExamples: customs officials
to go through customs
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I work as [a] customs officer and I meet a lot of foreign people every day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: to use  a knife or other sharp tool to divide something, remove part of something, or make a hole in something
dictionaryExamples: She cut herself a slice of bread.
He cut the cake into six pieces and gave each child a slice.
Cut the meat up into small pieces.
I usually cut off any fat when I'm preparing meat.
Who cuts your hair?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cut the cake with my friends. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to injure yourself on a sharp object which makes you bleed
dictionaryExamples: She cut her finger on some broken glass.
Careful or you'll cut yourself with that knife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The robot had cut its hand. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to reduce the size or amount of something
dictionaryExamples: cut prices/costs
The company is cutting 300 jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The third thing is Internet [business]. This way is very good for both consumer and company, to cut the cost. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to remove part of a film or piece of writing
dictionaryExamples: Several scenes had been cut when the movie was shown on TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll see how the film is cut to [fit] the story into two hours, more or less. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to go from one side of an area to the other, instead of going around it
dictionaryExamples: If we cut across this field, it will save time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wanted to cut across the garden of the house, and climbed over the fence. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If a problem or subject cuts across different groups of people, all of those groups are affected by it or interested in it.
dictionaryExamples: Interest in the Internet cuts across all age groups.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The TV has a wide audience cutting across all the sections of the society. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: to reduce the amount of money being spent on something
dictionaryExamples: We have had to cut back on training this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are ways to cut back on spending. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

blocks.phrasalVerb: cut down sth or cut sth down

sense.def: If you cut down a tree or bush, you make it fall to the ground by cutting it near the bottom.
dictionaryExamples: The new owners cut down the apple trees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People cut down the tropical rainforest to get the wood and [make] room for agriculture. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to reduce the amount, number, length or size of something
dictionaryExamples: They've cut her hours down at work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll see that this will help you to cut down your overtime in the long run. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to eat or drink less of a particular thing, usually in order to improve your health
dictionaryExamples: I'm trying to cut down on the amount of sugar I eat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly you must quit smoking and you must cut down on coffee. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb: cut off sb/sth or cut  sb/sth off

sense.def: to stop providing something such as electricity or water
dictionaryExamples: If we don't pay the gas bill, we'll be cut off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's when the electricity was cut off. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to prevent people from reaching or leaving a place, or to separate them from other people
dictionaryExamples: The whole village was cut off by flooding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were isolated [from] the other nearby villages because the snow cut off the only [road to] our village. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: cut out sth or cut sth out

sense.def: to remove something or form a shape by cutting, usually something made of paper or cloth
dictionaryExamples: She cut out his picture from the magazine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make it cheaper, cut the coupons out of the papers, don't go shopping when you're hungry and try to stick to your budget. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to stop eating or drinking something, usually to improve your health
dictionaryExamples: I've cut out red meat from my diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think they should also try to cut out cigarettes and take some exercise besides changing [their] eating habits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

phrasalBlocks.phrase: not be cut out to be sth/not be cut out for sth

sense.def: to not have the right qualities for something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not really cut out to be a nurse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I still think her behavior was absolutely beastly, because students will always make mistakes but it is vital not to reprimand them too harshly otherwise they will lose all their confidence and become convinced that they are not cut out for school. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

blocks.phrasalVerb: cut up sth or cut  sth up

sense.def: to cut something into pieces
dictionaryExamples: Could you cut up the cake and put it on plates?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cut up the cake. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an injury made when the skin is cut with something sharp
dictionaryExamples: He suffered cuts and bruises in the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have got a broken knee, but apart from that and a few cuts and bruises, I'm all right. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a reduction in the number or amount of something
dictionaryExamples: tax/job cuts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, due to gover[n]ment spending cuts he has lost his employment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a reduction of something, usually to save money
dictionaryExamples: The company has made cutbacks and closed one of its factories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There have been enormous cutbacks in the budget and children and teenagers are the ones who have suffered the most. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: very modern and with all the newest developments
dictionaryExamples: cutting-edge design/technology
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, in the past our previous generation could not enjoy such cutting-edge technology as it was not developed well before 1970. International English Language Testing System; C1; Nepali

sense.def: a document which describes your education, qualifications and the jobs you have done, which you send to an employer that you want to work for
dictionaryExamples: Send me your CV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Th[ese] students are the same as me, they want [to] pass their exams next year and put the degree on their CV. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a series of events which happen in a particular order and are often repeated
dictionaryExamples: the life cycle of a moth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, the main disadvantage of zoos is that they put animals away from something which belongs to the natural cycle of life. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a bicycle
dictionaryExamples: a cycle route/ride
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing about our cycle routes. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to ride a bicycle
dictionaryExamples: I usually walk or cycle to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We cycled around Hungary.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: the sport or activity of riding a bicycle
dictionaryExamples: professional cycling
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to go swimming and cycling. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: someone who rides a bike
dictionaryExamples: He drove into a cyclist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [There] was me, my friend and a group of ten people guided by a professional cyclist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: believing that people are only interested in themselves and are not sincere
dictionaryExamples: Many people have become cynical about politicians.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently, we had better not jump to such cynical conclusions and enjoy the competition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian
